RATING: 6
08-12-14: This one is a good game, but a bit of a letdown. I bought into the BGG hype but the game itself felt much more like hard work than a game (i.e. FUN). And by hard work, I don't mean the hard but rewarding kind, but more of the boring, tedious kind. I'd give it another shot.

UPDATED 4-27-15: After having played two other Ignacy games since first playing this game a year ago, I think the quote above "the game itself felt much more like hard work than a game" could apply to all of them. Witcher I have no desire to play again, at all. Imperial Settlers I'll try again, but with only 2 players. Robinson Crusoe feels like I'm doing my taxes, but at least when I do my taxes I have the reward of receiving a refund a few weeks later.

RATING: 7
I think there's a lot to explore here (no pun intended). It offers something truly thematic, whilst utilising many of the Euro-mechanics I am always drawn towards in a game. The production is of a high quality, but the rulebook is terrible.

I traded this away. It's a good game, but it suffers from the same "problem" as D-Day Dice. Unless you invest time in playing through the scenarios in sequence with the same players over and over (or play solitaire), you never get the opportunity to move on past Scenario 1 or 2. I play a lot with new players, so this sort of game doesn't suit me well.

Traded for Catacombs with 2 expansions, and no regrets.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
How many bad things can happen to survivors on an island? Turns out -quite a few. I mean, we are talking about a cursed island here. Maybe it should be called Cursing Island?

There are survival games and then there is Robinson Crusoe. This isn't your typical cooperative game of trying to get the objective before time runs out. This is a slog. This is a fistfight against nature. Every decision matters and every successful die roll is cause for celebration. The pain starts early and never relents, as you lose health from every direction. That moment you build the shelter is a huge relief. When you finally get the roof up, you'll be dancing around for joy. Every moment in between is a time of nerve-wrecking hair loss.

There are six scenarios that come with the game that wildly change the feeling of how to approach your goals. However, the basic laws still apply and you'll only be successful if you prioritize well and take some risks. Playing safe on the Cursed Island only prolongs your suffering. The theme is incredibly strong, as you find yourself having to choose between food and warmth, between shelter and the wood pile, between morale and construction. The only easy decision about Robinson Crusoe is that you must add it to your collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The 7 rating is generous here.  Even after finally mastering the rules, I never really found this to be very immersive.  I also found the wild unpredictability annoying for such a difficult game to learn.  I came within a couple of die rolls of beating the hardest scenario, set it up and played it again with an almost identical strategy...and died in about the third round.

This is one of the only games I've played solo.  One play with 4 players and several on my own.

UPDATE : Lowered the rating to a 5.  There was just too much that was frustrating about the game.  While there were some positives, they get overshadowed by too many negatives.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is probably the most thematic game I own. It so perfectly captures being stranded on a desert island, the thrill of discovering something that'll save you, the crushing dread of a giant wild animal attacking you and then the deflation of defeat when he comes back several turns later to eat your food too. The rules are written terribly but I ignore this so readily because the different parts work together so well and we just get lost in the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Excellent co-op. Feels very thematic, invites loads of discussion around the table and is exceedingly challenging. It is a sandbox game for sure (with sand!). My only concern now is the difficulty. Is it even possible to defeat this game? The first scenario, maybe so. But the others? No way unless the cards fall exactly right and the dice do not betray you. Some might enjoy the brutality, but I find I give up after a few crushing defeats. It feels like the game shouts a playground dare - one that I am just not willing to take up too often.

RATING: 6
2014-09-15
I've got really mixed feelings over this one. The theme can't get much better, but somehow the cluttered set of rules stand in the way of immersion. Instead of pondering what's best for survival, you spend your time trying to figure out how the book keeping works and what is written on all the cards. Furthermore, there are certain actions that are absolute necessities, but why make execution of those actions too complicated. Take hunting for an example. Thematically it makes sense, that you first have to track down the animals before hunting them down. But for gameplay, it just makes it too complicated. 

I guess Robinson Crusoe will get better after half a dozen of games under your belt, but considering its length, I just do not see myself playing often enough.

Here is my tip for all you designers out there making thematic games. Keep the rules fairly simple and ask yourself whether you could streamline the rules so that things are accomplished with single actions instead of small incremental ones. Ask the play testers, whether they actually felt like being in the game instead of trying to figure out, in which order to perform things.

Robinson Crusoe is by no means broken, and I could play again. It is just a bit too fiddly for my taste of thematic co-ops. But at least it's better than Castaways, which is a half finished product compared to this one.

2016-11-23
I have to add that this game can be ridiculously hard to the point that it is not enjoyable anymore. I love challenges and I do not mind losing. However, I do want to feel that, despite failing in the end, I gave a valiant effort and made some progress at least. 

My experiences with Crusoe have sometimes been quite far from this. Whatever improvements or progress we have made has been immediately snatched away by random events. You build a shovel only for it to break. You build a fire only for rain to quench it. You find food only for you to swallow your own tongue. Then halfway through the game you realise that it is mathematically impossible for you to win anymore even if bad things stopped. And this can happen even if you play a perfect game. It just seems that it takes more to beat a perfect storm. Thus I have come to suspect you have to have all the stars align on the first couple of rounds to even have a slightest of chance of winning. If this is really true, it certainly is not a good thing that a 2-3 hour game is decided during the first 20 minutes but you still have play it till the bitter end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
+Highly thematic.
+Gives players lots of freedom to work together in a meaningful way.
+The game responds to what the players do through event cards geared towards the actions the players take.
+Multiple scenarios offer numerous ways to play and keep the game fresh.  The designer has already released a new print-and-play scenario free of charge!
+Lots and lots of events and treasures mean you will very rarely see the same ones pop up.

=Some "interesting" translations on some cards and other components.  Usually these aren't enough to make the cards/components unplayable.
=There are a lot of little rules to remember in this game, which means it's easy to not play entirely correctly.
=This game is VERY hard.  I haven't yet decided if it's TOO hard, but it's close.  I don't mind games with a steep learning curve, but I'm concerned this one is simply designed to make even the best players lose more often than not.  With shorter games, I don't mind losing fairly often because I have time to try again, but with a longer game like this one, I'd at least like to have a 50/50 chance of winning with competent play.

-The game feels highly chaotic and random.  Winning seems more about luck than good strategy.
-The rulebook is terrible.  Very poor translation with lots of grammatical errors and typos.  I can understand problems with translation, but how hard is it to catch "Ilsand"?
-Even ignoring translation issues, the rules are still lacking important details and are not well laid out.
-There are only 4 player roles in the game, and 1 of them is only supposed to be used for 4 players.  The rest of the game has a lot of variety, but it seems they skimped on perhaps the most important part for adding to replayability.
-The tokens are not the best quality.  They are rather thin.

UPDATE 8/23/14: Recently received the Z-man version of the game as a gift.  While the tokens are much improved in this version, the grammar errors and rulebook readability are not.  I can't tell if Z-man had a proofreader look at the game, but if they did, the person did a poor job.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
+ Sailor Character, Promo Beast Cards, Promo Event Cards, Poachers Scenario, Treasure Island Scenario, Tracing Doctor Livingstone Scenario.

Robinson Crusoe is truly an amazing co-operative game and one of the best designs I've ever played of any board game genre! So far it's the only title that was actually able to marry a rich and interesting theme with really solid game mechanisms.

In fact I find most thematic co-operative games deeply disappointing, as they usually have an awful lot of reading cards and then a bunch of lazy design choices on the side. Take Arkham Horror as an example. I don't want to roll dice for 2-3 hours and have clunky mechanisms with lots of exception for no good reason. Theme is just not a good enough excuse for that. Robinson Crusoe instead has a clever worker placement system, it has resource management, it actually offers choices and tactics to explore. It's true, the game has a lot of small rules and exceptions for the sake of theme like Arkham does. Yet they all make sense also on the game-play side of things, because they actually offer a depth of choices. 

At the same time Robinson Crusoe is able to deliver an amazing story thanks to a wonderfully clever mechanism: something happens to you, you might have to make a choice and that choice might come to bite you later. This is how you develop a story in a board game. So many people rave - undeservedly, in my opinion - about the Crossroad system in Dead of Winter, which is basically made of Arkahm Horror style events that trigger for mostly arbitrary reasons. Instead, let me tell you... Robinson Crusoe is what the Crossroad system wishes to be when he grows up.

Also I would like to mention that, partly thanks to the strength of the theme, I was able to teach and play this game even with non-gamers and younger children... and they were all engaged in the experience! I'm really amazed by the genius of this design and how everything has a thematic but functional explanation.

So take all of this, put it in a great package with amazing artwork and cool wooden components, like the new edition does. Then add a tall deck of cards for constantly new stories, 7 scenarios for a huge amount of replayability and you have a must buy product! I really can't recommend this game enough. Robinson Crusoe is just a fantastic game and one that I can see myself playing a lot in the future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pros:  Great theme, very challenging, adjustable difficulty.  Expandability.  Replayability.  This game beats Arkham Horror for me in the coop category for several reasons.  1.) less fiddliness.  2.) more randomish surprise elements...leading to more varied play experiences.  3.) the fight to survive feels more real, and the desire to play again to do better is there.

Cons:  Can be difficult to adjust the difficulty to where it is a challenge without being an impossibility.  Rules book is bad.  Do yourself a favor and download the many helpful pdfs on the geek that people have posted, this saves much time and aggravation.  All or nearly all of the rules information *is* in the book, but its not laid out logically leading to frustration.  

I have played this so far solo, and solo as 4 chars.  I find solo to be very hard, also I found solo as 4 chars very hard.  However, Solo as 4 chars + Friday & dog made the game challenging without the sense of impossibility.  I like this aspect.

I will be playing this with my nieces soon, and it will be good to keep Friday and the dog for that playthrough due to them (the girls) making sub-optimal choices due to lack of experience, and so I won't feel like I will have to alpha-game it just to survive.

This is a big point.  The alpha-gamer trait will rise in the alpha-gamer if he/she feels that they will lose without optimal choices.  If, however, there is a sufficient buffer of sub-optimal play choices, the alpha gamer trait will be rendered tolerable (this is my theory).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Good quality components but some of the cards are badly translated and generally lacking in editing. Since this is supposed to be a game that tells a story, poor language really detracts from the experience and prevents you from really immersing yourself in the theme. 

Both setup and gameplay is too fiddly for me, with different tokens and counters and resources constantly being moved around.

The rules are not bad per se, but they could have been implemented better. Lots of questions arise in the details, and there is much potential for human error.

All things considered the game is mediocre. They should hire some author or something to edit and re-write the cards in english. A thematic game like this, if any, should have a lot of great flavor text.

A bit more creativity and a few more positive effects among the event-cards would make the game more fun. Also the wording on the effects should be more consistent.

RATING: N/A
Theme! An incredible co-op experience that puts you right into the shoes of the bedraggled survivors. Utilises Ignacy Trzewiczek's genius way of marrying theme to mechanics perfectly. Does require scouring the forums and faqs in order to navigate the messy rulebook however.

My only real complaint is that it seems a little too easy (playing with two plus Friday, or three plus Dog), especially since for some reason it is notorious for being difficult. Perhaps we were just lucky in that we just 'got it' from the get go. But after multiple plays we have only failed once, against the dreaded cannibals, and even then it was down to the wire.

RATING: 3
Early positive impressions faded fast. 

The reality is the game is a bit too much the same from scenario-to-scenario. Good players will simply work out what needs to be done and only bad luck will stop them from doing it. The events have a lot of flavour, but they don't really change how you play, just make things easier or harder. 

Still, serious gamers might not be it's core audience. If they are, it's a noble failure - if not, it's a disposable frolic.

획득자원은 고정인데(사냥감 보상도 고정), 인원이 4명이되면 자원부족, 2명이면 행동력부족으로 3명이 가장 적절.

RATING: 6.5

I'd think that this was a fluke or a rule played wrong, but I think I've heard people talking about how many times they had to play, just to succeed once.

Possibly best as a solo game. Anything else and you're screwed. Or, look for a variant that makes it easier.

RATING: 6
It's a beautiful game with well integrated mechanics, especially in the adventure decks that get shuffled into events. I'm not certain it beats out other co-op games for me, but it's an uplifting alternative with easily tweaked difficulty settings. The game suffers from the illusion of choice; if you don't have enough food then you obviously go harvest or hunt. If you haven't built a level 3 or 4 roof and you'll roll two weather dice, you obviously focus on that. If you don't have one of the two +1 production tokens you obviously go for that. The engine building is really mundane in that way by punishing any choice that isn't one of the one or two optimal moves (regardless of whether you succeed or not).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting thematic co-op!  I appreciate how bits and pieces of it work nicely to make a thematic experience, and I think the game as a whole is well-designed, but there are a bunch of little oddities - the fiddliness is pretty major, for one.  Also, the different types of beast attacks and limited hunting deck (and the death iguana!) are somewhat weird.  It's a good game, but I've found that the experience isn't as clean as, say, Eldritch Horror and the puzzle isn't as interesting as Ghost Stories.

RATING: 8
Robinson Crusoe introduced me into the golden age of board games. The cooperative adventure of survival is always a blast. Sitting around the table with 2 or 3 other friends, with everyone holding their breath at a die roll or card draw is just thrilling.

The game has a reputation of being overly complicated, so I would suggest watching a gameplay runthrough/overview first. After that, it will seem more straightforward. (I have not played the latest edition but I suspect they have greatly improved on this)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Not my kind of co-operative game. There is absolutely nothing to stop one player from "running" the whole game. The game itself seems extremely luck-driven based on the card effects, which not much in the way of meaningful choices. The narrative isn't strong enough to create an immersive feel that could counter-act the above (as Arkham Horror does). The characters seem boring and hard to identify with: it can be very hard to actually use any special abilities, so your characters are interchangeable, and indeed often it doesn't matter which player's action pawns go in a particular place. Almost seems like some of the worst aspects of thematic, co-op, and Euro games combined.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not a game for the pessimistic.  Pretty much every card draw is a bad thing.  You will lose the first couple of games you play and it takes a few games to get into the flow of the game.  The rules can be a bit clunky and the book is not the easiest to scan through to quickly find a rule but if you role-play it and make any rules decisions thematically, it's not too bad.

Mostly, it's a puzzle game, you need to work out what items are available to you and what is critical to succeed in the scenario.  The rest is damage limitation and deciding when to push your luck to take extra actions.

Overall an enjoyable game, hard but it does make you want to replay "if we do THIS next time, we might win"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Interesting coop that mixes a bunch of Euro mechanics and Ameritrash variety in a way that doesn't quite work for me.  While it is an attractive game, I found elements of it problematic from a playability POV.  First, there is a lot of text to read on the cards, but the font is too small.  Much of it is in cursive which makes it even harder to read.  

Bottomline is that I don't really get the hoopla.  I might get a copy at some point if I can get it cheap, but at normal OLGS prices, never mind the going price given its current short supply, I will pass.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The game i prefer at the moment. 

An excellent survival and adventure game. It's a clever mix between Arkham Horror and Agricola. Bad things keep falling on your head, and you can succeed only with a good coordination and strategy. A lot of tough decisions, but a lot less fiddy than Arkham. The game is quite expensive, but offers already a lot of replayability. If you compare with the Arkham encounter decks containing only 7 cards, you'll play a lot more with RC without going through the decks.
All the scenarios offer a real different gameplays.

RATING: N/A
new in shrink
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Un poco lioso al principio ya que hay que tener en cuenta muchos conceptos distintos y todos son necesarios en cada ronda de juego. Esto suele resultar algo abrumador durante las primeras partidas y puede desanimar a algunos jugadores.

Cuando todos los jugadores conocen bien el juego la partida es mucho más dinámica y las conversaciones se centran más en la planificación que en discutir sobre las reglas o lo que puede o no puede hacerse. 

Como cooperativo hay que tener mucho cuidado con el "efecto líder". Con tantas cosas por hacer y tan pocas acciones por jugador es muy fácil que alguien "sugiera" a sus compañeros lo deben hacer en cada turno. Y eso no es divertido.

Como solitario requiere de bastante preparación para empezar a jugar pero una vez comienzas la partida no se hace pesado, repetitivo o aburrido. Funciona exactamente igual que el cooperativo pero sin tener que ponerte de acuerdo con nadie sobre cuales serán tus próximas acciones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have only played the introduction scenario, solo, and I've had a great time so far.

I think the game balances quite well the necessity to explore, gather resources, build stuff, and defend against the elements, as any game with this theme should.

Of all coop games that I've played, this seems to be the toughest to beat. It certainly requires the whole group thinking together to figure out the puzzle that each scenario will pose.

RATING: 8
Purchased new from sale of Warhammer Army.  

I really like playing this one.  I have messed up the rules several times in teaching games and playthroughs.  Because it has mostly been new groups each time, I have mostly played the first scenario.  I have only once played one of the other scenarios.  I was a bit surprised in that playthrough about how much the threat to the players changed.  It was not so much that the game was more difficult, but that the threat was different.  

Once you get your mind around the rules, it is not too difficult to teach this game working through the steps of a turn.  The player aids are also great for this.  Recommend picking those up from the files section here on BGG.

Thematic/Adventure
Coop

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
I was ready to really love this game, but it was so dang hard that I found myself feeling bad when playing it. I've never been so beat down and defeated by a game while playing it for so long. The thing I love out disaster style co-ops (Pandemic, Flash Point, etc.) is that it seems dire, but there are moments of hope. It may be false hope and the house may crumble around you a turn later from that hotspot, or the big outbreak, but at least you had a chance. Robinson Crusoe I almost never feel like I have a chance. I really hope that with more plays we are able to unravel the mystery of how to not completely suck at this game. I do have a lot of fun with it and the theme is spot-on throughout (especially when the event cards come back to haunt you) but we've only tried the 1st scenario and its supposed to be the easiest! I enjoy a tough game and I don't think that it would be any fun to have an auto-win, but a feel bright spots during the game would be great. I hope that a future expansion would add some tools that make it a little smoother. Still highly recommended and I'd ask to play it again. Solid game and theme, just be warned that it is crazy tough.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
12/26/14:  I wish that the designer had cared enough about the game to put more time into the rulebook.  Right now I'm frustrated with vague rules.  The rulebook should have been several pages longer  For example, only in the errata is it mentioned that your weapons level can go above what is shown on the charts.  Nowhere in the instructions does it talk about the map and the fact that incomplete tile areas though drawn in, are not playable.  The discovery tokens are not explained at all, you need to puzzle out what they mean or check the FAQ.  The green, gray, and brown cards are muted and very similar in color.  This mostly matters when you're checking the symbols on the encounter cards.  With respect to the colors, I do have to say that I prefer them to bright fluorescence that some american games have.

Rating may go up with more plays.

Once you get past the rules, you have an engaging game that has a lot of repeatability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
So, this is a pure co-op. That means it automatically loses points in my book. There's no intrigue. That said, I don't necessarily hate it.

My thoughts are - for a co-op to be good, you need to rely on other player's decisions, and not be able to make those decisions by committee. Robinson Crusoe MAY be complex enough to take care of this, but I still feel like a particularly informed player could go about correcting everyone's moves.

Again, I don't hate it (as much as Mike probably thinks I do - Just really wasn't in the mood for a co-op) but there's a bit too much randomness, and not enough strategy to really scratch the itch for me. Hell, I'll give it a couple more plays even.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A bit like a co-op version of Agricola.  You have all the pressure of trying to survive in harsh conditions but instead of trying to out-efficient the other layers you work together to solve the puzzles.

the game is very evocative of the theme.  I especially like the primitive tech tree that is available to the players.  

the downside is that unlike most co-op games, the different roles don't seem to play all that differently from one another.  The players don't really have much of an identity.

In addition this game does nothing to solve the common problem of "alpha players" in games where you all work together.  

These two weakness combine to create an experience that feels more like a very complicated jigsaw puzzle rather than a game.

That said, I think this is worth your time if you want to graduate from Pandemic into a slightly meatier or more thematic co-op game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not my cup of tea. Maybe when I'm retired and I have all the time in The world. Too slow from the giddy up and other ways/games I'd prefer for the time investment.

Plays from 1 to 4 players.

RATING: 9
A játék nagyon jó! De azért nem BSG... Kiskoromban ez volt az egyik kedvenc regényem, legalább 3-4-szer olvastam. Ehhez képest kicsit csalódás, hogy nem konkrétan Robinsonról szól a játék, hanem általában a robinsonokról, de még így is nagyon jó a hangulata!!! Aprólékosan kidolgozott, szép, tele jó ötlettel, jól is működik, kihívást is jelent, és nagynak érzem az újrajátszhatóságot is (küldetések, rengeteg kártya...). Elég sok apróságra figyelni kell, sok a választható akció, de pont ez a játék nagy erénye, hogy elég nagy szabadságot ad, minden játékban  egy teljesen más történet rajzolódhat ki. Akiket érdekel a téma, vagy csak szeretik a kooperativakat, azok feltétlenül próbálják ki. Amit még kiemelnék: szuper az ikonrendszer! Egyedül az építésnél jelezhetnék, hogy mire vonatkozik az akció.
---
Húha! Nem emlékeztem, hogy ez ennyire jó! Javítok a pontszámon! 2 év eltelt, újra elővettük, ezúttal az volt a nagy különbség, hogy alaposan felkészültem a szabályból, jobban átláttam a játékot. Nagyon jó volt a hangulat, részben a társaságnak részben a játéknak köszönhetően. Szuper!! Megyek is kiegeket rendelni:)
---
Zseniális ez a játék. Nem gondoltam, hogy egy-egy küldetés ennyire más tud lenni. Az adott keretből teljesen mást hoz ki 1-1 sztori. Nagyon tetszik a játékrendszer, és a hangulat, szuper! Tovább javítok a ponton, kedvenc kategóriába kerül a játék!
---
Valamiért a 6. küldetés volt a legkönnyebb nekünk, pedig papíron az a legnehezebb. Lehet hogy csak szerencsénk volt, mert néhány jó lap jött az elején, de végig maxon volt mindenkinek az élete, éhezés se volt sosem... Némelyik más küldetésben alig marad életünk a végére, sőt a kannibálos akár 3-4 kör alatt mindenkit le tud nullázni.
---
Az első nagy kieggel még szuperebb, de az elpakolás már kezd macera lenni, nem is nagyon vesszük elő 1 partiért, szinte mindig kettőt játszunk egyszerre.
---
Na végigpróbáltunk minden küldetést, ami 2014 őszéig hivatalosan megjelent. Tényleg csak próbáltuk, mert a 13-ból 11-et csak egyszer játszottunk. Minden létező könnyítést igénybe vettünk, e nélkül némelyik pálya szerintem 20-adjára se sikerülne, ha így vesszük, több száz parti is benne lehet a teljes eddigi Robinson univerzumban.
---
Egyedül és ketten elég nehéznek érzem, talán hárman a legkönnyebb?!

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.3
A game that thematically is very appealing though imo falls a bit short of what it could possibly be. The main board tries to stay thematic and succeeds up to a point, but it becomes less functional and intuitive as a result of the effort. The rulebook could be way better structured and explained to make more sense and avoid the frequent back and forth during the first 4-5 plays as well as the refuge to online faqs and errata in order to find the rule about several stuff that can be misinterpreted and/or misplayed.Overall, rather hard game to beat, mainly because of the luck elements in the game(random card pick for the seeding of the decks, card draw as well as dice rolls) which makes it a great challenge. Trying to beat it at least gives you a certain satisfactory after a few trial and error situations, which makes this game still stay in my collection for now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I like this game. Makes me feel like I'm on a deserted island
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I recall the designer stating on his blog that Robinson Crusoe solves the alpha player problem of cooperative games. I found this is not true at all: every turn players discuss and play at once, and this is very likely to end in one player find the best way of play and drive the others.

Apart for this quibble, I found Robinson a pleasant experience: it is random and not too deep in choices it offers (often the only choice is among playing it safe placing two counters on an action, or trying to do something more but rolling dice), but the thematic drive offers a satisfactory and funny couple of hours.

The production value is good if not stellar, with the notable exception of the rulebook. Portal has a name for good, quirky games with terrible rules writing, and Robinson is no exception.

Anyway, the game is definitely worth a try, and since my girlfriend loves it, it will see the table often...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impression: The word that immediately comes to mind is "brutal". Underneath the beautiful components of this game is a system that is designed to kick you in the teeth. Repeatedly. Thematically apt goals such as acquiring food, shelter, and basic tools, and hampered by the elements, wild beasts, and random events. Mechanically, it all makes sense and is fairly intuitive after an initial play-through. The AI providing the obstacles is generally very visible and you are aware of the punishment you're about to face. The problem is that it feels, at least initally, like there's very little you can do to prevent that punishment from occurring.

10 Plays: After having bought the latest edition of the game, I can't get enough of it. Every session provides a different experience with new stories to tell. I can now teach this game in about 10 minutes and everyone I've taught it to has enjoyed it. One would think that with only 7 official scenarios the game would become stale quickly. Not so. Most of my plays have been with the 1st scenario and I crave to play it some more. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is the most accessible theme for casual players and the game is the #1 best co-op I own. Even though the game is longer, the theme is very apparent and rich in the gameplay. The events are not as random as other games because of the time aspect of the crises and makes for a well-connected thematic story. 

It's not as fiddly as AH, and a lot easier for people to pick up than Space Cadets.

RATING: 10
An excellent game! Full of adventures but still you have to think a lot while choosing your actions in order to win. Rules seem a bit compicated at the beginning but later, after a couple of games everyting will be clear and obvious. Once you know the rules it is easy to teach other people. My son (11 years old) learned to play very quickly and adores the game.
It is a game you can play alone and it is a great fun too! Additionaly you can make up your own scenarios and share with friends.
Robinson is a must!!!

RATING: 8
Immersive theme and excellent game design. However, both learning & teaching this game can be a chore. This game is easily one of the hardest games I've played. 
If you like difficult games & can handle the inevitable losses and deaths you will suffer then this game may be for you! However even though the game is very hard it doesn't make you feel like you have no hope, you still feel in it even in the games you may eventually lose. 
Rich theme, solid mechanics (euro-worker placement, exploration, dice rolling & card play), very well designed. Instructions are a chore they are well written enough but could be structured much better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Great theme but the game itself is ridiculous and not really all that fun to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really like the unique theme, and it feels relatively collaborative, but it's not the easiest game to just break out and play.  Setup takes a while, the rules are unclear in places, there are apparently disagreements about which set of rules to use, and the different components are unclear (e.g., white wooden cubes are fur (?), but there are also white plastic cubes).  Additionally, I often feel like I'm going to make the best move I can regardless of the rest of the team...not like we're all trying to knit together into something more impressive, but just doing our own things.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
FAVORITE HEAVY WEIGHT COOPERATIVE GAME

1-4 Players / 90-180 Min / Weight: 3.69
Type: Thematic / Co-op / Solo

(Rated and commented after 4 solo plays in two days)

I've tried this only as a solo game so far. 3 times with 1 roles and once with 2 roles. I haven't cleared the first scenario yet even with the easy mode (2 roles + Friday + Dog), but it was close.
It is a very challenging game, but still make me keep playing, which is really amazing.

The biggest complaint about this game is the rulebook is not written very clearly. There are many ambiguous details so I needed to search for the rule forum or FAQ pages for them.

This is very different from Dungeon Petz, which has the similar complexity (weight of RC is 3.6 and weight of Dungeon Petz is 3.5). I recently got Dungeon Petz and found the rulebook was very well written and even very entertaining, so it was much easier to learn from the rule book that Robinson Crusoe.

RATING: 9
My first (and for a long time only) game rated 10.

This game is a blast. It is freakin' hard but fair all the time. All events and dangers delivered ooze with theme and make you feel like being the unfortunate person stranded on this deadly island.

With various player roles, 6 different(!) scenarios and a ton of event cards you get a massive amount of replay value.

Only draw back are the rules. This game offers a variety of different systems working together to make your life hard and therefor the rules are quite heavy.
Even over 30 plays it still occurs to me that I may have missed something during play (not very often though).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is as near a perfect Co-op game as you can get. The only reason for not rating it a 10 is due to the unrelenting tempo of the game. Even in real life, unrelenting tempo takes a break once in a while, with a lull to catch one's breath. 
With RC, the tempo never lets the players take a step back to enjoy their progress (or lament over the lack of), and "take-in" the game. It's a fire hose pointed at you for the entire session. So the 9.5 is for the near-perfect design. But it loses a half point for not being as fun as it otherwise might have been, for the tempo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

The challenges are difficult given the time you have to complete, but it makes for a great experience. This is a great combination of theme, some randomness and worker placement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A highly thematic, well-produced cooperative game that is not easy to win.
+ Different scenarios add replayability and variety
+ Lots of ways to use your workers giving you lots of choices to make each round
+ Character powers let each player offer something unique to them
- [b]So much luck.[/b] Cooperatives often rely on luck to balance the game but RC takes it to the next level. 
- Very susceptible to the "alpha" player problem that many coops have.
- Long play time. Outstays its welcome?

The high luck factor combined with the 90-120 minute play time will keep this game in "good, not great" territory for me. I think Pandemic does a better job balancing the luck-to-length factor and so I would play that game more often. The theme I really enjoy and I've only played the first scenario but would be interested in playing others to see if they change the game in interesting ways. The long play time and somewhat fiddly setup will prevent this game from getting to the table too often but that's alright with me. I honestly have no idea why this game is a Top 25 BGG game. Then again I like Dead of Winter even less and it's about the same ranking. I guess people really like well-produced, scenario-based coops?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Pros
Another promising cooperative

Cons

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The first four plays of this game were lukewarm for me.  I felt the rules really were convoluted and confusing, which did impact the first few plays.  I stuck with the game, however, as the game seemed to be one I should really like.  After my fifth play, the game started to gel.  The different phases of the game started to make sense, and I began to love the extremely rich theme that is integrated into every aspect of the game. 
 
Now, I love the game and I always want to play it.  I feel it is, hands down, the deepest and most strategic cooperative game I own.  Also, every time I play it, I am impressed by how the mechanics themselves tell a story.  Because of this, the game created wonderful experiences for the players playing it.  It is one of my favorite games right now.  I am glad that I stuck with it.

RATING: 7.1
This game was the most fun I've ever had while starving.
a co-op game was pretty refreshing since we've been at each others throats due to seafall. if you take my artifacts, i will punch you in the face will. If you ever sat on your living room sofa and wondered how you and your buddies would do on a deserted island, this game would probably give you an accurate picture. Apparently you can get seriously crippled trying to make a brick. Only through teamwork can you scrounge up enough bananas and sushi to survive. 
Will says most people don't win at this game. well we won on our first try. with minimal rules fudging. we win all the time. we won so hard.  
would not recommend to small children, unless they are winners.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I wanted to like this game so much but ended up loathing it. I felt so stressed and desperate fumbling for food and shelter, only to die by the hands, or say claws of a vicious tiger or fangs of a snake. Helpless, hungry, cold, because it was actually snowing, and very very low on morale. 
All these elements are actually in this game! What kind of a person sucks all the joy of the fantasy of being stranded on a desert island!?! COME ON NOW this could have been a much nicer game, a brighter more filled with wonder and beauty as you discover uncharted territories, taste delicious fruits nobody has ever tried before, or just decided to hang out by the beach and whittle flutes. 

Come on now, if anybody wants to feel totally desperate and close to death in a co-op game they can play Arkham horror, and that game at least is filled with wonder and awe against the unimaginable horrors from the unknown vastness of existence. 

Robinson Crusoe sucks the joy of exploration. With the players only focusing on getting those damn cubes or building a cabin in a very very slow and boring way. Moving little pucks. Well I'm all out of pucks, you know.
I'm out!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Despite being promoted as a thematic game, Robinson Crusoe isn’t thematic at all: in fact, as its theme wears out quickly, it clearly shows its true nature, that of a dry and extremely boring game revolving about the resource management only.

Actually when playing you couldn’t care less about your characters and their survival on the island, even more so since the game itself doesn’t even bother to try and tell a story: it’s only interested in the way its rules work and make it harder for you to collect the resources you need.

In the end it lasts too long, plays too complex and feels too cold to be even remotely fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Scenario 1 completed on 2nd try - 46 VP (Cook). Possibly lots of errors in play noted.
Scenario 1 completed 3rd try - 31 VP (Explorer)
Scenario 2 completed 1st try - 21 VP (Carpenter). Might have been luck on event card draws (less book icons) and exploring only 4 tiki statues. 
2nd attempt (Chef) conceded by round 9 with 4 crosses built but no chance to succeed in the final 2. 3rd attempt (Chef) failed at round 10 - 4 crosses but not enough wood for 5th. Total chef failed attempts = 6.
Scenario 2 completed 7th try - 31 VP (Cook) round 10. Explored exactly 5 tiles, only 2 tiki statues. Hatchet treasure overpowered wood requirements. Only 1 fog area remain.

Scenario 3 - ended in failure on the 5th round due to 3 consecutive Event cards in a row and "Cataclysm" on the 4th draw. Due to that, we had not enough wood to build the raft and in turn be unable to save Jenny while she falls in hunger and cold on the island.

Scenario 4 completed for 2 players - looked most certainly like a loss until final round 8 when the event "Natural Dam Breaks" gave us our most lucky break of the year! A +1 wood needed to top up our wood supply to 3 so that we can finish off the Jolly boat to get us off the island! Absolute craziness and epic finish!

RATING: 6
A really detailed and meticulous cooperative experience. Folks are trying to accomplish a fairly simple task, but the Island is thwarting them at every turn, forcing everyone to engage in the simple act of just staying alive. 

I don't own the game and have only played once. It may not be as difficult as the rules and play-aids make out, but the symbols are not intuitive and are annoying small. This makes it difficult to remember what effects do or even to know they are from across the table.

The topic and theme are attractive, however, so I'm sure I'll be giving this one second and third tries after learning the rules.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The praise is deserved. Others have said it much better than I so can just affirm. What makes it such an immersive, narrative experience is that every mechanic makes so much sense. The decision points occur at the most cleverly appropriate moments and give one the tension that they should have. Luck is there (something that concerned me) but not to the degree that it makes one feel as though one's decisions don't matter. Rather, they round off the edges of the decisions, making them calculated gambles. This is important because the specific gambles one takes becomes a matter of intense discussion, which helps mitigate the alpha player syndrome. It all just...works. This seems to me the most creative co-op game I've ever played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a great game!

So engaging, so intense! Breathtaking!

This is a survival game... and you'll struggle every minute of the game. You need food, but you need a shelter, then you need to upgrade your tools/tech tree. You need to explore in order to do all the other things... then you feel you are running out of time... and then you split your actions so you can do more things... and then things fall apart! You can't do both things well, some get done, and some don't.... and then there's all the events (wild animal, bad weather, psychological reactions...etc) ufff...

It's crazy madness! Things get worse each turn! And when you get that feeling of accomplishment, the very next turn you get caught in troubles again. 


It's simple to play, but so hard to master! You'll be like you can't control a single bit in this game... but it's such a great experience. You'll lose way more than you'll win... but when you win, it's such a great feeling!

One of the best games I've ever played. Certainly, the best co-op I've experienced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
- game is very difficult
- many, many rules
- FAQ can drive players crazy
- You'd better make notes because when You will come back to this game in the future You gonna need them! ;)

- it is a cooperative game (no rivalry)
- players fighting against scenarios, it is easy to lose in this game
- to play this game smoothly one player should know the rules to avoid annoying breaks 
- playing time (120-180 minutes)

Still, if complexity of the game is not a problem You should give a shot.

WARNING: IT IS SUPER HARD TO COME BACK TO THIS GAME AFTER THE  BREAK. IT IS ALMOST IMPOSSIBLE TO REMEMBER ALL THE RULES.

RATING: 7.8
Very very pretty game.

Interesting and fitting theme.  I enjoyed the designer's videos and some of his concepts related to this game before I even played it.

I really enjoyed my first play of this game.  It is however for me very complex in some ways so for me, I don't think it flowed as nicely maybe as it could have.

Intelligently done co-op game that has a very gritty feeling.  There are 6 phases to every round and the weather phase can be brutal.  This game will not be for everyone.  It would work well for people that like an occasional solo game and for groups that enjoy social gaming. (talk and play)

I think a sound track with waves n seagulls would go very nicely with this game and of course storms for the weather phase. :)

There is a quick start file that was crucial to read I think before playing for the first time.

Will you and your party survive?

DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT COMICSTYLES GUIDE... :)

RATING: 10
Got a number of plays under my belt.   A few solo missions, and a handful of group games, with various scenarios.   This a one of my favorite games.

  Love the difficulty of the game.   The theme is really strong.   It might not seem like it through the first round or two, but once you start to realize how much is going on, how many thing are going wrong around you, how many things you actually need to accomplish...your will start to feel like you are stranded.

One con, or the closest thing I can come up with for a con, is that there is a lot to learn to play the game.  Many cards are two sided and during initial setup, it can be difficult to understand what is going on.   But once you get through a game or two, you will have the hang of it.

It drips, from all sides, with theme.   The characters special abilities make them feel like the characters they are.   And the teamwork aspect is very strong.

Fantastic Game.

RATING: 8
My rating is based on solo play. This game is fun, interesting, and challenging. The rules are a little convoluted, sometimes leaving a sense that something might have been missed during a game. The theme and presentation are excellent. Each character gets two actions per turn, and players have to decide which actions to take for the good of the community. I think this system is better suited for solo play, which gives the sole player full control to pursue whichever actions/strategies he/she think best.

RATING: 7.5
Es un juego colaborativo en el que se ofrecen hasta seis escenarios distintos que suceden en una isla en la que los jugadores han naufragados. Sólo he jugado de momento el primer escenario.

Es un juego bastante dificil de ganar, pero asegura una buena experiencia. Es muy cinematográfico. En el primer escenario, tuvimos que cazar, explorar la isla, contruir el campamento, protegernos del frío y demás.. y además construir una pila de madera para hacer señales a un hipotético barco.

Despues de echar un vistazo a los escenarios, el juego no hace sino ganar puntos. Cada escenario ofrece alternativas diferentes que le dan un sabor especial al juego. Muy recomendable. Toda una experiencia.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Enjoyed this one quite a bit. Have only played it in groups of 2 or 3, but I think it would also work very well solo. The game does theme tremendously well--pretty much every gameplay mechanic makes real-world sense.  The six scenarios give quite a lot of replayability, especially since the last one (Robinson Family) will have different objectives and require a different strategy every time. 

Compared to some other co-op games (e.g. Eldritch Horror), the options for scaling the difficulty of a given scenario are not very robust. But the scenarios themselves do range from very easy (Castaways) to very challenging (Cannibal Island, Robinson Family.)

Setup is one downside. There are lots of decks and components, so give over 15 minutes or so to that. My other complaint is that the rules are sometimes unnecessarily complicated. The game could have accomplished much the same thing while being streamlined considerably. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Punishing yet fun co-operative game. Sometimes in games like this I feel like the limited choices really don't leave you with many meaningful decisions, but somehow in Robinson Crusoe I didn't. Although you aren't planning out chain-reaction moves that leverage adjacent tiles, or other typical Euro game moves, there is a good deal of thinking on where to spend your limited action points. The theme was great and it sounds like there are a lot of fun scenarios. Would definitely like to play again.

First play and we lost on Round 6 or 7. Joe died.

Update: Have now played 4 times. Bumping to an 8.

RATING: 10
This is a really well designed game.  It's addicting.  So much going on.  Yes, their is a fair amount of luck with dice rolls and card flips, but as with many games, its all about luck management.  I really feel like I'm on the island struggling to survive.  Plays great solo.  Only reason it is not a 10 is because the rulebook is horrible--a perfect example of how NOT to write a rulebook.  You can't find anything quickly, no index, poor headings, and constant "important" headings which are meaningless and don't help you find the important info you are looking for.  It does take time to learn, but once you do, it is absolutely worth it.

RATING: N/A
Z-Man edition
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Unique

REGLE
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
So many interesting things going on in this game. The idea of having secondary penalties when problems aren't addressed is really smart, and the incorporation of delayed effects back into the event deck is a brilliant and unique mechanic. The game is also carefully calibrated so that you always seem to lose something every turn, and you can never quite do everything you want. Often you need to spend resources to work towards your long-term goals, but need the resources right away to save you from an immediate weather or event effect. Spending two actions on a task can remove the risk of failure, but the sacrifice is often too great to be worth it. The game is brutal, no doubt, but it is also an interesting challenge, and gives you so many ways to win (and lose).

My problems with the game are minor, but may be a huge turn-off for other players. The dice rolling can be frustrating, and often your life or death comes down to the roll of a single die (on the other hand, you can avoid rolling dice by spending more actions, but it's almost as punishing to do so). You also have to basically be ready to be hosed again and again, relentlessly, for the entire course of the game. It's a totally unforgiving experience: only bad things happen to you, and few cards provide any good news. Not for the faint of heart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Despite being a bit overloaded one of the best co-op games around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My joke about Robinson Crusoe is that it's what Arkham Horror would be, if Arkham Horror were any good. Some crazy swingy luck (some of the events are nasty), and over-chromed, but flavorful and nice risk management and resource allocation choices. The extra scenarios - riffing on/ripping off a wide variety of island-survival-literature - are a nice touch too.

Even after a couple games I'm still not totally sure what to make of it, whether it's OK, good, or great (the most likely answer is good). It's over-chromed and a touch over-long, and the swingy events aren't quite so welcome in a game of this length and complexity. Traditional Portal very bad rules and questionable iconography. Balanced against this is the fact that it's a cooperative game that pushes some boundaries and tries to deliver in a spot somewhere between the insanity and crazy but flavorful chaos of Tales of the Arabian Nights and the finely-honed and well-balanced Lord of the Rings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A really challenging cooperative game, which also excels at providing a story. Many decisions you make in the game will come back, usually to haunt you, later, which is really neat, as the event deck "remembers" some experiences you've had.

It's a real challenge just trying to survive on the island, while also trying to fulfill the win conditions of the scenario. Things really can turn ugly!

A great cooperative game if you like a game that punishes you thoroughly, while giving you a chance to pull things out.

RATING: 7
This game is different than many other co-ops. It almost feels like a ”normal” eurogame, which means that it takes quite a while to play and is quite complex. Also, the theme seems to integrate well with the game mechanisms.
There are several scenarios (I only got to try scenario 1 twice, a win and a loss) and different roles which means the replayability should be good, especially considering the lots of cards which will come out randomly each time! However, this doesn’t solve the “alpha male”/”captain”/”Mr. Know-it-all” player problem when one player tells the other what to do.
I love co-ops, but this isn’t my top choice. It was good enough and very different, so if you don’t like co-ops you might still like this one.

Use the official setup, finish the 1st scenario on Jan 25, 2014.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So apparantly it is almost impossible to get every rule right the first times you play this game. We won the first scenario at the first try and were like "that wasn't so hard!" Then we checked the rules and were like: "what, you can only gather wood OR food in the gathering phase?!" I also missed the rule that you have to use more workers for gathering resources and exploring tiles when the tile is not adjacent to your camp. Or that the book symbol triggers a bad event that is written on the scenario card. 

Of course, even if you know the myriads of rules, there is a  probability that you still get things wrong during the game, just because you are not focussed enough. You forget the weather phase, for example, or a token that says "time-consuming action". When you realize these small mistakes a few rounds later in the game, it feels like you cheated. 

Apart from that, this game is great. I really like the permanent sense of discovery and how unpredictable everything is. You cannot "solve" the game. It is not like a puzzle where you can rack your brain and come up with a masterplan. Every round confronts you with another problem and you have to leave some of them to chance as you neither have enough time nor enough resources. This is why the game feels so incredibly organic. You have to decide on the spot, trust your instincts, and be prepared to get screwed despite the best plan you could come up with. It is half an experience, half a game. It is an adventurebook, actually, but this one is much more driven by your own decisions and more atmospheric.        

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This is a great game, but it suffers from 1 thing. Rules! Maybe I haven't played it enough, but remembering the rules/gameplay is difficult on this one. I'm not talking about what all the little nuances on each and every card mean, but just simple gameplay. I have done around 3 plays of this game and still seem to forget something. For comparison sake Scythe has a decent amount of rules, I've played that about 3-4 times, and I remember the rules fairly easy. I would give it a 10, but it lives up to the "you have to play this about 10 times before you'll understand what to do" hype.

RATING: 7
Update Feb 2016:
Did not hit the table often, due to the alpha syndrome and fiddliness in setup. There are much better coop games, and its upcoming Martian theme sibling will have the cards in an app, so sold this one.

---

One of the best solitaires/coop in existence. Don't go in expecting deep decisions, this is an optimization and dice chucking game. If you can avoid alpha gamers, you are in for a great ride. Must have.

+ very thematic, with great narrative
+ easy to play, once you get the hang of it
+ uncomplicated mechanisms that tie well together
+ tough but manageable, well balanced

= luck of the draw galore. Since it's a storytelling game I am ok with it
= although it has many scenarios, I am unsure whether I would play anyone again after I win it

- alpha player syndrome galore
- the rulebook has some gaps, but FAQs exist
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ricky Royal how to videos on YouTube were a must.  I made it through about 1/2 a round solo but due to time limits, gave up.

I enjoy the game but still feel lost despite the video tutorials.  I'll give it another go.  It is indeed fun, but I think it would be more fun as a group game than in solo play.  I'll update this later.

After several more attempts, I finally beat the first scenario.  The game is hard, kind of complicated, and not the typical "worker placement" type of game I normally like.  While it is still fun to play, I think I'd prefer to whip out Agricola, Stone Age, or Lords of Waterdeep over this one...and my kids don't care for this one at all...."too hard, I don't understand it".

After more plays, the game hasn't improved for me and has just been more frustrating.  I'm dropping it from 8 to 7 because it just lost all fun for me.  I ended up trading this game away and I don't regret it.

RATING: 9

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
solo variant
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
"Robinson Crusoe" is the kind of game that makes you stand up and cheer when you successfully finish a scenario. Winning feels like an accomplishment, and there are few games that make it feel for meaningful. I give the game huge respect for that, and I definitely want to feel that thrill again.

However, "Robinson Crusoe" is also a game that leaves me so emotionally drained at its end that I don't want to approach it again anytime soon. Bad things are happening all throughout its long, long runtime, and it does get wearying after a while. The game also suffers from "Alpha Gamer Syndrome. I tend to think of it as "miserable Pandemic," not because the games play similarly but because in "Robinson Crusoe" - just like in "Pandemic" - you're often going to end up in a situation where one player is calling the shots and everyone else is just doing what they're told.

I really hope to play this game again, hopefully with a strong-willed group who can determine for themselves what actions they want to take. For now, this games resides in my respect Hall of Fame, even if I don't truly love it.

Also own deluxe wooden token bundle
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good
Quick and will get a lot quicker (prediction)
The variety of the scenarios show how well the game mechanics link to the given theme without a heavy additional rules burden.
Despite the euro style game mechanics this should appeal to the thematic crowd.

Not so good
I do not think this game solves the alpha player issue at all 
Rules are not the greatest (scenario 1s winning conditions not clear - we played it wrong)

A potential solution to the alpha player issue is to take leaf from RPG games.  Rather than planning our turn and considering the characters as assets (my approach and too much like pandemic) the best way is to run your characters seperately and negotiate co-operation when needed (more like the Pathfinder card game).  Who is going to collect some food (asking the other players) rather than just treating a character as two actions.

Having played the game solo I thing that the temptation is to treat the characters as assets, not a good idea (multi player), since it damages atmosphere and disempowers other players.  Play it like more like a thematic game rather than a euro despite the worker placement mechanics and puzzle like nature.

By being the person that knows the rules you can end solo playing the game and having the new players watch.  Next time I will have to keep reminding myself to role play the game and let the rules and win take care of themselves.

For me the weak link in this game is thematic rather than game play.  If a loved the theme more this would be a straight forward 10, it is the best co-operative game I own in game play terms. The Pathfinder card game and Eldritch Horror games thematically appeal more and that for now matters more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Moja pierwsza gra kooperacyjna i jestem nią zachwycona po dziś dzień. Kupiłam ją z myślą gry na 2 osoby i świetnie się do tego sprawdza. Można wybrać 2 poziomy trudności, więc nawet jeśli przejdziemy wszystkie scenariusze na łatwym poziomie, to warto zagrać na tym trudniejszym. Scenariusze dają duże pole do popisu i powinny spełnić oczekiwania nawet najbardziej wymagających graczy. Gra świetna zarówno dla graczy średnio zaawansowanych, jak i nałogowych geeków. Jakość elementów pierwsza klasa. Instrukcja bardzo długa i toporna, polecam przeczytać 2 razy, ciężko w niej znaleźć interesujący nas wątek, bo przewija się on zapewne jeszcze na 10 innych stronach instrukcji. Dobrze rozegrać na początek rozgrywkę solo i najlepiej ściągnąć FAQ do gry sporządzone przez fanów (dostępne na BGG w języku polskim), które rozjaśnia wątpliwości w konkretnych sytuacjach i na konkretnych przykładach, nie zaszkodzi również video recenzja. Pomimo tych przeszkód technicznych, zdecydowanie warto. Gra jest ogromnie klimatyczna, przygotowanie niestety zajmuje chwilę, ale później nie wiadomo kiedy czas ucieka i pomimo, że jest to kooperacja naprawdę czujemy się jak rozbitkowie na bezludnej wyspie, kiedy co chwilę spadają na nas jakieś katastrofy (więcej w tej grze bata niż marchewki), ale może właśnie to sprawia, że chcemy rewanżu i dalszych rozgrywek. Gra łoi i gnoi na każdym kroku, każdy kto ją zna, ten wie, że żeby wygrać trzeba albo źle grać (80% przypadków), albo mieć niesamowite szczęście. Uważam, że to must have.

RATING: 9
Lots of moving parts and fiddly rules, so whilst you learn it, you are going to need to cross reference the FAQ and rule book regularly. The more I've played it, the more I like it. In some ways, I feel that the intro scenario misrepresents the game. You'll finish castaways limping across the finish line, hemorraghing health and resources. It feels like survival, not a win. Subsequent games might be harder to win, but they feel more focussed and directed, in a way that's more intelligible. This game makes no attempt to resolve alpha player issues, but the easiest way to do that is to not play with Alpha players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Heavier cooperative scenario based game with strong theme and atmosphere. Lots of game parts, lots of rules, but everything is so cleverly put together in one big immersive experience. This game could be very hard and challenging (depends on number of players - some scenarios are easy when playing solo using one character) and you will probably loose more often than not. But when you manage to beat the scenario, it will be very satisfactory. You will be struggling most of the time against odds, battling with bad weather, unlucky events and trying to avoid/lower the consequences of them, but also running out of time to finish the scenario goals. One bad event after another, you probably won't manage to survive, but hope is always there..

What I like:
- Theme is very well implemented. You really feel as you are survivor on the lost island. The tension is real and you are beaten from weather, wild animals, bad luck similarly as if you really were stuck on the wild. 
- There are number of scenarios available (plus additional created by fans) and each of them are different so you can choose whatever you want. Replayability is high there.
- Each decision is hard. You usually need to do more actions than you can at the moment, picking the priority ones can be challenging, but fun.

What I dislike:
- There are lot of rules to remember. This game takes long to master and it is pain to learn it from scratch. But once you got into it, it is so rewarding. Ideally you have somebody who can learn you how to play it (takes role of some kind of "gamemaster" to handle most of the rules). If unplayed for a long time, you probably should revisit some rules as they could be forgotten.
- The setup and tear down time is long. The game could be finished quite quickly (at least when playing solo with only one character), so preferably have several sessions in one game night. There are lot of components, tokens, cards and it takes some time to prepare everything.
- The game is very luck dependent - the events are picked randomly and they could be truly devastating for the moment or easy as a cake. They can be somehow mitigated but still sometimes you are victim of a several bad events and you cannot do anything about it. Also dice adds some random element as they could be devastating when rolling badly (mostly weather dice). This is great to the theme - sometimes everything seemed to be against you, you cannot control everything, but for true gamers who rely mostly on their skills this could be frustrating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Theme is strong and unique. Other than the fiddly rules, it could be a perfect story-driven game. Mostly a solitaire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I like this game. Its a cooperative game where you are stranded on an island. The game sets up goals that you have to achieve. All the while you have to survive against the elements. It has a heavy theme. I even play tropical island sounds on the stereo while playing. Its very challenging. I've played twice and haven't yet won/survived. Walker and I agreed that it makes for a very good gaming experience.

RATING: 3
This game is all about the story; I'd say it's more of a RPG with boardgame mechanisms. The game system presents a challenge, but it's not a particularly engaging one unless the players are interested in the flavour-text and the unfolding narrative of shipwrecked adventurers struggling to survive in an inhospitable wilderness. 

The 6 scenarios, and the massive variety of event and adventure cards, give the game huge replayability for those who are interested in the story. For those who are not, the game feels samey from the second play onwards.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Still learning how to play. But I've been watching videos to get a better handle on the game. And I must say that this game has me very excited! I think much of whether a game really incorporates thematic elements into the mechanics is subjective. And I must say that for me, this game really conveys the idea of survival on a deserted island. I absolutely love the theme and I think the game play actions and mechanics really mirror that theme quite well!

This score may go up once I play and get the rules down. And yes, there are a ton of little rules that need to be maintained. There are so many moving parts in this game and it seems overwhelming at first. But at least, unlike my COIN games, knowing what to do and when to do it seems a bit more intuitive, even though you might still suck at the game. 

I would say that once you learn the big picture on what to do and how to process it, the rules will mesh much better than a COIN game, which is incredibly complicated as to the big picture. 

I don't have that many games as I am just not drawn to many. But the ones that I have, have captivated my interest for the most part. And this one is no different.

RATING: 8
Lovely, thematic, and interestingly challenging. More randomness than I tend to prefer in my games, but for the action dice, at least, it probably evens out over the long haul. (The weather dice, tile draws, and some sorts of card draws seem more swingy.) Could plausibly suffer from "not enough decision-space for the # of players" once one knows the game well, but at my current level of skill there were such a large number of plausibly-good choices every turn that it was an interesting discussion. Want to play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75

Aunque los dados le dan ese odioso toque de azar, no es obligatorio usarlos, si te arriesgas es porque quieres y porque asumes el riesgo de fracaso.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
While I do see the cool stuff in this game (Artwork, resurfacing events, differentiating scenarios, cool adventure cards) the rest just beat this game down for me. The Rulebook was way too fiddely, I got frustrated how much I had to look through all the pages to find stuff I needed for my playthrough. The events and dice make this game way too random for me. I do understand that it simulates trying to survive on a hostile island, but I always felt like I was at the absolute mercy of the dice, which i hate. Also, I, as a colorblind person, had real troubles identifying some symbols and telling them apart.
I played it twice solo, I will probably never play it again. Maybe with a full cast of four players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Part of what makes this game great is the challenge.  A cooperative game that becomes a sure win becomes a sure bore...not going to happen here.  However, you do pick up on certain strategies after multiple plays that will always be needed to win any given scenario.

I really enjoy playing this game because I never feel like I'm just trying to gain points.  It's easy to turn the game into a story.  And there's always a sense of urgency and the threat of something bad coming your way.  It keeps you on your toes.  The theme is rich.  The majority of game mechanics are logical, rather than just mechanical.  For example, you may draw a card and be faced with a choice:  If you opt to eat from that goat carcass you found, be ready for some diarrhea later on, or choose not to eat from it and no worries, except that you might go hungry that day...

RATING: 9
Designer: Ignacy Trzewiczek (Imperial Settlers)
Publisher: Portal Games
Player count: 1-4 (best with 3)
Weight: Medium heavy
Mechanics: adventure / cooperative / worker placement
Setting/theme: Adventure / exploring / fighting
Play time: 90-180 minutes

Based on run through and two solo games. This game breathes theme and I am very excited about this game. The game is brutal and if the cards are against you, you're unlikely to win this one, but that makes perfect sense in such a brutal environment. Would love to play this more and to introduce this to other players, but the complexity and the length make it hard to get this to the table except solo.

Still, a definite keeper in my collection and if it would get more playtime likely to be in my top 10.

RATING: 7
I have played Castaways previously, and was expecting Robinson Crusoe to be a big upgrade.  I did not find this to be the case...at least after one play.
It seemed to me to have the same basic formula.  Either play the way you are supposed to, or suffer a beating the entire game.  In Castaways the name of the game is to keep pushing exploration.  Robinson Crusoe may have the advantage that each scenario may have a different winning method, but that waits to be seen.
One other thing i learned in playing Robinson Crusoe is that my personal preference is to play these coop survival games alone.  I feel that the that you have to restrict your choices to be able to win does not make for a fun group experience.  Maybe it's just me...but the feedback I for from my groups tells me I might be onto something.
So...I will probably keep both Castaways and Robinson Crusoe in my collection...but only for solo plays.

RATING: 9

RATING: 8.2
A great co-operative that provides a superb thematic experience, with the advantage that there are lots of different scenarious and difficulty levels to chose from, so it´s an adventure game but there are almost always new decisions and different surviving techinics to discover.
The game is also very weel conceived, as your options and decisions always have the right impact on the history sequence (they are consistent with each other).
The sad part of the game is that turns out quite heavy, with lots of events to pick and resolve, cards to flip at the right time, automatic mechanics that should not be forgotten, etc.
Because of all this, there is the tendency to appear some alpha player (which can even be a good thing) but, for short, it´s a really good game, although it would be nice if it was lighter.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played twice solo and twice two player (Castaway and Robinson Family scenarios), even though I've only logged a single play.

Robinson Crusoe (RC) isn't a bad game, but it's too frustrating and as a consequence, not as fun as it should be. It's such a brilliant idea for a theme, and unfortunately so much potential is wasted on a game that ends up way too random and punishing. For a game of this length and complexity, you should have much more control over your decisions. I realize that randomness was necessary for thematic reasons (being in the wild requires one to accept a loss of control of one's environment), but the gameplay suffers because of it.

The theme is great, but there are just too many things in the game that are unthematic. If the randomness weren't so frustrating, then perhaps I could ignore these unthematic characteristics. In other words, if the gameplay were so good, the theme would be irrelevant to me. One example is that you cannot choose a sustainable shelter or food production. For the most part, these things are only introduced if you are lucky (i.e. cellar). There is no way to begin the game trying to domesticate any animals or plant a garden. 

Another example is hunting. You don't hunt for a particular beast (unthematic), but rather draw randomly from creatures that require anywhere from 1 to 6 strength to defeat (without being wounded yourself). If I am hunting in a particular fashion, then I can limit the types of creatures I would encounter. Also, if it were thematic, then if I encountered an alligator, then I very well might avoid attacking and back away if I didn't have sufficient weaponry. You don't have that option in this game. 

Furthermore, the beasts all provide varying numbers of food. Without the ability to store food (or do anything with the excess) and without the foreknowledge of this food windfall, it mostly goes to waste. If it were thematic, then I would develop a way to store a lot of food [i]before[/i] killing a tiger, for example. 

I have to build up palisades in order to protect from wild animals? Again, this is clearly a fantasy made up by a designer who has no real knowledge of outdoor survival. Wild animals will rarely attack a human, and cases are very rare when it does happen (usu. due to being in between baby and mother or when cornered and threatened). 

Events are just plain ridiculous sometimes. The decision ones are too restrictive and often nonsensical. Other events are too punishing (i.e. not fun). There should be more items in the game to provide efficiency (such as providing extra action tokens). The "bed" item only benefits a player who rests during the day, and not during the night? makes no sense.

There are some good things about the game. I like the exploration mechanic and the ability to move camp. The icons in the game work well. The item cards are fun to use, as are the character abilities. Morale is a nice part of the game, as is the weather dice (although the amount of randomness should be reined in dramatically). 

It's great that there are multiple scenarios, and I have read through them. Unfortunately, the frustration I have with RC makes me not even interested in moving on to the other scenarios. The randomness of hunting and the events is played the same in all scenarios, which means I don't think I will like them any more than the first scenario. 

Such a brilliant concept wasted with flawed mechanics and excessive randomness.
The weather and animals encountered should have been more controlled based on the scenario. This would make the game more realistic and less swingy. 

Overall, I found the game too frustrating (yes, I got all the rules correct) and punishingly random. Instead of being fun to explore an island, develop various tools, and encounter neat events, it was a struggle just to keep from being injured making a shelter or suffering from freezing rain. Not fun at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
