RATING: N/A
It took a few turns to wrap my head around this one, and I'm still not entirely sure what just happened. There are a lot of things going on here. My first impression is generally positive, though. My main concern regards how dependent the outcome is on the distribution of tools and events. We managed a win by the skin of our teeth, but if we hadn't pulled a certain tool at setup, we wouldn't have come close to surviving. That is potentially worrisome for a game this long and involved.

This is a pure co-op  -- you don't really take turns; you all discuss what you're going to do as a team each round. And it's not for the faint of heart. But it's definitely interesting, and the varied scenarios suggest good replay value.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[2014-03-10 Rating: n.a. -> 7.5]
When I first read about Robinson Crusoe, I did ignore it because I thought it was overly thematic. Let me explain this: For me, the mechanics are the most important thing in a game. The easier they are, the better. If the theme somehow matches the mechanics, well fine. But I don't really need this to enjoy a game. If the mechanics are easy to grasp but enable some deep gameplay and the theme is completely pasted on, I don't care. I don't need any fiddly rules that enforce the theme of a game. 

After watching some video reviews of Robinson Crusoe, I was left with the feeling that it had a lot of extra rules that are only in there because they help with the theme. And in fact, there are a lot of rules in the game that you have to remember. But all in all it's not as bad as I thought at first. So I'm totally fine with the influence the theme had on the rules and I can stand the fiddlyness of the game's core system since it's quite a lot of fun to solve this optimization puzzle that is Robinson Crusoe. Because despite of the whole theme and all the event cards that introduce new restrictions and obstacles, good play in Robinson Crusoe is all about identifying and making the optimal move under the current conditions.

Another thing I've lately come to realize is that I do like cooperative games solely because of the challenge and the puzzle they present to me and not because of the team play. In fact, playing a cooperative games with people often diminishes my enjoyment of them. The reason for this is that I want to win the game despite of all the mistakes I do normally make. I'd like to see if my (maybe stupid) plan works and if can win although I do make the wrong decisions all the time. I don't want the group to decide that something won't work, I want to see it by myself and lose if made the wrong decisions. So most of my ratings for cooperative games are for the solo variant of these games. This is also true in Robinson Crusoe. In fact, I did only buy the game so that I can explore it by myself and my rating is for Robinson Crusoe with only one player. With more players, I would rate it a 6. Although Ignacy Trzewiczek tried to eliminate the alpha player syndrome it's still there. This time you don't have to deal with someone who can surely know the optimal move at any given time but you still have the problem that there are people who are able to convince other people more easily than others. This situation came up in all the games of Robinson Crusoe I played with a group. Someone was always sure they knew the correct sequence of actions and was able to talk the other people into trying their solution. Guess what, I wasn't this person. Perhaps I should really, really try out Space Alert which is collecting dust on my shelf for some years and which seems to address this problem better than Robinson Crusoe.

But enough of my general rant against theme and cooperative games. Despite of everything that spoke against Robinson Crusoe, I do think it's a fine and solid puzzle game that seems to have a lot of replayability not only because of all the different scenarios that are included within the base game. The core system is solid and apart from some inconsistencies and timing issues the rules are quite clear in the german Pegasus Spiele edition of Robinson Crusoe. I'm looking forward to my next visit of the cursed island.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fine co-op that offers a few tense moments.  It is oddly really brutal at times, though, which is a different sensation.  Instead of fighting an ever tighter squeezing anaconda, like you would in Ghost Stories or Pandemic or..., Robinson Crusoe gives you the false hope of "Here's some cake.  Here's a baseball bat to the nose.  Here's some more cake.  And what is this?  Cake?  Nope, a baseball bat to the nose again."  The end result is roughly the same either way - a difficult challenge to beat.  But the process along the way makes sure you can't really get a good read on how you're doing.  Also, the mechanisms for the gaining and losing health around the demoralizing points are nonsensical.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played once and it was a very enjoyable game session and I would play again, although the game is not without it's flaws.

I did have hopes, given some of the comments about the game that I have seen, that it would manage to be a little more than just a group problem solver, however that is exactly what it is. It does succeed in presenting some interesting puzzles to solve but also comes up short in some areas:-

- Hasn't in anyway solved the co-op alpha-player problem - in fact it's even more prone to it than most. 

- The flavour text and artwork do their best to bring the theme to life but it doesn't quite succeed for me. It never escaped from being an exercise in managing scarce resources.

- I never really felt engaged with my character, the differences between them don't really seem to have much play effect, partly because the special powers are virtually impossible to resource.

- Functionally, the game would play identically if played solitaire.

- I also have a couple of doubts about the longevity of the game - once you have found the right strategy for each scenario (i.e. solved the puzzle) then replaying a scenario just turns into an exercise of how lucky you are with the card draws. I think there is an intention to provide more scenarios so this may not be an issue.

RATING: 5
I was resisting to play it for a very long time. Then I was resisting to read the rulebook. In the end - after almost a year - I put it on the table. WHAT A GAME! To be honest - the best coop that I have played. Great thematic, theme, mechanic, custom dice, great scenarios, big variance in the base box... I am really, really amazed. I was seriously doubting that there is still a good coop game there - which is not about Cthulhu (as there are already too many games about Cthulhu and Zombies) - but Robinson has shown me that there is hope. 

EDIT: This game as every single coop - is great solo but bad in a group (at least for me). Rating going down to 7

RATING: 8.5
I do love a good co-op game and this one contains some great mechanics, you have a little bit of worker placement, you have a little luck of the dice, a bit of push your luck and of course a mission to be completed by all team members to prevent certain doom!

Components are nice and everything fits into the box beautifully, I don't have any of the expansions or promos yet but I fully intend to get them, 4 players is the perfect number I think for this one, but it does play 1 and 2 (with the assistance of a dog and Man Friday).  A variety of scenarios are available and more can be downloaded I believe, each with varying difficulty.  Well worth a look if you are a fan of survival games and co-ops.

Sadly, this one doesn't make as much of an appearance in my house as I would like it to, but I intend to remedy that as I believe my wife would love it!

RATING: 7
Tense cooperative game, which tends to create a atmosphere of desperation and increasing panic, which really matches the theme of being stranded on a mysterious island. The game is unforgiving and hard to beat. The fact, that it comes with a variety of scenarios keeps replay value up. The only minor problem I have with it is that there are no hidden objectives or any traitor mechanism, which makes it susceptible to alpha gamer problems and turns it more into a solitary-like puzzle. But what an intriguing puzzle!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
LOVE LOVE LOVE!!!
This is probably my favorite game ever! If I chose to rate my games this would get a perfect rating :)! I love the game and the theme (realistic survival). Yes, there is a learning curve for the game's rules but once you get into it, it makes logical sense (aka: what would I do/what would happen in real life?). I am looking forward to purchasing ALL of the expansions and add-ons that come out for this gem (especially Voyage of the Beagle and the new Lost City of Z!). This is the one game that I would deck-out "to the nines" with custom pieces, inserts, etc.

This game is brutal and unforgiving. I love it! Why should survival be easy? Why should we always be able to get off the island alive? You shouldn't! Suck it up! Also, some find that this game has too much randomness but the randomness seems realistic to me. For instance, you roll dice for weather because no one can predict the weather. Also, you can always avoid rolling dice by allocating the whole day to an action.

If you have any questions about this game give me a holler! 
PS- Ignacy, You are the best! Please continue to make scenarios and expansions for this great system! I CAN"T WAIT FOR THE MYSTERY TALES EXPANSION... IT LOOKS AWESOME!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a game that I resisted. I bought into and was burned by the hype surrounding Mage Knight. That turned out to be a game that I hated, I respected, but hated because it felt too mechanical. So when RC was getting a bunch of mentions and some people who I really trust as far as their game tastes go were talking it up, I caved. What a fantastic game. The core engine is simple and straight forward. I love that it is a co-op where you do work together because it isn't a puzzle to solve but an experience to go through together. That's what sets it apart. That and it feeling very narrative despite a higher degree of abstraction. Just a fantastic design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Such a brutal co-operative game! It's amazing how frequently, and how significantly, things will go wrong - and with thematic flair too. You'll hear a growl while exploring, or get stung by a mysterious insect while gathering, or do a poor job of making the shelter - with later, horrible consequences being directly tied to these events.

That said, this is probably the only good thing the game has got going for it. Behind it's massive difficulty, there's a fiddly and clunky game system obscured further by a poor attempt at a rule book. In most games, I tend to side on just playing it however feels best, disregarding whatever the rules might say.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a really neat co-op experience.  It does a good job of conveying the feel of wilderness survival, with limited time to do anything and the constant pressures of hunger, weather, and wild animals.  The thick event decks also provide a good worry about the unknown and what might be waiting for you around the next tile or turn.  You have to overcome these problems and try to stay ahead of the curve by building labor-saving tools.  The small tech-tree of inventions is nice, and I like the way the basic ones are all out at the start but there are special ones available that change from game to game.  This variety, plus that from the different classes, starting items, events, scenarios, etc. give the game a lot of replayability.  That, and the fact it's nut-crushingly difficult, so you'll likely need to play a few times to win.

I'm not sure it's entirely balanced with 4 players, since you effectively have no way to get more food the first turn, meaning the majority of players starve the first night.  This, plus the nerf to the camp arranging action, can make it hard to get ahead on the morale race.  The rules are a real chore, and things aren't always written where I expect them to be.  Some of the card and scenario rules aren't clear either.  The iconography can also be difficult, though there is a key on the back of the book.

Anyway, I've enjoyed all my games of this, even the ones we've lost.  Looking forward to playing it some more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Brutal coop game - loved the first adventure.

RATING: 8.5
This game is brutal! ...in a good way. Using action selection and variable player powers, you need to work together to survive on the island. Random events in the form of 4 different card decks keep play-throughs fresh and interesting. The base game comes with 7 different scenarios that all play completely different from each other, but I sometimes worry that once you figure out the basics of surviving, your actions could become monotonous.  The rule-book is terrible; I read through the whole thing multiple times before I understood what was going on. Just go online and watch a playthrough. It can be played solo, which is really nice.

Fiddly at times, rather complex, but an experience to try at least once.

RATING: 8.01
It would be 10/10 if not for imperfect and inelegant rule set with a lot of loop holes and unclear specifications. FAQ and player aids are required to grasp every concept and enjoy this game without debates about what happens when and why.

Otherwise, definitely the best coop game with awesome deserted island theme and with best replay value so far (even without a single expansion, although they are available and very welcome). Very ruthless but with adjustable difficulty level.
Unfortunately, only up to four players.

[b]Update:[/b] Alpha player syndrome affinity, long setup and awful rules made me lower the rating from 9 to 8.5.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating dropped from 8.5 to 8.4 due to the lack of interest.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Adventure cards which have immediate effect after which they are shuffled into the event deck making it possible to have additional (usually worse) effect if it gets drawn later during the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As is often the way with coops i quickly sour on them over time. This game is fairly unforgiving. Sometimes you need some vital fur and the hunt cards just don't produce it. That's thematic, fine, but given the long set up time and all the effort this game takes i'm not sure its worth it if often your decisions don't really matter. I often feel as though the main decision is what build order to go for, after that there's a bit of resource management but most of the game is determined by the card draws.

----------------
I don't normally go in for coops, but i quite enjoyed this. Gives you lots of options on your turn and has plenty of different mechanics and things going on (event decks, hunting, exploration, resource gathering etc). It also has some great custom dice. On one hand its very euro, collecting cubes to survive and win, but also has plenty of dice throwing and event cards to keep things interesting. I think it does a good job of representing challenges of survival and does well on a thematic level. I wonder whether it would play out for me quite quickly though.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is great for solo, but it is incredibly brutal, even with Friday and the Dog.  Having finally played it with someone else, we had a much easier time of it.  It's a great game along the lines of "lots of terrible things are going to happen to you", but if you are resilient enough and build a great resource machine, it's not as horrible as you might think.

What's exemplary about this title is the theme and the actual focus on co-operation.  A lot of co-op games involve a shared goal, but not shared anything else.  You win together or you lose together.  Here, I find that the co-op is greatly reinforced if you want to properly win your chosen scenario.  You must actively work together to ensure that the group survives each night while trying to build something efficient enough to reach your win condition, which often involves redirected much-needed resources to the scenario card instead of to your own pool.

Great fun when you're not really interested in bashing your friends' faces in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I was initially really excited about this game, and committed to playing it ten times this year for the 10x10 challenge.

The rulebook is horrible. For our first six or seven games, it felt like we spent more time on BGG looking up rules than we did actually playing the game. I kept hoping that it would get better, and then I'd see why everyone loved the game so much.

Eventually it did get better, and the games went by more quickly, but they still weren't satisfying. I'd say the outcome is probably 90% based on luck, which does not really make for an enjoyable gameplay experience.

I'd actually say my first play was my favourite, when the luck worked in an exciting way and let us stumble upon a patch of mushrooms just when we were about to starve to death. But that was back when I still thought our decisions really mattered. Once I realized we were just going through the motions with a randomly determined outcome, my interest declined considerably.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Pandemic super-sized. It's hard not to admire designer Ignacy Trzewiczek for the brilliance of this production. The theme works, it feels like an RPG, the storyline comes through, and the game play is both robust and varied. Genius? Perhaps, but the game loses a few points for needing a game manager to keep track of everything that is happening, which always lessens the experience for me. Plus, this game is brutally difficult, and may make Ghost Stories, its co-op kin, feel like a walk in the park.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Rules too fiddly and luck factor too high on a game so punishing. Alpha male issue is still highly present and a round feels like you accomplish little to nothing making the impending doom because of a bad role or bad timing of a card a game of high frustration and little reward.

RATING: 8
This game is a strange little gem. Blends in a lot of mechanics and it definitely feels super-Euro, but with the most well implemented theme I have seen. The way the game jumps back at you based on decisions you made earlier is stunning. It is a difficult game (to beat, not to play), but when you beat a scenario it feels very rewarding. One of my new favorites.

RATING: 9
What an amazing, tough, fun game. Win or lose, I always enjoy the experience. The story-driven aspect is fantastic, and the way the game is set up where you have to plan all of your actions at the beginning of a round really adds to the theme of the game. We feel like we are at the camp, starting the day, looking at what we have and what we need, at which point we have to determine who will do what but never know who will be successful, get hurt, fail, or have an adventure on the island. All the while, the weather changes, your party has successes and setbacks, your morale increases or plummets, and you fight to live on!

RATING: 7
This is a great game. Decently thematic, with vast variability between scenarios. Resource gathering is tedious and unintersting, but all other actions are quite exciting. Sometimes the onslaught of negative effects becomes oppressive, but luck mitigation is available. The lengthy setup and nuanced rules make me dread playing it at times, and like most cooperative games, this game is very prone to 'quarterbacking'. However, all said and done this is one of the best cooperative puzzles published to date.
[Pro Tip: 'The Robinson Family' scenario is the best. All other scenarios feel tacked on in comparison.]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
28/01/2017

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game unfolds like a Tarot Card reading.  There is a common experience unfolding on the table, a story which you are playing.  

The dynamic narrative that underlies each scenario provides ample opportunities for replay.  I've played three scenarios, of course scenario 1 being played most often at this point, and each time the scenarios varied enough that they were still engaging. 

The game engine is very open for interpretation, which I enjoy.  I find that most areas of uncertainty in the rules can be resolved by applying thematic common sense, the dog can't build a knife because a dog can't build a knife.  This common sense interpretation of the rules holds very well throughout the game.

Tony
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
RC seems like a game I might enjoy solitaire (and I know for a fact the game is popular in the BGG solitaire community) but felt bloated with 4 players. Unlike other thematic dice games (such as EH or AH) where you run around a map and collect stuff to fight the game, there is very little player agency here.

Without players being in a physical space on the board or collecting individual items, players lose the feeling of associating with their character and see through the veil. So why have more than one person decide what actions to take each turn? 

And those decisions are really minimal. For example, you often are deciding to take a chance at being down, say, 2 food or 1 wood. Which is worse and how to address? Or as to what to build when the decisions are railroaded for you (for ex: roof > pot > shovel). You don’t need four people to make these decisions.

Yes, I like the way the events foreshadow things to come later, and I give the game credit for hanging together thematically, but my interest faded quickly due to the nature of the decisions. You just don’t need that many people to decide things here. It should be billed as a solitaire game.

Also, the game commits the sin of imbalanced powers. It's OK to make players fight against overwhelming forces, but you have to give them some powerful stuff to counter it (again, see EH and AH). That’s the unwritten contract of the game – get more powerful as the game does and then it's fun to trade blow for blow with the game. 

As it was, we were so, so poor in currency (determination), that we didn't get to use our powers very much, and when we did, they felt minor relative to the forces working against us. I would house-rule the game to give players more income so they can actually use their powers and engage with the game as individual characters. [i]Hey, look what I can do![/i] Why give players individual powers but then deprive them of the chance to use them? 

The answer to that question for me is because I think this designer is the Dan Brown of the hobby.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Foamcore Insert and Sleeved

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I love, love, love:
- the many scenarios to play
- the decisions between risking what to do quickly and possibly not accomplishing it vs what to do slowly but guaranteeing it to be done
- the encouragement to explore for helpful materials or terrain
- the agony of whether to take a bonus now but risk an event later or pass up a well-needed bonus to avoid possible danger
- gaining determination when failing at a goal
- the good mix of luck vs planning
- the really difficult challenge and unlikelihood of winning
- the new component quality
- the solid 4th edition rulebook

I dislike:
- that certain terrain allows for building certain things--how does this make sense?
- the success marking on the dice--did you know that's supposed to be a check mark?
- that no matter what beast you face, you always win albeit possibly with wounds

Final verdict: Fantastic game that's difficult to win and really brings its theme to life. Lots of replayability, great components, and well thought out use of luck only where it makes sense.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
I will readily admit that Co-operative games have a hard time with me in terms of seeing their purpose and rationale for play.  
Played once - 4 player.  Reason for the low rating is two  fold:
a) I didn't see that there was really much choice in the game.  Lots of luck when certain chits or cards were drawn yes, but meaningful player choice ? Seemed like the player choice is either extremely obvious or the choices of previous players determine what you do. 
b) Rewards - e.g. the tokens drawn from the bag didn't appear scalable yet the demands (food / shelter / palisade / weapons) were.   Experienced player's comment was "2 player, we've won several times, but 4 player seems impossible".  Didn't come across as balanced on the scalable options: = poor design/playtesting.  Also, seemed like the order in which the chits come out of the bag has a major impact on play.  

I will be very interested to see where this is in a year's time once "cult of the new" has worn off (It's position as I write this - Feb 2014 - at 13 seems overrated).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[u]The Good[/u]: 1) The game has an engrossing theme, the rules reinforce this theme at every opportunity, and the components bring it all together - just a near perfect game, thematically speaking. 2) The replayability here is off the charts. The game comes with mountains of cards, and yet each play will only see a small fraction of them.

[u]The Bad[/u]: 1) The iconography was hard to grasp at first (in its entirety), which led to a moderate learning curve. 2) Maybe a game based more around luck than player skill. Think of it rather as a simulator of deserted island scenarios, than a matching of wits between player and game.

[u]The Bottomline[/u]: If you find the setting enjoyable at all -the whole: being lost at sea only to end up washed ashore on a deserted island, and having to find a way to survive- then this could be a great game for you.

RATING: 10
One of the top sandbox games out there.  This is a flexible system.  Scenarios take the game in so many different directions.  Varied characters.  Varied set up.  Varied cards.  Variety within variety.  Has a real RPG and storytelling feel to it.  But at it's core it is a euro action selection mechanic that asks you "Do you feel lucky?"  A fantastic game.  Second edition rule book makes it easy to learn, but you better set aside some time to learn it.  I have only played it solo and do not desire to play it as a co-op.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game. Enough luck to make it interesting and unpredictable. It's got a serious flaw though:

Adventure cards and mystery cards. These are mostly bad. Optimal play (from my experience, played 4 times won three different scenarios) requires avoiding these if possible.

The adventures that allow you to gain something short term but lose something later on are almost never worth it, and the bonuses from mysteries are way to random and specific to be worth chasing. The result is that the game presents you with a lot of tempting options which you all turn down because the expected value is too small. While this might be very thematic (the last thing you want when stranded on a cursed island is even more adventure), it's also not much of a thrilling ride.

The solution could be to have a bit higher expected value, or be able to control the payoffs a bit better. (I don't want to risk wounds for a treasure that might be the barrel I desperately need, but might also be some warm clothes that I don't need at all). 

Still, the game is good. Recommended. But get Pandemic and Space Alert first.

RATING: 6
Rating history: 10|10|8|8|10|10...

[b]Narrative co-ops. I'm becoming a big fan of this sub-genre.[/b] My first exposure came with Knizia's co-op Lord of the Rings board game in 2002 (which I'm still playing by the way). Now this game - though almost ridiculously complicated to learn - also does such a wonderful job of creating story among players. I am curious to see how this plays over 20 plays or so, but the different scenarios provided with the game seem promising. Even playing the same scenario several times results is quite different challenges.

As much as I enjoy tight Euro-style co=ops (Pandemic, I'm looking at you), these narrative co-ops are amazing.

A Christmas present from my mother, 2013!

Jan 04/14 - #1 - L xxxxx, Jeremy, D, Des, Shaun
Jan 06/14 - #2 - W 24pts, Jeremy
Sep 04/14 - #1 - L 4th week - Dewald, Britt, Jeremy (RIP)
Jul 22/15 - #1 - L 7th week. Solo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pros
-Enjoyable push your luck melded with worker placement
-Frequent game choices that force players to decide and weight in on short term gain versus long term loss. When you lose, you often can point to some reasons as to why beyond a single bad roll
-Numerous game scenarios (many difficult ones!)
-Lots of team work involved
-Events are frequent, thematic and fun (despite then mostly being bad, I still enjoyed drawing them and reading them)
-Well labeled and detailed game board
-Scalable from 1 to 4 players.

Cons
-Alpha gamer may still be an issue, but rarely is there one obvious path to victory
-Semi-difficult game can be a turnoff for some players
-Moderate to long game length can be a turnoff for some players
-Not that many options for resources on tiles seems odd (always only food, food/wood or wood) - always want to sit camp on food/wood.
-Only four playable characters.
-Some confusing rules
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is fantastic!  As a lover of all things Survival, this is a fantastic add-on.  I do know that the instructions could be clearer, both on the overall level and the episodic stage, but the game has quality play, fair replay, and some freedom for expansion at a fan level.  Perhaps most importantly, this feels truly unique.  I don't mind similarities within the standard genres of deck-building, worker-placement, et cetera (these are just examples; this is not a deck-builder), but it is nice to see a game that seems to break out on its own as a true novelty.

RATING: 6.5
Fúúú, nagyon nehéz ezt a játékot értékelnem, mert legalább három vetülete van, amik mind nagyon eltérő értékelést kívánnak. Talán vegyük külön őket:
1. Szabály 
Rettenet, borzalom. Továbbra sem értem, hogy hogy működhet így egy ekkora kiadó, mint a portal games, hogy képtelen szabályt írni. Már eleve a leírással is nagy bajok vannak, de szintén bajok vannak az ikonozásokkal, azonnal elérhető infókkal, amik minden esetben hiányosak. ráadásul úgy, hogy nem is sejted, hogy valaminek utána kéne még nézni. Ezen felül már eleve a szabályalkotásnál is iszonyatos bajok vannak, mert az egyszerűsítésről, streamline-osításról még életükben nem hallottak. Felfogatatlan dolgok vannak itt is, pedig ez a 3-4. kiadás már. Hatalmas nagy kár, hogy alapvetően szuper ötleteket fecsérelnek így el... :(
Értékelés: 2

2. A játékmenet:
Na ez már sokkal jobb. Jópofa közös túlélés, érdekes ötlet a közösen dolgozás az akciófázisban. Viszont ezzel van egy kicsi bajom is. Mert így ez egy szoliter játék lett, amit többen is játszhatnak. Az, hogy nemhogy titkos infód nincs, de még csak saját köröd se, amiben lekussoltathatnád a többieket, és magad dönthetnél, a legdurvább alfajátékos problémát generálja, amit valaha láttam. Ha pandemic-kel valakinek alfás baja volt, akkor erre rá se nézzen.
Értékelés: 7

3. A történet:
Na ez az, ami fantasztikus ebben a játékban. Nagyon szórakoztató ki sztorik kerekednek, ami egy nagy történetté is jól állnak össze. Ráadásul a rengeteg random tényező érezhetően mindig egészen más mesét generál nekünk. Egyértelműen ez az a pont, amiben ez a játék szuper erős. Igazából annyira szélsőségesen erre van kihegyezve, hogy kicsit olyan érzésem volt, hogy ez nem is társasjáték, hanem egy nagy közös mesegenerátor. És annak nézve szuper.
Értékelés: 9,5

Szóval összességében nehezen tudom társasjátékként értékelni. Így kerekedett a fenti szám.

RATING: 8
Wildly unpredictable, fiddly and chaotic but it delivers a great story.

RATING: 6
I don't think Robinson is actually that different from most other coops. The major selling point might be the variability of a large number of random factors combined with the use of scenarios which significantly alter the winning conditions and how the game plays out. This variability, however, comes for a price: There is significant upkeep work to be done, lots of small parts add to the fiddliness, and the game can feel a bit procedural at times and run quite long.

RATING: 7
Rating after 1/5/10/25 plays: 9/(8)/-/-

A surprise hit! Each game tells a wonderful story, each turn can be agonizing with the number of choices and the limited actions, the random events out layer upon layer to the story, introducing complications and the occasional boon. 
The game felt similar to Arkham Horror, without the outré elements of course.

The first time around, reading the rules can leave you scratching your head, but as one becomes familiar with the design, the mechanisms click into place.

RATING: 8.5
One of my favorite games in group or solo. The subtle interlocking mechanics really convey the impression of being stranded on an island with meager resources. The game can be punishing but making a few good key decisions significantly improve your chances. The scenarios are interesting and varied. The beautiful components complete this wonderful product. The rules are elegant and the game flows well. Unforgiving as it is, Robinson Crusoe will test the patience and possibly discourage some players. But for those who like a challenge and a very unique experience, it's a must buy!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RC is one of the more thematic co-ops I've played. This is on level with Merchants & Marauders in terms of thematic density. The mechanics have been designed to help the story along without getting in the way. Even though there are a number of moving parts, it is a fairly straight-forward game. That being said, the first scenario lacks some of the tension that higher scenarios would have as I'm sure this scenario was designed to be more of a learning game than one where players are actually threatened thoroughly with impending death. I'm going to read the rules again to see if we missed anything, but we played with someone who had already played 5 times before, so I'm pretty sure everything was covered. That being said, I enjoy how the theme of discovery, tool building, and fighting "beasts" come together. The different dice for the different actions is a real nice touch. The way the tool development works on a tech tree fits in with the theme well. I'd definitely play this again and probably would see my rating go up with a harder scenario.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Robinson Crusoe does a more than adequate job at creating a narrative driven cooperative game. It's central mechanism is communal worker placement where people can opt to attempt to achieve actions individually or in partnership (the latter guaranteeing success).  This joint effort mechanic ties in well to the thematic drive of the game as well as providing some interesting choices in how to best solve the puzzle at hand.  

However, for everything good about Robinson Crusoe, it lends itself, more so than other co-op games, to a dominant voice.  Being that all information is open (in reference to each round) the player who is either most apt at reading the scenario, or is just more aggressive will control play -killing the intended experience.  

Robinson Crusoe is a strong cooperative game with strong narrative yet for me it doesn't sit alongside the tension filled LOTR or game play bliss that is Defenders of the Realm as a top tier game.  


UPDATE:  Robinson Crusoe can feel overly random at times and even create situations where the game is knowingly lost rounds before the scenario ends.  Familiarity also tends to chip away at the narrative creating a feeling of mechanics over story.  Still good, just not great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is one of those magical designs where each rule element is evident as an abstraction but inextricably tied to a thematic element or event. You can't really appreciate one without the other. This goes so far as to mesh the meta-game with the narrative itself, where the planning and coordination of actions is very much in line with a "Survivor" style deliberation that would be happening daily amongst a shipwrecked crew. My wife feels like the game is too "RPGish" for her, which is interesting considering how structured the rules are... but it does feel like an RPG in its own unique way.  Fascinating game.

Expansions owned:

[b][thing=144722][/thing][/b]

RATING: N/A
9 - $54.40
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game components and art design of this game are outstanding. The game is meaty and has a lot to offer. The theme is very strong too, it really feels like we are stranded on an island. The game mechanics of event cards possibly coming back to hit you later in the game is very elegant and I wish other games were using this mechanic more. It would have been great to have the same back of cards for all events though. As it stands the next event can get quite predictable just recognising it from the back of the card. The core game is also almost like a game system (makes me think of Time Stories from that point of view), as each scenario manages to feel very different from the others, and options for future scenarios seem endless.
I also like the fact each failed roll still gives you determination tokens, which will help future actions, so rolls are not just 'pass or try again later'.
On the downside, I would have liked to feel a bit more empathy for the characters. At the moment it feels like moving two nameless wooden disks on an island. Look at what Dead of Winter is doing for instance. Also, the game can feel hard and unforgiving. It is efficiency and risk management at its best but I don't like that one single failed roll or disappointing exploration often means defeat. The game feels organic as you are managing the decline of your character and try to achieve the objective before she/he dies, which to me feels a bit like being Di Caprio in The Revenant at times: a sensorial experience. You are feeling the starvation, the wounds getting infected, the fear, etc.
Finally, the game can suffer from quarterbacking. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Fun and challenging co-op in the first play w 2 ppl and Friday; great theme and seems to have plenty to do for each player. Won 1st scenario despite some missteps but could have just gotten lucky draws. Long set up and first time play but we were playing very fast towards the end. Want to play again soon. Manual could be better but we got through the game with only a rules mistake (thought you could only do 1 threat action each turn instead of both).

++++

Lots of plays later and we are all still enjoying the game (with a regular group of 4 players).  We've made it through the 4th scenario and are looking forward to challenging Cannibal Island (gulp/drool).

++++

Played through the last two scenarios - actually beat Cannibal Island first try (though I suspect we were VERY lucky and it was certainly a close call).  The Robinson Family scenario took us three attempts (one we lost from bad play, another bad luck - somehow managed to draw most of the book events at the start and got every 'discard invention' and 'flip finished invention' card in the game).  Still, very fun co-op game that we enjoyed immensely.  Sign us up for the expansion.

RATING: 10

I greatly look forward to expansions, and I think I'll continue to be hooked on this game for a long time to come.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First Impression: Initial thoughts are that this is a nice, tight coop game with a good but not amazing narrative.  So it's not going to retire Arkham Horror in that respect.  The twist is that it is filled with agonizing decisions that also feel thematic.  Game is still quite vulnerable to alpha dog syndrome, but so is any complete information coop.

Update: I've had a strange relationship with this game.  I played a large number of times when I got it, I quite enjoyed it.  Then it dropped off the radar for almost a year while sitting on my shelf.  The next summer, however, I came back to it hard.  It is a gem.  Serious staying power, I can't believe I dropped it for so long.  It has huge replayability even with a single scenario.  Games are tight and challenging.  This game breaks out of the cult of the new and has become a go-to coop game---unlike most coops, there's a lot of "game" there, not just narrative, without being incredibly dry and unthematic.  

Update: A major achievement.  I've written more about it on Fortress Ameritrash, particularly its near perfect realization of consequences while respecting choice in gameplay.  It didn't start there, but it is now one of my 10s.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Preliminary rating.
This game is rather fascinating. It shines thematically, even though you're basically just 'building' a survival engine. It gives me a similar feeling to Agricola, in that your options are quite limited and just about everything in the game wants to damage you or destroy your supplies. (Which, as bad as it sounds, is a good thing in a game because it makes your decisions more important!)

It really is like Friday, but on steroids, with TONS more depth and replayability.

The game is super fiddly, a lot to remember, the rulebook and iconography are extraordinarily confusing at first, horrible layout, but once it 'clicks' you can run through a few turns fairly easily. I keep thinking that theres probably a better graphic design for whats presented, or a better way to explain whats what on the board (like just writing the word of what that action does instead of a symbol.)

Update: Lowered my initial rating. The last play of this seemed very uneventful. I didn't feel the tension, or the theming so much as an optimization of resource gathering. I still want to explore this more, perhaps we were just too 'lucky.' It's still fiddly though, that remains unchanged. ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is no desert island stroll. It's survival. Weather is brutal, food is scarce, beasts are fierce. In spite of terrible odds, building tools or just getting a roof over your head feel is rewarding in itself regardless of win or loss. It's almost funny just how merciless this game is, but it's a rich, involved challenge that leaves me wanting another try.

RATING: 10
The biggest adventure of my life! Overwhelming!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
You can read the positive points anywhere, so I'll only list my gripes with the game.  I'm still rating it highly.

- Lots of bookkeeping, and fairly complex.  There's also a lot of symbols, which are not always clear on your first playthrough.  In a group of mixed experience, this means that inexperienced players will often just go along with the ride.
- It's basicly a solo game, all resources and items are kept in the "party pool", so players don't have any stuff of their own (except for "determination tokens").  There are also no player turns, you take your turns simultaniously as a group. The result of this is that you always must play "as a group", and decide everything as a group.  I realize this is a coöperative game, but I still like "playing my character" and making choices on behalf of my character.  This "it is advisable that everyone gets permission from everyone else before doing anything" style of play isn't really my cup of tea.

- The above two points, coupled with the fact that this game hase zero hidden player information, and is relatively hard, make it extremely vulnerable to the "alpha player syndrome".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
While I'm usually not big on strategy games, this one fits the bill for me perfectly.  I like resource management, I like worker placement, but I hate the tendency of most Euro-style games to be competitive (since, yeah, I tend to suck at them) and the fact that very little of the theme or story has any bearing on what I'm doing.  This game is highly thematic, in that the choices you make always have a feeling of story progression, whether it be building up your habitation to protect from the weather or building inventions to unlock other inventions you will need in the future.  I also love the healthy element of chaos and randomness present in the card-drawing and dice-rolling, because adapting your strategy on the fly has fast become one of my favorite aspects of games.  If you want a game with Euro flavor but enjoy a setting where you can't always control everything, this one comes highly recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
1-4 giocatori
60-120 minuti
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
First attempt and my brain exploded at confusing rulebook.  There's gotta be a better way to explain this game.  Seriously, somebody please find a way.  I had to rewatch gameplay videos to understand the game flow and know what my options were at each phase, and all the tiny rules.  Did a lot wrong on my first solo attempt.  Lost.  Kept trying to reroll weather dice to see if it was just dice hating me, but nope.  The game pretty much beat the snot out of me for 5 months in a row.

2nd Attempt, after watching the gameplay videos, much better.  I did a lot wrong on my first play.  This time I succeeded by October pretty comfortably.  The story really shined this time around...probably because I wasn't reeling so much from being beaten incessantly over the head with unfortunate events and had a little time to enjoy the journey.

The experience of this 2nd attempt is enough to make this game a keeper.  Can't wait to try other scenarios.

UPDATE: I've played Castaways and Cursed Island a few times now, 1p and 2p.  I'm STILL finding new ways that I've been playing this game incorrectly.  I appreciate that a game system in which alternate scenarios can be applied, that dynamically change the game's story is a major achievement in game design, but it's just a lot to keep track of with these finicky rules.  Overall, though, I think it's a winner and I'm willing to put up with the fussy rules and needing to read FAQs and quick start guides looking for clues about how to interpret certain situations.

UPDATE: Up to this point we had been hunting completely wrong.  It took 7 plays for us to finally play the game 100% correctly.  We beat the Cursed Island scenario 2p and on our 8th play, 3p, we beat the Castaways scenario.  The game is running smoothly now, and by that I mean I run the machine of the game and encourage everyone to do their best to stay tied into the story being told.  There's a lot of moving parts, and at times it feels like I'm the only one who knows how to keep the game together, but overall it tells a really compelling narrative and even my teenage nieces had fun with it on their first play.  After we won I explained all the other scenarios we can act out and their interest spiked even more.  I think I need to explain this game as if we're acting out a story.  People who approach it thinking we're playing a "game" might have the wrong idea.  It's hard work trying to survive on a cursed island.  

UPDATE: my wife and I have been playing.  We're stuck on Saving Jenny.   Poor Jenny.  Poor, poor Jenny.

UPDATE: played my first 4p games... died twice.  So much harder with more people.  Tried it twice and failed.  Came home and tried it by myself playing as 4p + dog + Friday and I completed the Castaways Scenario at the beginning of Round 11.  The roof is your friend.

UPDATE: played 4p again and lost miserably. SO much harder.  Agh!

UPDATE: 3p is perfect.

Wrote a review about it: [b][url=https://yourturndad.com/2018/01/30/robinson-crusoe-adventure-on-the-cursed-island-a-review/]https://yourturndad.com/2018/01/30/robinson-crusoe-adventure-on-the-cursed-island-a-review/[/url][/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Difficulty to win rating in parentheses.  

Scenario 1: Castaways [9/10] - We lost...but it was close.
Scenario 2: Cursed Island [8/10] - We won...with 1 round to spare! (Although our health...)
Scenario 3: Jenny Needs Help [8.5/10] - We won on the final round, with several resources to spare.
Scenario 4: Volcano Island [8/10] - We won...with 1 round to spare! (Although our health...)
Scenario 5: Cannibal Island [8.75/10] - We won...on the last possible turn of the last possible round...but ONLY because we broke the spyglass for 5 free determination tokens.
Scenario 6: Swiss Family Robinson [7/10] - We won with 2 rounds to spare and 4 or 5 health apiece. Perhaps we had unusually good luck, but this one seemed a lot easier than the previous.  It also felt less thematic.  
Scenario 7: King Kong Island [8/10] - We lost! We completed the main task (finally) of setting 3 traps for Kong, but we ran out of time before we could tranquilize him.

RATING: 5
This game suffers from the same issues many cooperative game have: no interesting decisions to take. It's thematic yes. But actually you try to get some cubes and you roll some dice for it. Repeat. As each character has some advantage in its domain it's obvious that the soldier will hunt, that the worker tries to get tools and the explorer explores the island (of course you can do different however). It felt way too scripted. The game captures the story well but mechanically the game is boring to me as it drags a bit (but this could be due the fact it was a first time game).

RATING: 4
Games are funny. Based upon a grokking of the rules, a love of the components and theme, etc, etc., it seems you should love a game. Then, every time you play it, with one or two or three or four people, everyone in your game group says, without variation, "why have I just spent two hours and a lot of coordinated effort pretending to starve?" Yet you keep the game, hoping that initial promise will pay off. 

UPDATE: Last line should read, "So you sell the game to someone who will hopefully enjoy it and weeks later barely notice it's gone."

RATING: 8
TTS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We have played 14 times and have completed all 6 scenarios included with the base game. My biggest gripe is that the scenarios seem to vary wildly in difficulty. It is strange that we found the last 2 or 3 very easy, while the second and third were the hardest. The first scenario was fairly easy as intended. We used the exact same setup for each one in number of characters, event card mix, etc. I think the game should have scaled to make the later scenarios much harder. We shouldn't have been able to beat scenarios 4,5, and 6 on our first try. We didn't scale the difficulty up because we found 2 and 3 fairly difficult. 

We are going to play through the scenarios again with a greater difficulty. I will increase my rating if it scales up well, and we see some replay value in the scenarios. Each scenario seems to have a certain trick in how you have to play it to win. I am not sure the random event cards add enough variability to make the scenarios very repayable. Perhaps it would be nice if there were more than 3 characters available for 2 player games. 

Even with its potential flaws, I rate this game high because it has no problem hitting the table. I am always excited to play it as is my primary playing partner. As an added bonus I can solo anytime I want. Each turn there are always interesting decisions to make, and the best route is not always clear. The theme, components, mechanic - it is all great. If I can get the difficulty to scale and good replay ability it will be a perfect 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It seems pretty obvious that Robinson Crusoe is a game that revels in its top-down design. That is, the mechanics are an outgrowth of the theme, and not the other way around. And yet the co-op aspect and worker placement all make this game feel comfortably familiar. It's a good balance.

Players will need to split up the tasks of managing their camp, collecting items, preparing for natural disasters, etc. Some have complained that this can lead to one player trying to boss all the other players around, which could see happening, but that's an issue with the players, not the game itself. It wasn't a problem in my experience.

Co-op players who love games like Pandemic may find that Robinson Crusoe simply offers too much. Every action is handled a bit differently and every item performs a different function. These are easy to remember because the mnemonic of the theme is so prevalent, but it there is still a lot of rules overhead. For me, I found that to be a necessary evil to deliver the narrative experience of your titular adventure on the cursed island, but it is unlikely to evoke adjectives like "crisp", "clean", or "elegant". 

Is it too hard to win? Too easy? To ask these questions is to miss the point of the game. Not that your play will not improve as you learn the game, but if you aren't enjoying the story-driven experience of this learning process, it may not be the game for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not likely to play again. This is a zombie game with a different theme. Co-op trying to fend off death. Not my cup of tea.

Not something I'd play all the time, but as far as coops go, I'm cool with it.

RATING: 7
I had this on my wishlist for half an eternety until I finally got it. It's a great game, and does coop really well I think (though I've only played it solo to date).

The rulebook could be a lot better. Reading it, at times, makes it feel like the game must be really complicated to play - things are laid out a bit confusingly, to me, at times. Actually playing the game is a lot smoother though (barring the occasional rules uncertainty, where BGG comes in really handy).

The game is tough, but beatable - feels fair overall, though randomness of course can foil the best-built plans. As it should in a game like this: It introduces a feeling of adventure and excitement, and occasionally dread, and models the unpredictability of lonely life on a desert island.

RATING: 7
Pretty good co-op game of survival on a desert isle. A lot of different tasks have to be accomplished, so players can work on different objectives and all be contributing to the whole. Dice roles can mess with your plans though, sometimes causing you to fail your task, or activating further misfortune in the form of various event decks. So, there's a lot of luck, but trying to overcome it is kind of fun. Really great presentation.

(1 play)

RATING: 8
A game that thrives off intensity! Every round, you can feel the pressure build up! It makes you really stress out over every single decision, as you know deep deep down, failure is inevitable. The different scenarios really breathe life into it as well; each scenario forces a different play style and way of thinking in order to be successful ! If you're looking for a co-op for people who like to sit down and challenge themselves mentally, and are okay with dying in really saddening ways, Robinson Cruscoe is the game for you! (I swear to you that I actually like it...)

RATING: 9
First of all this game is one of the most thematic games i have ever played. The rules are complicated however the gameplay is elegant. Most of the actions are coming from the theme and can be understood easily. The game tell you a story. You and your few friends are on the dangerous cursed island trying to survive. The game is about endless torment about not to die. The scenarios are quite different from each other so lot of replay ability granted with the base game. Be prepared to actually win a game is quite a heavy task. One little mistake and you find yourself that half of your life has already gone. The artwork is outstanding and helps you a lot to imagine your adventure.

RATING: 10
One of those rare games that keeps me thinking about it long after the game play ends.  It took me one session dismiss this game, but 5 months later I eventually picked it up and again and the second session solidified it as one of the best games I've ever played.  Don't be mistaken, you'll lose far more than you'll win, but that makes the wins so much more enjoyable.  You'd be doing yourself a disservice not having this game in your collection.  If you don't get it the first go-around, give it another try.  You'll be glad you did.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I love survival games. Being stranded without supplies, finding some and trying to stitch together a plan with what you've found. Robinson Crusoe does an excellent job at this, presenting you with some options and letting you grow out your own adventure from them. Speaking of adventure - the card system is really cool. I love how the game's foreshadowing system works and how events can bite you later.

Underlying all of this however is a stunningly designed game. The worker placement works very well and I always feel like I have a ton of options on my turn. The scenario system also helps to form your general strategy. And the game is tough as nails which keeps you challenged and coming back for more. The solo game gives you access to some extra workers and plays really smoothly. Really there's just nothing this game doesn't have - it's superb

Best with 1-3 and good with 1-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Quite possibly the most strategic and fun cooperative game in existence (not to mention hard). If you are a fan of cooperative resource management/exploration games this is for you, buy it without question.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When Friday got rabies I pretty much gave this an instant 8.

•

A master class in rules exceptions, except where those exceptions are excepted.  In that case, you'll have [i]no idea[/i] how the hell it works.  Ideally, a game should have exactly zero rules exceptions, and every failure of that ideal should be completely necessary (i.e., the game won't work without it, and there's no way to rewrite the rules around the issue) and, perhaps more importantly, every exception must be [i]utterly obvious and memorable[/i].  The rules here are an [i]if-then-BUT[/i] mess, making for an awful lot of pretty big buts.

You are most definitely gonna need these to help figure it out:

[b][thread=1033838]Castaways Quick Start Guide to Robinson Crusoe[/thread][/b]

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/83876/round-sequence-crib-sheet][b]Round sequence crib sheet[/b][/url]

Ultimately, the way to play this as intended is to not worry about playing this as intended and just kinda go for it—otherwise you will drown the fun-baby in a murky bath of rules, rules exceptions, botched rules, beetle-browed page-flipping and anxiety.  Squint, wave the the hand and play through.  You can always get closer to the thing next time.

[imageid=3085062 small]
[size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]Friday says to walk it off, Mr. Orange.[/i][/size]

Expansions & swag:

[thing=144722]Voyage of the Beagle[/thing]

[thing=170907]Treasure Island Junior[/thing]
[thing=162959]Tracing Doctor Livingstone[/thing]

[thing=179658]Discovery Tokens[/thing]
[thing=156413]Beach Cards[/thing]

[thing=156823]Sailor[/thing]
[thing=175182]Hunting Dog[/thing]

[thing=162604]Spyglass of Illusory Hope[/thing]

RATING: 6
A melting pot of trillions of cards, tokens, plastic and wooden cubes. The English is odd on more than a few occasions, the rules are disorganized, and setup and take-down times are outrageous. 

The game kinda works, but only if you can look through its shortfalls. They REALLY should have tried to simplify a lot of stuff to improve the game. I also wish that the characters felt more individual to each player. 

It is a bit too long, complex, and luck-driven to warrant an 8 with me and my gaming partners, but it works okay as a solitaire, if you don't mind the setup time.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wonderful present of my Secret Santa in 2013

This is THE most thematic cooperative game I know (which are at least SHADOWS OVER CAMELOT, SHERLOCK HOLMES, PANDEMIC, FORBIDDEN ISLAND, FORBIDDEN DESERT, GHOST STORIES, FLASH POINT, HANABI, LEGENDS OF ANDOR to name a few).  It only takes you one round to realize all the perils you are facing a castaway. Brutal but so rewarding gameplay. Looks complicated at first with seemingly endless rules. But it falls together very well and plays very naturally. Brilliant! Also love the great variety this game offers with 6 scenarios, always differing tools and events so that no game plays the same. One time you feel stranded on an icelandic island battling frost and snow. The next time its a tropical island with food in abundance but wild animals all around you.

Sure, there could be a problem with a dominant leader as in many other cooperative games. This has never been a problem in my groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
8.0 based on first play. We beat the first scenario handily, which makes me think we played the game wrong. Towards the end we did realize that we were making some minor--maybe a little more than minor errors. First, we didn't realize that invention cards go in the unavailable resources slot. (For those who don't know the game, the resources you acquire don't become available until the next round. This includes tools you build, apparently). We also didn't realize that helper pawns (which you get by building tools) must be played with real player pawns. I'm not sure if either of these made a huge difference (since we always could have just sent a solitary player pawn instead of a solitary helper pawn). We might have just gotten lucky, since 3 of our 4 randomized invention cards were helper pawn cards (in other words, extra workers). We also were incorrectly healing too much with the fire place (allows you to trade food for +2 heals, but ONLY 1 food. We were trading multiple). This probably made a huge difference, since my constant supply of determination tokens allowed me to kill beasts and retain an ample supply of food. 

Anyway, this is probably the most fiddly game I've ever played. I didn't really become immersed in the theme(like so many say you do) because I was struggling to remember what every little chit and token represented. I also found the rulebook downright infuriating. Every rule you need is in there and, if you can find it. But the rulebook is like a lesson in recursion. Some rules are in completely unintuitive sections, and very important rules are segregated in "example" boxes for no apparent reason. Further, these example boxes are often not even near the section requiring the example. If you play, I'd highly recommend using the community created resources in conjunction with the rulebook. 

Having said all of this, the game is beautiful and I can see that it has potential. Learning games are always rough if you don't have someone to guide you, so these comments should be taken with some grains of salt. I think this game can be everything that people claim it is, by about the 3rd play. But be prepared to be disappointed when your first play is bogged down in fiddly rules, tokens, and a poorly organized rulebook.

Edit: Everything that I was confused about also confused at least a few other people on BGG. So, this is a rulebook problem.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
很棒的角色扮演/合作遊戲，非常豐富的隨機事件/工具/寶物，很有特色的角色設定(可惜角色有點少)，每次玩都是不同的體驗，最厲害的我覺得是劇本每個都設計得很有故事性且玩法都很不一樣，且bgg上已經有許多玩家自製劇本可下載。
缺點嘛...這遊戲很吃骰運，爛骰太多是會滅團的，計畫總是敢不上變化啊...
作者Ignacy Trzewiczek曾寫過一篇文章："Are you designing game? You better have Vlaada Chvatil in your testing group!"，文中Vlaada很直接的打槍了當時還在play test的魯賓遜遊戲機制的不合理，被打槍後的Ignacy耿耿於懷的反應也很有趣，後來原本的機制被拿掉，加入了現在的士氣條，如果沒有Vlaada，這遊戲可能不會這麼棒。這篇文章也收錄到他的書中"Board games that tell stories"，有機會要收這本書來看。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Heavyweight, full co-op with a shipwreck/survival theme. It's kind of a fusion between ameritrash and euro gameplay, leaning more towards euro; some minor dice-rolling and uncertain card-draws, but decisions are mostly deterministic. There are multiple scenarios, and they all have some goal beyond just survival.

This is the perfect thing to play if you have a few hours and want a grueling full co-op experience.

Setup is an absolute beast. It's the only thing that has soured us on the game. Unfortunately, there isn't really an analogue for it. Maybe Dead of Winter in full co-op mode on a higher difficulty? That's all I could really think of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Kind of like a co-op version of Agricola, where you struggle to feed your "family" and keep them alive, while trying to get what you need to fulfill the scenario's requirements.  A great puzzly worker placement game that really feels like it's kicking your butt and that there is no hope... which is a good thing in this genre.

RATING: 4
Played this twice (enough to know I don't like it).  Embodies the concept that cooperative games must be action grinders where you get a very limited number of actions and you must waste the majority of these simply to survive (in effect you throw away these actions doing nothing to help you win).  Its amazingly frustrating because you can spend the entire game collecting food so that others can attempt to take actions to meet the requirement to escape the island (and that's called cooperative).

This is a gigantic miss.

RATING: 10
What a thematic game. It opened a new dimension for coops for me and my wife. Really, really love this game. It is challenging, there is no clear right and wrong. The luck factor fits the theme really well and can be reduced if you pay the cost. It is up to you how often you want to roll the dice, how dependant you want to be on card draw. That is fantastic. It plays well with all player counts. 

The most terrible thing about this game is the rule book. Even after really studying it hard, having a test play and so on we still made mistakes which were discovered after way too many pays when we met with friends who also own that game. They also made some mistakes, all different from ours. So expect to have a hard time at first.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.46
[b]Solitaire Review:[/b]

This is definitely the most immerse experience I have in my collection. Every game, it becomes less about solving the puzzle, and more about survival the weather and making sure I have the resources needed to live another day. I've truly started thinking of the yellow cubes as physical food I need to live, in this gem of an experience. 

As I've slowly whittled away at each scenario, I'm always left with a desire to go back to every challenge and try to outdo my previous score. I really have enjoyed the Solo experience of Robinson Crusoe as much, if not more, than playing in a team. Just like a good novel, I get totally lost in the story every time, with minimal distractions around me. 

The randomness is what drives the difficulty of the game, and at times can be infuriating. The card draws fit the story the game is telling flawlessly, just leaving enough for your imagination to fill in the blanks. However, some events, scenario situations and activity cards are so devastating when activated in tandum, that it sometimes seems excessive and hardly fair. 

Overall though, the game has it's claws in me and I can't wait for future expansions and to get to the the King King and Doctor Livingstone scenarios that have just  arrived from Portal publishing. 

[b]Pros:[/b]

- Impressively immerse
- An unbelievable amount of scenarios that utilize an already impressively repayable system. 
- With the help of the BGG phase order sheet, the game plays very smoothly and quickly for it's overall weight. 

[b]Cons:[/b]

- Lots of holes in the rules, so you often have to think thematically to move things along. If you think thematically however, the result is often very satisfying, be it good for you, or devastating.
- Apart from the randomness and rules, there is nothing bad I can say about the game.

[b]2015 Rating:[/b] 9.50 [b]Rank:[/b] 9 [b]Plays:[/b] 6
[b]2014 Rating:[/b] 9.35 [b]Rank:[/b] - [b]Plays:[/b] 15
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Great game!! I love it. The game is super thematic, everything you do is there, you can feel the game breathing theme. The basic survival mechanic is very well done, it makes all the sense in the world and it is fun. With only that mechanic and maybe just fighting for survival, the game would have been great but, in addition, there are several scenarios, uniquely designed, it is not just a standard paper with different information in every subchapter, no, every scenario has a unique configuration, every mission feels completely different, you can see perfectly that you are in a doomed island, or trying to film King Kong, or just surviving... and it is true! 
You also can create your own scenarios or try one of many that can be found on the internet.
Positive:
1. Highly thematic
2. The survival mechanics work very well
3. The scenarios are very different
4. Everything that happens makes total sense from theme perspective
5. The number of players can be very variable. A two-players game works very well
Negative:
1. It may be a bit difficult
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The game is real FUN.  That is once you get through (preferably - master) all the rules, details and possibilities.  It requires 1-2 plays.  But once you pass that point the game becomes a jewel: with complex decision-tree, non-obvious choices, thematic and demanding.

The theme is integrated into mechanics, cards etc. BEAUTIFULLY.

The pressure from the game is high - it punishes you severely.  Not something for the faint-hearted.

6 different scenarios are SPLENDID idea helping the replayability.

RATING: 10
Purchased with the proceeds from selling Defenders of the Last Stand game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Crisis management: Resource management hell: Story-driven: Push your luck: Full co-op: Dice

VERY strong themed game which includes a storyline, to me this was by far the best aspect of the game due to 'which' theme it is and how underused/original it is, and how well integrated it is, I think we mostly 'felt' we were on this Island and trying to survive which was cool. 

Gameplay was FUN actually, due to the nature of the events and the push your luck aspect, but also stressful at times as well. If you don't like the stress/challenge of ITYOTD or Gric, you might as well steer clear of this one, too. (two more reasons I DID like it)

I was worried about the dice, and how much the luck might effect things but after playing that worry is almost gone. Its a factor, and one that constantly needs to be accounted for but can be mitigated too at times, just not all the time. On the set of dice we seemed to use most there was a 66% chance of success, and our success rate was more like 75-80 so this helped, the other sets are tougher in general so beware and PLAN to get hosed more if you take the chance with those. Note that 'usually' a bad roll here or there is NOT too critical, and you mostly get to decide where to push your luck, however deciding not to (push your luck) costs you an extra action EACH time, and you really don't have actions to spare....There is card draw luck here too, probably not much different than any other similar game but when the two aspects are combined you can see that no matter how you cut it, its just a factor you have to accept going in and a trade-off for tension and realism.  

I really like the idea of having different scenarios here and see several benefits like adding to the theme/story-telling, reducing the feel of a static board (Map is also modular) and having different goals to help keep the game fresh and different each time you play a new one. After only one play its hard for me to comment on the tactical versus strategic nature, I think its slanted for sure but do think you have to stick to an overall plan based on your scenario and how you want to approach the game from what is available (tools, etc) and what becomes available, you are also forewarned of future bad events so I don't think its w/o planning and fully tactical at this point at all. 

Critique's would be rule clarity, again, but also not the easiest game to learn due to just shear amount, its a little more involved than your average co-op and also runs longer too, first scenario was a good 2 hours (note that gameplay is actually pretty straight-forward however and this was also 4 player and our first game though). In its defence here, I will say that any 'realistic' game I have ever played (that I can recall) was NOT light on rules, so here too for the theme to really shine I think its likely a necessary sacrifice and worth it. Significant set-up. Fiddly with bits moving all over the place, I don't take off much or anything for that, but you might. I don't see the dominant player issue solved here, but I knew that going in and now agree with others who said it but note decisions are WAY less obvious than in something like Pandemic so this does help. Its full co-op, and everyone needs to be [i]involved[/i] for sure using their special abilities and in negotiations/team work but a DP can still try to control everything if he chooses to (Maybe later scenarios address it more? Not likely)

Not sure what number might be best, maybe 3 might be a tad shorter than 4 but overall my best guess says this should scale very well 1 right to 4. Oh, technically it has a worker placement mechanic, and we're all tired of that but don't worry, I didn't even notice its the theme that stands out, NOT the mechanics.  

[u]Update[/u] - Did I mention the game was Brutal? This game won't be for everyone, crisis management is punishing and not everyone enjoys it for sure. Have played twice more and lost the 2nd scenario both times, really like the game its VERY well done imho but the rule look ups are taking a toll on us, FAQ helps but needs to be polished and completed to be fully useful.  Likely will settle at 8.5 rating for me once rules hopefully become smoother in play (card effects and such keep giving us hiccups) and I think it's the best 'serious' (non-party style) co-op to date

[u]Update[/u] 8.25 => 9  A bit of a bigger jump than I thought, just really enjoying the game and the rules are finally melting into the background letting the game shine.  The book is fairly good for the most part, the FAQ really needs completing and better formatting though.  

This is the type of adventure game I have been waiting a LONGGGGGGG time to play, it feels very complete in that it has everything you would want in an adventure, is challenging (damn hard at times) and highly immersive AND your decisions feel meaningful, the last part usually does NOT go together with adventure, sooooo many examples.  Mage Knight also does that last part right, but note I have only played that once so far and those rules were brutal too. Robinson has: Exploration, hunting, treasures, traps, monsters, building tools, slight tech tree, a different goal and other aspects to each scenario, lots of story telling events, characters with different variable powers (maybe character development only thing missing?), weather, building a camp with different aspects including the upkeep of these, constant need for food, constant resource struggle, never enough actions or time, and likely a couple more I am forgetting. 

Robinson is an excellent game and really well designed, and is especially enjoyable for anyone that enjoys crisis management. Luck plays a role and sometimes more than others, but after 6 games I only felt it really influenced the outcome once (that I can recall anyway) and as I noted before many times you can mitigate the luck by choosing NOT to push your luck, I think the luck could be a tiny bit high only or maybe even just right, its not bothering me at any rate (I should note I care about luck less in co-op's since I'm not competing against others). Playing really brings me onto the Island and escaping everyday life much more so than many games, and this is a big reason I game in the first place so top marks for immersion from me.  My Rating is likely to stay here, if luck was just a little lower and the game was just a little more strategic it might have hit a 10 for me, I do think its that good. Game should also have good legs I think too if not overplayed, since there are now SEVEN scenarios (and more coming) as of this writing and they all look damn tough to beat. 

[u]Update[/u] 9 => 9.5  A few more plays and the game is a masterpiece really, and really reminds me of Agricola in many ways, including having a bunch of tempting cards around potentially diverting your attention from your core goals.  Most likely going to be a 10 for me and will make it into my top 10 (now in my top 20), the theme is so strong and game tells a great story, its so immersive and really fun to explore (literally and figuratively), discover and play as long as you can take the beat down it dishes out, and combined with great strategic and tactical decisions you have to make, it’s just a great great game imho and so many great elements that come together beautifully. 

The last worry I have left now might be that we may be on to an optimal way to play, one that will more or less work for each scenario. It's only a very slight worry as of now, and only more play will tell me whether its just that and hopefully nothing else.  

Awesome job on this Ignacy, thank you for this GEM and the great adventures.  

------

[b]Jeepers, will Portal EVER do a better job with the RULES??? [/b]

Come on guys, this one is "better" but how many times do you need to hear the same complaints, ever single game has the number one same complaint of confusion in the rulebook. And a shame too, the games all seem to be pretty good and yet the rules have ruined SOOO many people's enjoyment.

RATING: 8
Fun coop, there's a sense of challenge but it feels fair. And finding the right balance between not having to roll dice and doing enough things is interesting, in fact probably a big part of the real decisions of the game. Though how to use your resources is also a serious question, and in that regard this game feels more proactive than a lot of other coops which in my experience usually feel more like continuously cleaning up after messes the game generates. In this game you start in the hole and you work your way out, the game trying as hard as it can to slow you down but rarely actually reversing your progress.
