RATING: 7
It's an okay coop.  I played it once or twice.  It's sort of a cross between a coop and an economic game as the group builds up its resources by gathering some raw materials and using them to put cards into play representing things like a wall or rope or whatever.  Meanwhile bad things are happening and you are exploring the island to find spots to get the resources you need.  I like economic games and there are real choices to make together and the theme comes across well.  I don't like it as much as some other coop games like Space Alert or Battlestar Galactica or even Pandemic as it didn't have the same sense of tension and impending doom.  I'd be willing to play it from time to time if the group really wanted to but I wouldn't suggest it on my own,

I won't add anything about Robinson Crusoe except to say I agree with the positive reviews.  This is a co-operative game with a huge amount of replay value (it's more of a game system in which scenarios are played rather than a single game).  Just be warned, it has a steep learning curve due to complexity.  It's not the most fiddly game out there, for sure, but it leans in that direction.  And be ready to fail; this is a tough game.

RATING: 7
2013-08-29

Initial Rating: N/A (August 2013)

At last we got to play this, however it wasn’t a good experience. A friend tried to explain the rules, but he didn’t have them clear so it was (kind of) a mess. Right now I can’t give the game a fair rating so I will wait until we play it again.

I read the rules yesterday and now I´m able to explain it.

For now, it seems the game has potential. It doesn’t fix the “dominant player” problem as I have heard, but it does transmit the theme fairly well (although I’m not a fan of this kind of theme). This is one of the few cooperative games that have excited me this year. 

The game art is ok, the icons on the cards are very small for my taste, and the quality of the cards is abysmal for such an expensive game, need to sleeve them ASAP. 

For now I expect to play this next week (before the rules leave my mind).

Current Rating: N/A
[hr]
2013-09-02

Initial Rating: 7.0

After another play, I’m beginning to like this game a lot. The rules are somewhat confusing in some parts, but the game is easy to teach and flows quickly. For now I´m giving it a preliminary 7.0 but I will play again this week.

The game can take a while to finish, however you are engaged the whole time so you don’t feel it. It seems the scenarios are hard to beat (I hope this is the case) but I’m not sure about this as I only played the first one. The art is great. Perhaps one of the most complex cooperative games I have played (I love this). It has many interesting options (unlike most CoOP games out there) and the event cards keep the game interesting. In particular I love the way the events now affect our future (poisoning, diarrhea etc.). I´m glad I liked the game as I was losing faith in the Cooperative genre.

It has luck in the form of events and dice, but (most of the time) you can mitigate it with clever play, so in general this doesn’t bothers me. 

For me, this is WAY better than Pandemic, I want to play it again and perhaps I will buy it.

Current Rating: 7.0
[hr]

RATING: 10
Survivor: Realer than Reality The Board Game.

You have washed-up on a deserted island. Do you:
(a) Find food
(b) Build shelter
(c) Make sharp sticks
(d) Explore the island
(e) Salvage crates
(f) Invent a shovel
(g) Complain
(h) Give motivational speech to other survivors
(i) Live together
(j) Die alone

A great cooperative game with a strongly integrated theme. Take risks and reap the rewards, or play it safe and not die.

RATING: 9.5
This is a very unique game. It allows so many possibilities in a highly thematic setting for playing a game. Although it offers very few characters, 4 from base, 1 from expansion and 2 more from other sources, it still managed to offer a great gaming experience. I love the theme, the mechanics on how it works, and quality of the production. The only complaints I have would be: poorly written rule book and lack of characters. The rest is simply outstanding. Try it, it's worth it if you like this sort of game, which is moderately complex in my opinion.

Update:[After two games of 2P, and 4 sessions of solo in scenario 1and 2, I can conclude that this game is really a fantastic creation. The theme, the excitement, the tension it build and the dilemma it gave us when making tough decisions, all are excellent quality stuff. Try it at least, you won't regret it!] 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is the true 'Sandbox' experience that I wanted from the board game. It truly hits all the aspect 1) sense of exploration and adventure, 2) managing resources, 3) building items - all while you are trying to clear scenario's goal.

Each scenario gives vastly different feel to one game from another. There is just so much that comes with the base game that you will never go bored with years down the road. I could be playing a game where I rush to grab woods to make a huge bonfire to send rescue signal, or taking a role of exorcist to discover dark mystery surrounding the cursed island. On top of this, the designer and fans constantly bring their own scenario ideas where you can print and play which is just fantastic. This game will never get old.

The only negative that I have with this game is the production quality on the cards. The game board, dice, wooden tokens, and just about everything else is perfectly fine. But you can definitely tell that they cut the cost down on the cards. These cards have such a terrible finish on them that they get damaged so easily with careless shuffling. Thus, I highly recommend people to sleeve them - they will definitely wear out quickly otherwise.

Also, the game is incredibly hard. It does reward players for taking best possible choices, but sometimes you wonder whatever choice you make, you have a little chance against the game as it feels like much of the game is luck driven with which tile comes up, which event card gets revealed, and so on - not just dice rolling. However, this bothers me much less than other games as I take this game for its thematic values, not strategy. I am stranded on an island, struggling to survive - if it was like spending a week on tropical beach with fruit cocktails, I would have been much disappointed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Microbadge
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game hit my playing groups sweet spot. We have been yearning for great story driven games that gives you the feeling of a sandbox world where you can do "anything" and your actions have consequences. This game put our dream a notch higher: no downtime between players, there's so much to do so there's no one to say "this is the absolute best solution" do like I say or we're going to die here.

I can't wait to my next set of games - didn't even clean the table from RC for a week :D

RATING: 7.23
MG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a complex, thematic, and highly procedural co-op that is quite punishing to play (both in terms of game play and meeting scenario goals as well as in rule look-ups and set up and break-down). There is a lot to track and keep in mind as you go through the game and the game bafflingly does not come with a good rules summary to help. Personally, I am quite patient with rules-heavy games and don't mind looking up a bunch of stuff during play, but I think I am in the minority on that point. I've played this twice now (scenario 1 & 2) and both times we came away saying:

"I like the idea of this game, but it's a ton of work to play."

"I want to like it more than I do."

"We have other co-ops that are just as much fun that have a A LOT less overhead."

"I don't mind a hard co-op, but in this one I feel like it starts getting hopeless, but not totally, but enough that the last hour feels utterly hopeless. At least with Ghost Stories the inevitable tragic end comes quickly."

These kinds of responses tell me the game is not for my group. This makes me a little sad since I, too, love the concept of the game. I have too many games, though, to hold onto ones like this hoping that attitudes change.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A very interesting game with some great mechanisms. I suspect we will never be able to play it without the rule book on the table.

RATING: 7
It's a decent game, unique in that it is a survival game. It captures the theme quite well. I like the idea of "foreshadowing" through deck-building: you know ahead of time what bad stuff will happen to you, although I don't think it's worth memorizing them, so it appears random.

The major complaints are the rulebook and the cardboard components, which are so thin and small. These are the small problems that plagued 51st state, this company really needs to fix their product quality.

edit: the new edition is wonderful, it is now a solid game.

RATING: 9
Reality is unpredictable...and Robinson Crusoe captures that concept in board game form like no other. Yes, it's tense. Yes, it's tough. But that's what happens when you're deserted on an island. If you want that experience, this is your game. If it's too tough for you, use the official suggestions in the back of the manual of throwing in Friday and the dog. Friday and the dog make the game a little easier, but more importantly they allow you to take a breather every once in a while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Robinson is a success thematically, has replayability through differentiated scenarios and offers enough interesting decisions to warrant gamers' attention. But it suffers from the same problem of being overloaded with mechanisms as Trewiczek's other games that I have tried so far (Stronghold, Pret-a-Porter). Each turn, players go through administrative motions to simulate the hostile environment on the island and have to cope with the results while ultimately working toward the scenario goal. There are some clever ideas such as the possibility to take benefits from events and in turn shuffle the event into the main draw deck which later will lead to potentially severe negative consequences. In detail though, the system is creaking, e.g. the awkward handling of mandatory events, the repetitive die rolls or the motivation mechanism that feels plugged on.
I would play Robinson again but as far as cooperative games go I rather stay with Pandemic, Space Alert or Arkham Horror. The input-output relation is better on these titles either gameplay wise (Pandemic), funwise (Space Alert) or in immersion (Arkham Horror).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.3
This game beats you up from start to finish. Very thematic and fun to make up stories as you play. Rules aren't the greatest.

5/27/2016: I really enjoy this game. Although there is a lot of ambiguity in the cards and rules, I have found that if you go with the option that makes the most thematic sense, it really enriches the game rather than take away from it. You start to create a dialogue of why you are taking a cube off the board rather than just moving a yellow cube back into the supply pile for example. I would like to see another 5-6 good scenarios created for this. There are some fan made ones that I may need to try.

RATING: 8
2014-02-13 - 7.5 - Good coop - a little bit too long setup, and not as thrilling as it should be in my opinion. I liked it but I always prefered to play something else. You need to remember about a little bit too many things that are triggered during the game.

2016-02-13 - 7.5->8 - After a long time of not playing Robinson I finally got my own copy. And I must say that there is a lot of adventure in this game. IMO you should know the rules well to fully enjoy the game. There is quite a lot of small rules that you need to remember but it's just worth it.

RATING: 7.5
Crisis after crisis, this is a very thematic story-driven cooperative game. Sometimes the luck plays a huge factor and makes impossible to win, regardless of plans. Not a very good solo experience, because this is not a puzzle, it is a pure Ameritrash, you play the odds.
Scenarios Overview: Castways (long and hard), Cursed Island (fast and easy), Jenny (fast and hard, but too much streamlined), Treasure Island (too much dependent on luck)..

RATING: 10
One of the rare games I bought before playing it first.  What a great call!  I am in love with this one.  It has a ton of replay value and is just dripping with theme.  I'm sure it isn't for everyone, but this one is for me!  Maybe my favorite game.  :-D  I also pimped out my game, so that just adds a bit more flavor to it all.  I also own all promos and expansions for this one and intend to always get anything available as they are released.  I also got a copy of the 2nd edition rules, which are definitely better.  Oh... and it can also be played solo and is actually good when playing that way.  I am not the biggest solo board gamer, but this one will hit the table when I am feeling the itch to play even if nobody else is available.  Love this game!

RATING: 10
This is one hell of a difficult game. You need to do all these things but you have a limited number of people to do them all. You may of course try and do a lot of things but then you roll dice to see if you did it and, let me tell you, if you have no luck in dice you will lose, actually you will lose a lot in this game. But cooperative games MUST be hard. Therefore, if you are looking for an adventure on an unknown island you cannot get better than this game. It is a pure 10!

RATING: 7
Only played twice, once through each of the first two scenarios with the wife.  We won both, which seems odd, comparing to others' reviews, but I've scoured the rules and I think we're doing it all right.  The first scenario was pretty fun and very thematic.  It seemed we were doing very well, then the later rounds (months) hit along with worse weather and wiped out our resource stores - we barely were able to get the needed wood before the final round to start the bonfire before the boat left range.  The tension built well right up to the end. The second scenario seemed much less tangible and weakly themed.  I can't wait to get more than two of us playing and to try some of the later, more elaborate scenarios.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[b]*Possible trade/sale*[/b]

With two rounds under my belt, "Robinson Crusoe" currently stands as one of the most enjoyable games I've played in 2013.  

Designer Ignacy Trzewiczek, is always trying to tell a story with his titles and this one comes through in spades.  Solid euro mechanisms are given a dose of theme and chaos from dice and event cards.  You may not always be able to mitigate every bit of luck, but you'll certainly have fun and be left with an interesting tale to tell. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I Very like this game, but I would not want to play it all the time. Game is hard to win. It's fine that you have to be prepared for everything, but you can plan every action, and event card can ruin this.  Game can discourage to play anothe one game. 

On the other side, there is nice balance, some mechanics to make game little easier. Mechanics are very interesting, and winning the play gives you big satisfaction.

Nice for 2 players.
___
Bardzo lubię tę grę, ale potrafi swoją trudnością zniechęcić i nie zawsze chcę ją wyciągać na stół. Gra jest trudna do wygrania scenariusza. Mogą wystąpić sytuacje, że jesteś gotowy na niemal wszystko, a wydarzenie zrujnuje Twoje plany, ale HEJ! w końcu jesteśmy na bezludnej/nawiedzonej/pełnej kanibali itp. wyspie, nikt nie mówił, że będzie prosto. Mechanicznie, jest świetna, choć o kilku drobnych rzeczach trzeba pamiętać i warto mieć w pogotowiu instrukcję. Trudność gry można zmodyfikować pewnymi mechanikami (Pies, Piętaszek) Satysfakcja z wygranej jest ogromna, zwłaszcza, jeśli od przegranej dzieli nas jedna rana. Gra z czasem zyskuje w naszej planszówkowej ekipie. Bardzo przyjemnie gra się zarówno we dwójkę jak i pełen komplet czterech graczy. Posiada też tryb solo, którego osobiście, (samego trybu, a nie w tej grze) nie jestem największym fanem, ale spróbowałem i da się :-) Bardzo polecam, ale dla graczy, którzy już w coś pograli i nie zniechęcą się kilkoma porażkami pod rząd.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Amazing game. Theme and story development is among the elite for any game I've ever played.  Extremely challenging! During our game, we never felt like we were just playing against the game.  We actually developed light personal attachments to our characters and really wanted to survive the brutal challenges that the world threw our way.  *Requires* teamwork, but there's plenty of room to briefly "do your own thing" if you simply don't agree with the rest of the group.  Be warned, however, that cooperation is a must just to be able to survive to the next day.  We completed the Cursed Island scenario on the 10th (and final) day and clawed our way back from what looked to be certain defeat at least twice (including at the end of day 8 due to extremely severe storms combined with a significant lack of supplies).  Awesome!

RATING: 9.5
Have only played 2 of the scenarios in solo mode, but man what an experience.  By far, I think this is the most cohesive looking board game.  The artwork and design on the board and the cards really gives that added sense that you are on an island.  Based on theme alone, the game is top notch.

Though it is a coop game, I like the caveat that all the decision making is simultaneous.  Though there are some decisions that may be better than others, it doesn't feel "scripted" as any choice may still require the roll of the dice.  So what may seem like a very good decision at that time may totally screw you over after the dice has been rolled.

Learning the game was a chore though as the rulebook is not succinctly designed for easy learning and to recheck rule specifications.  Having player aids and the FAQ at hand is a must for me when playing the game.  The game can be fiddly but am willing to look past that for it's great gameplay.

RATING: 5
Great art.  Great theme.  The game is just too damned difficult and the rules have too much ambiguity.  There are situations where you have to make up rules as you go along and this makes the sheer quantity of rules it already has feel less meaningful.

If you're new to the game go to the back of the rulebook and apply ALL of the recommendations that make the game easier.  The difficulty is just BRUTAL and can feel like a time waste sometimes.

My advice if you're looking for a co-op board game that's moderately rules heavy:  skip this game and maybe get Eldritch Horror instead.  It has a clearer theme, stronger rule set, and even though it's difficult the gameplay feels a little more meangingful.

Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island is an epic game from Portal. You will build a shelter, palisade, weapons, you will create tools like axes, knives, sacks, you will do everything you can to… to survive. You will have to find food, fight wild beasts, protect yourself from weather changes…
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
http://portalgames.pl/shop/en/robinson-crusoe-2nd-edition-upgrade-pack--197.p.html


Trzewiczek takes the players to a deserted island, where they'll play the parts of shipwreck survivors confronted by an extraordinary adventure. They'll be faced with the challenges of building a shelter, finding food, fighting wild beasts, and protecting themselves from weather changes. Building walls around their homes, animal domestication, constructing weapons and tools from what they find and much more awaits them on the island. The players decide in which direction the game will unfold and – after several in-game weeks of hard work – how their settlement will look. Will they manage to discover the secret of the island in the meantime? Will they find a pirate treasure, or an abandoned village? Will they discover an underground city or a cursed temple at the bottom of a volcano? Answers to these questions lie in hundreds of event cards and hundreds of object and structure cards that can be used during the game...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
► Best thematic game.

[b]• Rating update September 2015: [BGCOLOR=#00CC00][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][BGCOLOR=#00CC00][b]10[/b][/BGCOLOR][BGCOLOR=#00CC00][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][COLOR=#FF3300]▼[/COLOR][BGCOLOR=#00CC99][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][BGCOLOR=#00CC99][b]9[/b][/BGCOLOR][BGCOLOR=#00CC99][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/b]

[b]Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island[/b] is a highly thematic game for 1-4 players, which scales really well with any number of players. The replay value is very high: 6 different scenarios, 4 different characters with 4 unique abilities each and a [i]huge[/i] amount of different cards which would only be available in other games by buying at least one expansion. The components are fantastic: the overall quality is great (thick cardboard tokens, custom dice), the artworks are gorgeous (minimalistic scribbly journal style) and the game is full of nice little details like double-sided character sheets for both genders. The game board deserves special praise, as it is not just beautifully illustrated, but it also has one of [b][i]the[/i][/b] best layouts, making it readable like a text page (left/right, up/down) and guide you through the game's different phases - it is effectively one giant and interactive player aid.

The theme is very strong in this game, as it puts a lot of constant pressure on the players in their struggle for survival. This richness of theme comes at the price of complexity though: the rulebook is relatively long and full of small rule details and exceptions. You can read the rulebook several times and still discover some new details you overlooked or simply forgot in previous games. If you are interested in this game, don't expect to play it the next day after you bough it, as you [b][i]really[/i][/b] need to do your homework on this game.
Thanks to the strong integration of theme, most rules will make sense and are theoretically easy to remember -- but there are just too many of them. So if you are the kind of player who always needs to play 100% by the rules: don't play this game, it won't happen. To be honest, I really doubt that anybody [i]ever[/i] played this game 100% correctly by the rules. There is just too much to keep track of and the fact that the game is actually a bit fiddly and full of moving parts does not help in that regard.

It is a flawed game.

From all the cooperative games I have played, [b]Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island[/b] is most prone to the Alpha Gamer problem (one player taking control over the group, telling everybody what to do), as all items are stored in one common group inventory and always available to everyone. The action/planning phase (the main part of the game) is also always discussed and executed as a group. There are effectively no individual player turns in this main part of the game, as the planning has to happen simultanously because players are often relying on each other's direct support. The only thing which gives your character a unique feeling are the character sheets featuring unique health tracks and abilities.

Cooperative games need to be really challenging, or they are uninteresting to play. [b]Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island[/b] certainly is very difficult to win, but its difficulty comes from the wrong angle: the game is overall very swingy and players most of the time just stumble through the unknown while hoping for the best. This is maybe ok if you and your group are playing a scenario for the first time together, but if someone is new to a specific scenario while the rest of the group has already played it before, the newcomer will have no clue what is important in order to win, further enhancing the Alpha Gamer problem. The first time you play a new scenario, it will just be trial and error, which can be very frustrating to players.

Coming back to the previously mentioned swingyness/luck dependency: the game plays and feels very modular, full of possibilities and things to discover, which is actually a very good thing, but it's a game of extremes, as players will either do very well or fail miserably (often in catastrophic chain reactions). Dice are involved in this game and yes, they can indeed be avoided to some degree, but the game forces the players to push their luck for saving precious turns, which leads us to the game's "Adventure Cards". The first problem with those cards is, that their name is misleading: they should honestly be called "Disaster Cards", as players want to avoid drawing one of these cards at all costs, simply because most of them are really, really bad. The concept behind those cards and how they are thematically integrated is actually a big highlight of this game, but they sadly just don't work as "adventures". It's great that they sometimes offer decisions between option A and B, but this again boils down to the decision if you want to push your luck even further and just delay something which might happen on a future turn and hit your group unexpectedly and hard -- and it is absolutely possible to instantly lose the game by some desastrous chain reaction of bad events.

Another very swingy part of this game is the way the game handles hunting: you draw a random card, and the animal can be something dangerous between a flock of parrots (strength: 1) or a tiger (strength: 6) - and you just have to go through this encounter no matter what, meaning: there is no option to flee for you or the animal (which still surprises me, considering how thematic the rest of the game is).
If a player are not adequately prepared, a character can suffer severe damage and maybe even get killed, which immidiately ends the entire game for everyone. Players can indeed invest a lot of precious time and resources in preparation, but there is still the chance that it will turn out that you overdid it and wasted time and resources which could have been used somewhere else.

[b]Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island[/b] is arguably more of an "experience" and less of a "game" because of its unpredictability. It's complex and swingy but at the same time exciting and thematic. You will want to try out a new scenario and yes, you will fail horribly at first and be frustrated. You will want to draw a risky "adventure" card although you absolutely know you should not peek around that corner.

Personally, the positive aspects outweight the negatives ones for me, but I cannot blame anyone if he/she sees this balance differently, rating this game lower than I do. I am actually pretty sure that my own rating for this game might decrease over time in the future.
It's without question a flawed game, it's not for everyone and it certainly is not a game I would be willing to play every day, as it can be a really frustrating experience. Still, if I am in the right mood for a very thematic and challenging cooperative game which defines the struggle for survival by relying on a good amount of luck, then I will indeed enjoy my visit on the Cursed Island. And you will indeed curse a lot on and about this island...

:arrowE: The [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kobayashi_Maru]Kobayashi Maru[/url] of board games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you can wait for the Zman version, I would encourage you to do so.  The English in the Portal edition leaves quite a bit to be desired and the organization of the rules also leave a few questions.  Also, the components in the game manifest and rule set do not always match in shape or color what is shown which can be annoying.  There is a very helpful FAQ in the files section on BGG that I would highly recommend if you do purchase the Portal version.

However, the game is quite a bit of fun and quite thematic.  One does get into the narrative and the experience and there can be arguments over who does what and what we need to pursue to survive the best.  My favorite aspect of the game is your choice to either place two workers on a space to take the action safely or only place one and roll three dice to find out if you did complete the action, if another event card occurs, and if you have to take a wound or not...The different inventions add a bit of flavor to the game and outside of the basic nine, these can be different from game to game.  Also interesting is how those event cards can cycle back through with some resulting from the action that occurred when the card was drawn (IE, took a spider bite when the card was drawn? - then when it comes up again in the event phase, you will likely suffer an infection and gain a wound.)

Does this fix the alpha player issue?  No, the alpha player can still drive the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
* Component (ZMan)

Tokens easy to punch, well centered, thick enough.

Nice mounted map, good quality.

Cards of OK quality: a couple creased at the edge (transport?), with white creases (on black!).

Box only a little too big. Very sturdy (like Manoeuvre or Commands and Colors: Ancients).

* Rules

Quite streamlined (but not perfectly so: must consume 1 Food during the night phase, but get 2 wounds instead of the usual 1 wound for each unfulfilled demand).

Mostly make sense thematically (BUT: for Winter clouds, the cold weather forces you to "heat the camp" (rules) by burning wood… even if you don't have invented Fire–which is nonetheless necessary for some actions, as if you couldn't use your camp's fire.).

Quite a few holes and non-mentioned exceptions in the rules, but well covered by the FAQ (example: in scenario 1, the Mast's wood must be used right away, instead of being available at the end of the Action phase as usual with an invention).

The rules have actually the largest number of holes and rules that don't make full sense thematically that I have ever met (in about 150 games). This does not prevent me from enjoying the game, but it can slow down a game in a slightly unpleasant way. A solution is to house rule while playing, based on what makes sense thematically (this is satisfying, and does not give the impression that one is cheating), and then check later.

Furthermore, many "official" rules exist, it is not always easy to know which one prevails.

The designer, despite all his good intentions, is not present enough online to answer the many rules questions that open up.

The rules were obviously not tested on a scale large enough to prevent many difficult rule questions to be opened and discussed—in my 100+ games, I have never seen so many rule problems. The rule questions do not prevent from playing the game. They just give me a bitter taste when the game has to be slowed down when a rule question pops up during play: it is always hard to know if there is simply a hole in the rules that can be house-ruled without too much consequence, or if one is missing some important rule information that the designer really wanted in the game.

* Setup

The setup involves many components, but they are easy to place, thanks to the theme and the absence of any "counting": we just put the components where they logically belong.

* Game play

The situation does not evolve linearly, contrary to many games: the players can go through ups and downs that are all different. Example, first scenario: a wreck, but some easy wood gathering around natural shelters in the mountain, but then many nights  in the cold  hungry, only to hope to be able one day to have a nice, comfortable base for wood and food gathering. Which happens. But then you are exhausted by all the hardship and start losing hope, and stop taking care of yourself, and die. I like the kind of emotions and the variety that lie behind this.

The game can be paused easily anytime, and in particular at the end of a round. With about 12 rounds in +2 hours, each round is about 10+ minutes: the game can be played for a flexible number of rounds and picked back up later (if the game can be left on the table). Very useful for taking breaks (solo, in a pair,…); similar to watching yet another episode of a series. Very convenient.

I can't really see a dominant player deciding for the others so easily: the variety of situations (inventions, events, adventures,…) makes it harder to know immediately what is best to do. Furthermore, the fact that some needs are really pressing means that the strategy is dictated in large part by the situation more than by the players (there is still room for clever advance planning, for getting ready for possible upcoming difficulties).

Having no player turns is great: players can all discuss together and be involved in the same way in the game: they all have the privilege of being able to take actions/play. Better than anxiously waiting for your turn so that you can contribute, or than trying to suggest to other what they should play, robbing them in part of their turn.

The event (and adventure events) that take place each round give way more flavor and theme to the table than the corresponding event cards in another cooperative game like Pandemic. Robinson is way above Pandemic in terms of  flavor and variety.

The fact that it can be played solo is great for fulfilling any desire to play it. You still get the story, the adventure.

* Feeling

When I'm thinking of it, Robinson is a game where, in order to win, players have to manage resources (Food, Wood, Weapons, Shelter, Roof, Palissade), build Items that help getting these resources, in an environment with random events that regularly change the details of the needs in resources. This is, to me a management game, with some uncertainty handling. However, there is no victory point accumulation, just a sudden defeat that the players must avoid. Also, the theme is very strong, rich and very well integrated with the mechanics. All in all, in terms of gameplay, Robinson remains a resource management game (that feels like a constant Harvest phase in Agricola, where the whole game *is* meeting the needs of your people): the goal is to be in a position to get as much as possible of needed resources—with the planning and resource counting that goes with it. But a beautiful management game at that: each game has drama and depicts a story. This is very different from, say, a wargame, an abstract, or a party game.

In other words, calculating resource needs and generation capacity, planning, counting resources, handling a bit of uncertainty is what you *do*, it's the task you must succeed at. The story is what you *enjoy*. This is different, for example, from a role playing game (where creating a good story is what you *do*, it's your task), but also different from a game like chess (where you try to get to good positions), etc. Fundamentally, the *task* that Robinson gives you is resource management. This is how you win.

I have so many good memories of my adventures on the island! This is different from many other games that also I like very much: I am attached to the *scenarios*, to the stories, because they had a marked flavor, because I did use my imagination more than in many other games. This feeling is precious. I get a similar feeling with games with scenarios with a strong flavor, like Earth Reborn, Claustrophobia, and (to a lesser extent, because the flavor is often similar) Space Hulk. Maybe Duel of Ages II will be like this to, thanks to the special characters and the funny situations in which they can find themselves. Some rare games of Magic: the Gathering are like this too, where some striking even happens (like Angel of Salvation saving a game, like Augustin VI (?) really bothering me for the whole game and naturally leading to my defeat,…).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Euro style co-op that has an amazing theme? Yep, it's one of a kind. Some scenarios are harder than others, but it's really not a problem. Brilliant game, only wish they had more scenarios.

RATING: N/A
Antique shop find!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've been on a tear about ccoperative games lately. They don't get much play action in either of my groups, and that bugs me, as there are a few I like. When Robinson Crusoe was suggested by a friend, I jumped at the chance, as I was getting to play a coop I'd heard good things about by a designer I really like. 

I was not disappointed, either. It's a tough game, but it sticks brutally close to its theme (with a few exceptions -- why doesn't fur help against cold? I'd like to tear down the palisade for wood, etc.) We had four nearly-new players (one had played before), so there was no alpha player problem. On the contrary, each round the planning was more like, "Hey, I can do some hunting, so that will take care of food." or "I think you've got wood covered, so I'll raise our morale and prevent this disaster." The game had its ups and downs; at one point all seemed lost and then we bounced back, only to get wiped out again. The weather dice are brutal, almost too much so. We were apparently shipwrecked in Alaska, and that was our undoing. 

It was a lot of fun and a great game. But, sadly, another game that won't get played because, "what's the point if I can't win?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
55 miniature market
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Sleeves
Rules Summary
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Engrossing theme, Lived up to its reputation of being hard.  My first solo play I lost half way through, my second I barely won.  Want to try with more and want to more scenarios.  Looks like lots of replayability.  The rule book's pretty rough, but I think teaching it wouldn't be that bad.  There's a lot to keep track of and PuntheHun's player aid is a must have to guide you through the steps of the game.

Best comparison for me is Dead of Winter, even though this is a true co-op.  All the cards that tell the story and dripping theme.  I prefer DoW, for the traitor aspect/unique player goals, and they way that mitigates the Alpha player problem.  Both are excellent though.

RATING: 9
El juego me ha encantado por su rejugabilidad (tiene muchas cartas de Evento, Aventura y objetos)y exigencia, pues te hace tener la cabeza en varias cosas a la vez,  obligándote a priorizar y elegir la opción no más buena, sino la menos mala, pues la mayoría de vicisitudes que ocurren son o malas o peores.Esto puede provocar cierto análisis-parálisis, sobretodo en las primeras partidas cuando no se conoce del todo la mecánica del juego. La tematización del juego es fantástica, te hace sentir realmente que estás perdido en una isla.
Juego difícil que promete horas de diversión, con el toque suficiente de aleatoriedad debido al lanzamiento de dados que le da más emoción al juego.

Uno de mis favoritos a partir de ya.

RATING: 9
I prefer it solo mode.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a pretty thematic risk management game, as almost anything can be performed or mitigated for sure, you'll just have to pay through the nose in actions to do so. I like that this game still has a decent amount of variety and theme without having to sacrifice strategic planning. This game besides the different themes gives a similar feel as Ghost Stories for me, despite the different mechanisms: both are variable puzzles whereas you need to balance risk with possible mega turns. However, in Ghost Stories you can be screwed over completely by one or two bad die rolls despite the strategy, whereas in Robinson I feel like you would have to get really unlucky to be completely screwed by the dice. In both games the individual character powers feel fairly different from one another.

There are a lot of tech options but I do not think they are a source of information overload, as usually you unlock a few at a time as you discover new terrain.

My cons of this game are 1. the rulebook leaves ambiguities in a lot of places and 2. there is a decent amount of upkeep to keep track of (each step is fairly quick so it doesn't bog the game down, but there are definitely moments where you might forget to complete one of the steps).

EDIT after buying the 2nd edition: Rulebook is clearer now but seems overly wordy and some sections aren't where I would logically put them. Still have only played the 1st scenario.  I prefer how in Ghost Stories the ghosts are very in your face, whereas this one it feels more like a race in that e.g. you need to get a roof up before the bad weather kicks in, or fulfill the objective before time runs out. There is tension because it always feels like there are a lot you want to do but don't have enough actions for, but it isn't as much as watching your board get overrun by ghosts. I have been playing things relatively safe in avoiding drawing adventure cards as some of them seem horrible, which has reduced the variability of a given scenario. Hopefully there is more incentive to take more risks once in a while in future scenarios so I can draw these cards.

In terms of solo play, the dog only being able to perform very limited actions and not being able to do so by itself makes the solo action selection a little bit awkward, especially since it isn't as rewarding to spend actions to boost morale in solo. It still is fun to play solo, but I feel like certain scenarios might strongly favor one character over another (not necessarily a bad thing).

EDIT 2: This feels like a very unpolished game, with whole decks and actions almost never being utilized in certain scenarios, making it rather unwieldy, along with wild swings in difficulty depending on a couple chance cards, chance cards that are too uncommon and unique for you to actually prepare for. I also haven't had a huge desire to replay each scenario more than a few times, as my approach to each doesn't change that much (luckily, there is some good fan content out there to maintain replayability). Unfortunately, no other game gives the thematic trapped on the island feel while have the strategic layer of a euro, so for now it will remain highly rated by me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A beautifully produced and original game that blends worker-placement with other elements in  such a way as to avoid the sort of grinding sense of themelessness one often experiences with other recent Euros that employ that increasingly overused mechanic. 

The rulebook is exhaustive but not especially smooth reading, which can make the game look painfully fiddly at first, but playing through a few turns is enough to give one a solid feel for how intuitively everything fits together. The one thing it took me a while to get used to was planning around the contingencies introduced on each Scenario card; studying these things in advance is VERY important. But the variability of scenarios adds enormously to the game's replayability. 

The way the scenarios work actually also place places it in an interesting and perhaps unique niche withing the history of the hobby, as gamers start to become disenchanted with WP-based Euros and correspondingly obsessed with the legacy mechanic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This one is really good, which surprised me a bit as I'm not a fan of the genre. After I play more scenarios I might change the score, but probably up to 9 and not the other way around :) Very thematic, quite simple once we get a hang of it, and actually quite fast-playing for such game. Good as a solitaire game (which also surprised me :P).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I thought Castaways was neat until I played this. RC is a much better game. I may have to say that Castaways has been fired. RC scales exceptionally well with any number of players, production quality is very good, the rules are well written, it is easy to teach, it is easy to learn, and the decisions you make have meaning and are interesting. Lastly, the story aspect is there. It is integrated into the game and isn't excessively long like it is in Castaways (where other players might wait up to 15 minutes for you to finish your expedition).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is very addictive. It's is as difficult to figure out as Roads & Boats, Twilight Imperium, or Arkham Horror, but it is SO worth the effort to do so. The first play was very frustrating, but after reading the FAQ, subsequent plays are much easier -- to understand and play -- not necessarily easier to win.

RATING: 9
Absolute gem of an adventure game!  Excellent mix of decision making and randomness make for a great play every time. The event decks are terrific, ensuring decisions you make while performing actions have lasting, thematic repercussions. The game's mechanics are very flexible and support a multitude of varied scenarios that play out differently every time. 

I have the Portal 2ed, which I'm told fixes and improves many aspects of previous editions.  The production quality is top notch, the rule book is easy to follow and descriptive, and the player aid makes turns go quickly. 

This is a go-to game for anyone yearning for adventure.

RATING: 7.5
"Robinson Crusoe" is an excellent game BUT it suffers from some bad design decisions that lead to excessive randomness. Winning or loosing the game it's not a matter of experience but it depends almost totally on luck, which is, to be honest, irritating. 

Nevertheless, its theme realy shines through gameplay and you have the feeling of an adventure. Additionally, the game has the designer's and fans' support (new scenarios! yeah!), which is always a great thing! 

So, in conclusion, if you are a fan of cooperative games and you can ignore the luck-factor, then RC is a must have. 

PS: Once again, not a very good rulebook, but this is not a big deal.

RATING: 9
I really love this game! It offers so much theme, you easily could get lost (where are you, Wilson! )

Difficulty-wise, it´s quite a challenge. It may turn off impatient gamers looking for a quick success. Indeed, you will have to try hard to win any scenario, and you will lose more often than you win. You have to be lucky sometimes, either. But the experience is quite rewarding and I recommend this game wholeheartedly.

The rules should have been more concise, at least concerning the german version of the Portal Publishing Version, so you should pick up this game for the second edition.

RATING: 8
For me this is very much a role-playing game turned into a board game, which means one thing - the players you are playign with determine its enjoyability.  Almost every game is made better or worse by its players, but this game more so than most.  It is tense, seemingly realistic (as best it can be) and if one really played-up the role playign aspect, I could see it really beign enjoyable.

Sadly, my group, although D&D role-players, couldn't seem to get into it.  I suspect I wouldn't enjoy role-playing with them anyway.

P.S. Not referring to everyone, just a select few who could ruin it for everyone.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is not for everyone, but I love it. The game comes with a number of different scenarios with different goals, but the heart of each one is to accomplish something while trying to survive and explore a punishing desert island. The game is VERY hard - if you are of the mindset that you must win to have had fun, you will hate this game. However, if you come at the game as an experience wherein you get to try and overcome insurmountable odds, hunt exotic creatures, go on adventures, and most likely die trying, and that sounds fun to you, then you will likely love this game.

One thing I will add - this game plays 1 - 4 players. I've found it great as a 1 player game with Friday and the dog to help you. Maybe it was just my friends, but 2+ players was a bit of a miserable experience. Choosing what we were going to do took forever, the game has tons of options (which is a good thing!) but leads to strong disagreements if strong personalities are involved. Not simple stuff like Pandemic "Jakarta is going to blow up," "But we're so close to curing red!" stuff. Fundamental stuff like "We need food to not die" "But we need wood to win the game!" "But we need to explore or we'll never get the tools we need". This can cause multiplayer games to turn into 4+ hours of frustration as no-one can possibly do everything they think is important, and the game constantly shows up every round to slap you around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Refreshing coop game to play with friends or spouse. The narrative flows naturally from the events and the objectives. Very well done.

RATING: N/A
Quick Impression: Wasn't overly impressed by our initial play through, but I would be willing to try it again with a more thorough understanding of what is going on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game was on my "wishlist" for a while. I knew it was a meaty game with great potential and reportedly infinite replay-ability, but I just couldn't pull the trigger. I already had some heavy/longish games that almost never get played, and I didn't want to add it, play it once and then store it with the others. Luckily, that was not the case--far from it. Instead, in the matter of a week, I've already broken this game out twice and I'm ready to play it again. Taking a look at the pros and cons:

The good:
-Immersive and thematic
-Addictive 
-Excellent components 
-Replay value
-Fun! 

The bad:
-Long--2-3 hours, depending on player count
-Relatively high learning curve
-Although thematic, the rulebook is rather lengthy. Be fully prepared to nurse the rule book for the first few plays. There are several rule exceptions and specific character/action rules that are difficult to remember at first, not to mention several different scenarios.

Update 8/11/14:

This game is simply too complex. I played another solo game today (third game total). I spent 50-60% of the game time looking up rules. Mind you, I remembered the rules fairly well, and have seen it played within the last week. It just seems like it's a little too heavy for its own good. Things began to fall apart quickly, but oddly, the tension didn't seem to increase as the became more difficult. I'm really struggling with my rating here. I like the game, but I seem to like it considerably less after playing it a third time. There's just a lot of pieces, time and effort put into a game that I could care less, once the halfway mark hit, whether I won or lost. I hope to get this back to the table soon, and I think I'll try another scenario to shake things up a bit. 

Update 2/24/17: 

It's amazing how a refreshed rulebook and a "Watch it Played" tutorial can transform a game from a messy clunker with a cool theme to one of my favorite board games of all-time. Congratulations, Ignacy! This game is finally coming to fruition! I seriously don't know if I've ever had so much fun playing a strategy-based board game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is an excellent, truly cooperative game. The rules are a mess, both in the book and on the scenario boards, which certainly makes it harder to play. In the second scenario the Fog mechanism is particularly confusing. 

The only downside to the game IMO is the way that the ending is usually somewhat anticlimactic. I guess that it's a result of the game being a Euro in nature (despite the dice and cards), the end goals themselves are achieved in a more Euro manner. It's odd, because the games plays out very thematically with each event being full of tension and story, but the game itself can end with a "oh, we won". 

Despite this slight failing, it's one of my favourite games at the moment.

RATING: 9
Very good co-operative game (also playable solo, but I never tried it). Encourages planning in advance and is very satisfactory when our previous moves just come together nicely in the later phases.
Sometimes you get the feeling you're going to lose the scenario, only for a couple favourable decisions to turn the game on its head to give you the great feeling of accomplishment.
Takes some time to prepare though and the game time may exceed 2+ hours.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really fiddly and hard co-op.

It's almost so hard that you should always play this game with the same group every time, since adding new players to the mix will only: 
a) lose the game 
b) make the game boring for the new player, since the experienced players will dominate every decision

The choices in this game matter a lot and you can't waste turns on doing stuff "just because"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Cooperative worker placement, with a captivating thematic background. The storytelling part is so well done, that if you are into the island survival genre, it's almost role-playable, while the solid resource/risk management engine gives enough to think and argue about. There's too many things to concentrate to, so there's the constant dilemma of doing things safe and slow but running out of time, or take a more hazardous approach, while the game keeps throwing random stuff at you- and it does all this, without missing a thematic beat. 

The rulebook is intimidating at first, too many information scattered all over without a summarized guide, but if one tackle it, the game itself is really simple and intuitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
An original and very creative co-op with mechanics I haven't seen before that holds its theme with a plethora of cards that mean you don't often encounter the same situations.

The game is tight like Ghost Stories and each scenario plays like a puzzle.  You can play them over and over too because there's enough variety of cards, land tiles and situations to make every game different.

The gameplay also provides a very thematic narrative.  This rating could go up after a few more plays.

Feb 20/13:  2 more plays. Bumped half a point to 8.5.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Before you sit down and attack this game, you must be prepared for the almost certain eventuality that you are about to spend 2+ hrs struggling through an ever deepening nightmare of tropical diseases, bad weather, and animal attacks that ramp up as your health dwindles, only to realise that you will not beat the game this time!
I don't get to play it much, and out of the 6 odd times I have played (castaways scenario only, so far), I've won twice! But It is SOOOOO satisfying when you do win. And when you loose, yes, you wonder why you just spent 2hrs playing this thing for it to mess you around and spit you out. There is a good reason though, and that is the theme. If you die in this game, its because you may not have the minerals to actually survive on a cursed island. I joke of course, what I mean is that the theme is so immersive that when you recount to yourself the events leading up to your terrible demise, it will sound like a story line for a film, "got ill from those berries, then Friday died whilst trying to build that godforsaken palisade, and the final straw was the wild animals taking my food just before the storm set in".
Win or loose this game is fun, you just need to be prepared for the worst before you play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Pros: Thematic, challenging, rich, and dramatic coop experience.
Cons: 
-The rules are a complex mess
-Fiddly with lots of bits and pieces to keep track of
-Can be somewhat dry if you get lost in the numbers and resource management
-Often overstays its welcome; plays better with an "intermission" about halfway through
-Susceptible to "alpha gamer" syndrome. Since each player doesn't have his own turn, cards, etc., it is essentially a collaborative solitaire game

RATING: 8.5
Maybe I should rate this a 9.  I really enjoy this game for it's terrific hybrid euro sensibilities with it's engrossing theme and Ameritrashy elements.

I just wish a single, complete rulebook/faq could be released because the game is tight enough that I really don't want to "cheat" on even the most minor points.

RATING: 8.5
When we talk about this game apparently we make it sound like we actually experienced the island ourselves.  Surviving this game is a lot tougher than farming.

Update 1:  Rating based on using "Castaways Quick Start Guide to Robinson Crusoe" available in the files section on BoardGameGeek.  Without this fan made guide we would have had no idea how to start our first game after reading the instructions that came with the game.  Since we used this in our first game we never experienced the frustration of learning the game from the rulebook that others may have experienced.  Whether or not a game's rating should benefit from external material like this is too existential for me to concern myself with.

RATING: 8
[microbadge=1714]

[u]23-Jan-2014[/u]:  Wow.  Seriously...wow.  What a game.  So thematic.  So tough.  Nice components and art.  The narrative in this one just unfolds as you play.  It's just what I was hoping it would be.

You play a character (or several if playing multiplayer) stranded on an island in the middle of nowhere, Robinson Crusoe style.  You must overcome just the basic needs of survival like eating and shelter and making tools and hunting and the weather.  But!  There are also six different scenarios included in the game with varying sets of goals to achieve.

So much in this game rides the wave of the theme so wonderfully.  Events come up that start rather simple and not too harmful, only to return later in the game to create havoc and a feeling of hopelessness.  Animals stalk you hoping to have themselves a tasty snack.  Storms batter your little hut as you huddle underneath the poorly constructed roof you built.  You search the island for supplies to build better tools and weapons to help your survival.

Oh my.  Just so much [i]juiciness[/i] packed into this co-op game.  It isn't easy.  But it is definitely fun.  Well worth the price of admission.

[u]09-Jul-2015[/u]: If I'm being honest, I have to admit this game is straddling the line between frustration and enjoyment. I've played eight times in total and have yet to win. And I believe only one of those did I actually have a chance for victory. Even so, I still really enjoy the game.

I find the narrative flow to be the game's strong point. There are so many events and things going on, I can't believe it actually holds together. Maybe others find this a detriment, but I get a lot of enjoyment from the experience of playing the game. There is much to be done, but there are never enough pawns to place on actions. Weather comes into play. Animals attack. Disease. Fire. Who knows what else?! It's a wild ride.

And so far, I'm staying on it. Maybe over time, the lack of success will eventually push me into that frustration area, but for now, I'm in. It's a fiddly game, with lots of decks of cards, and many tokens & cubes to keep track of, but the story created by this gaming experience has been excellent so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favorite board game. Ever. Its a wicked combination of immersive theme and a plethora of options during turns. Robinson Crusoe encourages sophisticated group thinking. 

The game brilliantly addresses the luck factor by (most of the time) giving you the option to use extra resources to avoid rolling dice and automatically succeed in whatever you are attempting. 

Please learn from my suffering! On a whopping six separate sad occasions, I set up the game and refreshed my memory concerning the rules- only to have the players decide to bail out on the attempt because they were overwhelmed and it had already taken up so much time. I was smart enough to recognize the merit of the game regardless, and I'm overjoyed that I stuck with it. YOU can and should avoid any similar sadness. This is a tough game to teach (to non-gamers, of course, even more so). There are a lot of different elements to keep track of. I heartily recommend playing through the game solo until you feel really comfortable with the setup and rules. I also recommend downloading one of the invaluable quick reference files here on the Geek.

This is a modern masterpiece of game design and I can't wait to see the future games that rely on its influence.

RATING: 8
Including promo cards

A wonderful cooperative game that is different each time you play it with tons of different event cards, weather that changes and of course the many different scenarios: 6 in the box, with some due out on the website (King King from what I heard at Essen), as well as an expansion I hope.

The experience is truly remarkable - a nice deep Ameritrash/euro hybrid that comes to life and actually feels real.

With regard to length - I don't know what people are talking about. Solo it's 30-45 minutes, and with two it's 60 minutes. Four might be a bit longer due to discussions, but hey, what would you expect on an uninhabited island?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Wow, I wish I knew what to think of this game. As a solo game it feels unbalanced after 10+ sessions; 2 or 3 of your 7 action choices feel under-powered in solo play, which is a real problem for me. It also feels as if the game is playing me at times. That's not necessarily a BAD thing in a game this thematic, but when I win I feel lucky, not good. Better in group play, but its length keeps it from hitting the table too often in most of my groups. I hope this one opens up a bit for me.

RATING: 8
A cooperative game par excellence that is simply frustratingly difficult to win because the rules are STACKED against you.  Even playing with the NPC allies Friday and the dog, you're still going to be hard-pressed to survive.  A fun game, with buckets of theme and lovely art - and, also, not replayable enough for me to warrant keeping on the shelves.  My then-friend Kelli in New Haven was a very sharp gal who picked the game up rather quickly and played it through twice or maybe 3 times with me.  As a present I gave her my copy and picked up a new copy of the original as well as the Beagle expansion and the promo cards - and then we drifted apart, I moved to Maryland and then back to OH... and it never got played again.

A GRAND game, just not a good one for my typical gaming group and the scheduling constraints thereupon.  Sold at auction on BGG.

(Written on 4/26/16)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ami elsőre átjön mindenkinek, akár tetszik neki a játék, akár nem: van hangulata.

A másik meg, hogy szép. De legalábbis nem csúnya.

Kooperatív, 1-4 játékosig + Péntek és a kutya, ha szeretnénk még képzeletbeli barátokat magunknak.

Ignacy ezt viszont kicsit túltolta, már ami a játékszabályzatot illeti. Nem az a játék, ami elsőre menni fog szabálykönyv lapozgatás nélkül. Sőt, valószínűleg a második sem. 40 oldal. Kicsit lehetett volna áramvonalasítani talán (3-4 féle jelölővel kevesebb, 2-3 pakli kártya a kukába és máris gyorsabban mennének a dolgok azon a k..rva szigeten). :0)

Mondjuk ahhoz képest érthető és logikus (szinte) minden, de mindenki számítson rá, hogy ahhoz, hogy ezt a játékot játszani tudja, bele kell tennie jó néhány órát.

Az meg csak annak éri meg, aki barátságban van az ameri játékokkal...

Nekem pont az a bajom, hogy nem szeretem az ameriket. A történetmesélős-kockadobálgatós játékoktól a falnak tudok menni. A Robinsonnak adok még esélyt, mert az első 1-2 játék kifejezetten érdekesre, izgalmasra sikerült.


Update (2017.06.13.): angol eladva, magyar kiadás megrendelve
Update (2017.12.20.): magyar kiadás megérkezett, már csak játszani kellene vele
Update (2017.12.22.): első játék pipa
Update (2018.02.12.): Nem nagyon került, így inkább eladtam.

RATING: 9
SOLO CAPABLE

120 Min. (longish setup)


Amazing game. Works great solo. Not even sure I'd want to play this co-op. Lots to think about every round. A very long game, for me at least. The 2 hr playtime listed seems short to me. I'm still new to the game, but I can't see getting it done in less than three. Be prepared to spend time thumbing through the rule book, the online faq, and additional forums; many questions about the rules will arise for your first few plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game, espacially the solo play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First impression is an 8; it's tough and the events, while random, fit the theme incredibly well. The way many events give you a boon but then get shuffled into the deck and hurt you later is pretty well executed; for example, a card came up while exploring telling us that we'd found mushrooms, giving us food. We had to shuffle the card into the event deck, and when it came up it hurt us all (eating wild mushrooms made us sick) unless we had the Cure invention.

The rulebook is tough to learn from (watch a video!) but it flows well once you get into it. 

Excellent, tough, thematic coop.

I must add that the support for the game and the positive presence of the designer has been impressive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Is there anything in this game that doesn't kill you??
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What a gem! The pride of our collection. A fantastic game about survival, adventure, and team work. Components are beautiful and numerous, but with some good organisation set-up is quick. Mechanics are easy to learn and rules are very thematic, meaning that queries can be solved with a little common sense. Plays just as well with 2 as it does with 4. 

Game play is tough, but in a co-op game that is excellent. Repeated plays have seen our strategies improve, but each scenario requires a different tactic, and the luck of the cards determines which challenges come our way. Can't wait for Z-Man to publish the expansion!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An overly hyped game that tries hard and gets some things right but has many problems:
1) the rules situation is a complete train wreck; many a wargame has a cleaner ruleset; lack of concensus even in rules clarification posts; I hate when an air of uncertainty hangs over an apparent victory
2) very high fiddly factor, protracted set-up
3) components not that great: board space poorly used; weird mix of mild and garish colors (the dice are truly ugly); tiny health track on character cards; what's up with the plastic cubes?
4) limited replay value: now that we've beaten Castaways (took three tries), there's little reason to play that scenario again
5) too long, more work than fun
[3 plays]

RATING: 7
A rules-complex co-operative game that is hard-to-learn, but really thematic.  Each scenario provides a rich and detailed story on top of an interesting strategy game.  Three players seems the ideal player count: more challenging than with 4 players, but also much faster.  The gameplay gets rote and procedural if you focus only on the mechanisms.  With this game, you want to embrace the theme and ham up reading the flavor text on each card that flips. (Traded to Pierre for Trajan.)

RATING: 8
Although bad luck with rolls can really destroy a game, I love the strategy of timing your builds and the mood of scraping by that this game creates.  This game is pretty immersive, because the random events and weather beat you into submission.  There are definitely better missions than others (the first put off my GF from playing again due to boredom), and the game is much better with fan-crated missions for replay-ability. 
The expansion adds some story diversity, but I'd rather have more event cards. My main complaint is that the event cards should have more diversity.  
Edit:  Good pre-game for Spirit Island.  I added a star ... je ne c'est quoi ... but this is still fun for me after a couple of years.

RATING: 7.5
A great co-op with a fantastic theme. You cannot hope to do even half of what you want to and are forced to make some pretty tough decisions. You need to take risks if you are going to succeed. 

6 pack-in scenarios plus another two available for download (thus far) provide plenty of variety. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Reminds me of playing Arkham Horror with lots of tough threats, opportunities and risks.
Beautiful artwork and immersive but fiddly with LOTS of  administration required to generate the story environment. There is plenty of strategic and tactical decisions to make. Seems like a lot of replayability available. Not a game for everyone. If you like coop and thematic games with lots of chrome this should appeal but ultimately a niche game.

Pretty good solo game but fiddly setup really requires 2-3 sessions to make it worthwhile. Yet to play cooperative - anticipating big alpha player syndrome. Unlike Pandemic, at least everyone is doing something all the time.

The ZMan rulebook is poor, in respect of both learning the game and clarifying the game mechanics. There are many game rule exceptions not addressed by the rulebook so FAQ referral is necessary. Quite a few typos in the rulebook plus card misprints, which shows that ZMan rushed this into production.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Our first game ended after 5 turns...... in death! so back to the island we go and this time we make to being rescued.

This game is not for those looking for an easy co-operative game but for gamers who want a theme drenched island of challenges.

RECOMMENDED.

You’re a shipwrecked survivor relying on your determination and skills to overcome the challenges of building a shelter, finding food, fighting wild beasts, and protecting yourself from the weather, possibly discovering the island’s secrets in the meantime.

A thematic and cooperative storytelling adventure game of action point allocation, worker placement, and variable player powers.

Need to play both more for a better assessment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yes, the rulebook (1st edition at least) is caca. Get the Castaway's Guide. Once you get over that hump, you have a game which creates amazing stories, filled with tension and memorable moments. The adventure cards are genius (and their absence in First Martians is what makes FM a worse game, IMHO). The press your luck aspect of dice rolling is a surprisingly effective way of giving you enough agency to feel elation when you succeed or curse your choices when you fail. Play wonderfully as a solo game. Feels much more open world than other coops like Pandemic. 

My faults, which take this from a 10 to an 8: 

(1) even after you understand the rules, there is a persistent level of ambiguity in various cards and effects that you really have to interpret the designer's intent far too often. This isn't ALL bad however, because this acts as a level for scaling difficulty: if things are going badly, interpret vague things in your favor. If things are going "too" well, interpret things against your favor.

(2) the game is punishingly hard. you are going to lose, a lot. losing is fun, sure, but i feel like the chances of winning are skewed a little too low, ideally you would have a balance closer to a knife edge to create a feeling of "can i win?" versus "i'm probably going to lose, let's hope a miracle happens". (I think Pandemic is much better at creating this knife edge, but probably easier to balance that game due to much simpler decision space in that game).

For what it's worth, I rated First Martians a 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Thus far.... not really impressed. The game has some randomness (I like random!), but the planning/actions that come after the random events and before the random events just seem pretty simplistic and not all that interesting. I reserve my right to change this, I'm only 3 plays in.

RATING: 10
Game of the Year for 2013 I think.
Absolutely love this game, the theme is excellent and brilliantly implemented, especially for a Euro.  The mechanics are evil and constantly up against you.  The adventures and mystery cards are great, and the 'choices with consequences' aspect to them is genius, making each drawn card have its own little narrative.
There are some design elements which seem a bit dry, and the board is a little colourless for such an adventure game, but this does not detract from it being the most impressive game of the year in every other respect.
Ignacy, I tip my hat to you, sir.
Expansion looks great too...

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In this cooperative game, players are stranded on an island, and take on the role of soldier, cook, explorer or carpenter. Players have to solve one of the scenarios (building a fire to be rescued, or rescuing someone else who is stranded) with different victory conditions.

Players have to explore for food and resources. In addition they have to build palisades, shelter and weapons, to protect agains beasts and the weather. 

Players can also build materials.

The mechanism for this game is worker placement to do those actions. If you place 2 workers, you guarantee the action, but if you place only 1 worker, you have to roll dice which may generate event cards which can be bad. 

It's a tough game to learn on the first play, and even then it requires re-reading the rules. The board is not intuitively laid out on the order of which to do things either. 

I have only played once. If you like problem solving games, then this game is for you. If you get discouraged with many potentially fiddly rules, along with something that is not intuitive, this game isn't really for you. I like the problem solving aspect of this game, so if given the opportunity would like to try this again. But I was slightly turned off with the non intuitive rules. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Highly thematic and deep co-op.

Some quirky rules and text; hopefully the new Zman edition will have downloadable rules which will clear some things up and smooth out gameplay. But I love it anyway.

RATING: N/A
I'm slightly turned off by the length of this game 2+ hours at least especially for first game as well as the complexity and heaviness. Usually I only like a game to be heavy/complex and/or long if it's a theme and mechanical style I REALLY think is truly awesome. I think it's cool that this is fully coop and people say it's one of best coops of 2012 and maybe the best one especially if you only count thematic games. People also say that the theme really comes through on this one and it really feels like being stranded on an island. Also they say that it has massive replaybility and each of the different situations/scenarios has a bunch of replability in and of itself. That being said, while I like thematic, and cooperative games, I don't know if I'm IN LOVE with the theme and what I've heard so far about gameplay enough in order to deal with having yet another long heavy game that has a steep learning curb and tricky rules especially for new gamers. I make exceptions for this sometimes if it really dazzles me but this one isn't quite there. However, based on awesome theme, cool fun factor, and overall great design I am very excited for it in general and do hope to have the chance to at least play the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
My plays and feelings toward this have fluctuated quite a bit. My first game was extremely tight - 2 HP, 2 HP, and 3 HP remaining, and we had just enough wood. It was tight, close and fun.

But then, I realized we were playing this tiny rule wrong or that tiny rule wrong or that small exception incorrectly. I hated looking these things up to clarify it. There were so many gray areas, and the rules breaks destroyed the immersiveness of the story.

I also found the game swingy, sometimes too easily so, and sometimes too hard so. I think the health track should've been bigger too since your cubes can slide a bit on the cramped space and you're always adjusting. Another thing I hate is how so many "events" are really just the same variation of "bad weather". Really now? -_- They could've made it so much more thematically interesting. The item texts should've had clarification too. The question marks are also extremely unfriendly to colorblind people.

I've played scenario 1, the Robinson Family scenario, and the volcano island, and overall, I didn't feel extremely thematically tied. I think the basic mechanic of place workers->roll is kind of meh to me. The rolling just doesn't feel that thematic for a thematic game, since its a bit too abstracted to be engrossed. This is hurt by the rules breaks especially.

I do like the event deck and how things come back, and I like the different characters. I think their costs should've been cheaper to use abilities though. It would've made it a bit more balanced and would've been more fun I think.

Anyway, overall, a disappointing game.

Plays: 6+

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A cooperative thematic game is usually not the kind of game I prefer (with the noteworthy exception of Space Alert). Also there is a lot of luck involved that is usually another minus for me (but clearly a needed part of the design in this case, otherwise the game would be just uninteresting).

In spite of this I like this game and my family liked it even more.

It is a nice simulation with a lot going on.

Two drawbacks.

The first is that the rules are not smooth, especially the way they are written down. There are often small doubts coming up, even after playing many games (although the doubts tend to be only about tiny matters, even only after one game).

The second is that the game is tense and really making the players curious to know what is going to happen next, but after some games the game (and the way it is played) seems to be scripted, even if the author put much effort in giving a lot of materials (for example there are really a lot of event cards). 

But these are minor quibbles. The only reason my rating isn't higher is because it is not the kind of game that I prefer. I enjoyed very much the first games and you may like it even more if you like this sort of game more than me. For example my daughter likes it really a lot.

I advise you to play it, whatever your tastes, at the very least to enjoy the adventure-feeling of the game and the original mechanics. 

It is unique in its genre.

UPDATE October 2013
I played the game again after some time and I liked it less, especially because it is quite painful to refresh memory about all the micro-rules, especially because you need the FAQ to understand how some of them work. 

Besides IMHO the number of meaningful decisions is too little compared to luck and bookkeeping.

Consequently I have lowered the rating from 7 to 6 and possibly I would rate it even lower if it were not that my daughter really likes it: the thematic experience seems the strong point of this game, but it is not what I search for in a game, not only at least.
