RATING: 7
[B]TTS Play:[/B] Really enjoyed my first play of scenario one - it was interesting and engaging.  Played the Cook and rocked it thanks to the karma of the island: the broken bottle and pistol starting items kept me alive during beast encounters - I would not have lasted long without them.  My healing ability (soup!) and cloud reduction (warm food!) kept my health (and moral) up.  I explored a ton during the no weather turns and that REALLY helped (just took the hit for no shelter, and just healed myself later...).  The hatchet was essential for wood and just when I needed more there was a hurricane, for +2 wood.  The animal fights were timed perfectly, bringing food and pelts so I didn't need wood to improve shelter.  Really fun game...  It was a close last round, but I had played smart and mitigated the weather on the ninth round fine - was rescued the tenth round...  Going to snag the cardboard version of the game ASAP.  Got the cardboard in hand and loving it!  Another awesome play - down to the freakin' wire... Too cool, too cool.

BOX INSERT: Daedalus Productions Quick-Start Insert for Robinson Crusoe 

CARD SLEEVES: Mayday Games STAND57USA size sleeves for Event cards only (an Adventure cards inserted into Event deck).

EXPANSIONS: Voyage of the Beagle campaign played once.  Merged applicable components with base game and now exclusively play one-shot scenarios.

PURCHASED SCENARIOS: Dreadful Adventure on the King Kong Island; Tracing Doctor Livingstone; Poachers (Lukasz Kaleta)

PRINT AND PLAY SCENARIOS: Zombie Island (Cedric Chong); Leviathan's Defeat (Cedric Chong); The Naturalist (Robert Masson); S.O.S. (Bryan Wills); Hunters (Wojciech Wons)

RATING: 7
Difficult co-op game. This game plays very close to the edge, you're always just on the cusp of dying, and you really need to decide if you want to spend more time being safe and risk not completing your goals, or push your luck and risk suffering some horrible fate. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Great cooperative adventure game, especially for gamers tired of Pandemic or people who want to beyond this level of gameplay.

Everything on it is hugely thematic, you can write a story, even if the manual doesn't go into explaining theme very deeply, but it just make sense if you come to think about it.

A great mix of ameritrash and eurogame mechanics. 

I think it's inevitable to compare it to Castaways, because of its theme, their cooperative nature and because they were published at the same time. Even if the gameplay feels completely different, the have some mechanics and elements in common.
-> The strategy/tactic is very plain in Castaways, you do almost the same in every game. In RC, besides having different scenarios, you can try very different strategies (even with the same items).
-> RC wins making a bet for the cooperative nature; I just don't like semi-cooperative games.
-> RC is immensely more replayable; even one of its scenarios is more replayable than the whole Castaways.
-> RC is shorter.

In my mind, there's a clear winner.

RATING: N/A
Bagged
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
A good story-driven game along the lines of Tales of Arabian Nights.  

Like ToAN, don't expect a whole lot of planning ahead for later turns, but rather players try to "surf the wave" of the story and make the best of the bad situations that come up randomly.  

It's a "fun but not fair" kind of game, so if you demand game balance or fairness, this is probably not your game.
There is also a continuing issue with one player possibly dominating the rest and telling them what to do. This is a common problem in co-op games, of course.

Rating reduced for poor graphical layout.  With so many icons floating around you'd think that they would be bigger and more readable.   It makes a difficult-to-introduce game even more cryptic, especially for non-gamers.

RATING: 7
Very good game. Strongly recommended if you like cooperation in gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a game of survival, where each scenario adds an objective on top of that.  Maybe you have to rescue someone, maybe you have to lift a curse, maybe you have to fend off cannibals ... but in each scenario you have to: get food so you don't starve, build a shelter so you don't die of exposure, fend off beasts like tigers/snakes so they don't kill you.  On top of that there are mysterious treasures to find, random events and strange events.   So, there is adventure here, but the focus seems to be on survival - brutal conditions with no one to rely on but yourself - I know in real life I'd probably die, I wouldn't know what to eat, how to hunt or even start a fire - so far removed I am from my ancestors!

The game has open information and a loose turn structure when it comes to actions, so don't play with bossy people if that's going to bother you.  The game also forces you to develop a strategy and stick to it.  There are many, many things you can do and want to do in this game, but you can't do everything.  Anything that distracts you from your chosen strategy better be worth it!


The game hasn't been as brutally difficult as I thought it would be.  Certainly much easier to win than in Ghost Stories!

My rating is based on playing the first six scenarios, at least three times each  - the first scenario "Castaways" was a lot easier than I expected, which I have now won three times in a row - all scenarios offered a lot of strategy and also threw a lot of problems at you, which made you decide whether alleviating a new problem was worth it if it was going to divert you from your scenario goals.

The second scenario was very different, and virtually impossible for me, because I had the rules wrong!  Like any game, getting the rules wrong can destroy game balance and here it was devastating!  Once I did get the rules right, it was much easier, but the strategy I employed was futile and I had to change things up quite a bit.  What I 'wanted' to do, just wasn't really possible.

The third scenario was again quite different and challenging, though with so many plays under my belt I did quite well on my first try.   The fourth scenario was interesting and quite different.  The fifth scenario felt overly difficult due to pure luck and so I don't care for it - just too frustrating.  Scenario six was challenging, but possibly my favorite because you get the chance build so many cool things.

At the end of the day, I think calling it "Survival on the Cursed Island" would have been a much more accurate description.  Except for Scenario 5, there isn't much 'adventure' compared to just surviving: hunting, gathering, building.  That's the focus.  There's a huge deck of treasures, traps and monsters, but you pull very, very few of them each game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I like this game.  Finding the right people to play it with has been a challenge as it is a heavy, gamers' game. (I've  managed to fry the brain of non-gamers friends/family I've tried to play this with.)  Some of the complaints about the rule book seem to be unfounded in my second edition of the game.  There's a couple of things I've had to look up on the internet but that's it.  Brain burn is an issue, however, and the rules take a lot of learning and re-learning. If you're prepared to put in the effort though, it does provide a memorable thematic experience.  Playing it with dedicated gamers I'd give it a 8 or a 9 rating; casual gamers only a 6 or 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]We actually had a lot of fun playing this one, but man the rule book was a mess. I got tired of feeling like we were continually playing the game wrong and the huge FAQ was not fun to search through. If this game had a clean rule set it'd still be in our collection getting played.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]- A truly immersive gaming experience, one of the first games I've played that really tells a story of your particular adventure.
- The artwork is awesome, the tiles look beautiful and I love how the character mats and various decks of cards have sepia toned gesture drawings that look like they were done with ink in a field artists sketchbook.
- The production is top notch, there are absolutely no cut corners in this game, the $ of this game is definitely more than justified once you open up the box.
- Amazing how such a complex game flows quite smoothly after your first play or two. 
  [i]Overall I found the rule book to be well written and any other questions I had were answered on one of the faqs found here on BGG.[/i]
- I love how brutal this game can be, it really intensifies the stress you feel and forces you to work together as a team if you are going to have any chance at surviving [i](i.e. winning).[/i]
- The game does take a while [i](our games have been between 1 1/2 to 2 hours each)[/i], but time flies since the game is so engaging.
- By far the best co-op I've played, in fact I already bought the first expansion, but we won't break it open till we play through [i](and survive)[/i] the rest of the scenarios in the base game.

I'm happy that my buddy Jason brought this over to our house and taught us the game; I didn't want to by it sight unseen since most co-ops haven't been a hit in our house. With Forbidden Island/Desert for those times when we need a quick game and Robinson Crusoe when we want a meaty, story telling experience I think we're done adding co-ops to our collection for a good while.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

świetna polska gra.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Dripping with theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
心得:
除了食人島之外都破了
基本上不太會管分數，主要還是想要完成章節
但是抽牌跟擲骰的遊戲，運氣真的很重要
特別是前幾回合，如果運氣很糟，基本上就不太可能贏了
也沒什麼讀文字，代入感遊戲對我好像也還好，主要是解困局算有趣
基本上主要是要往目標快速前進，不要做太多不相干的行動
規則:
*根據劇本設置起始板塊，回合數除二向上去整拿事件卡有書沒書的一樣數目，洗勻放在上方事件牌堆，獵物牌先放一旁，其他冒險卡放對應位置，回合標記放第一格，發明卡固定9張再隨機抽5張
*每個人拿一個玩家版血量放最高格跟兩個行動圓片，1人拿星期五+狗，花費看兩人，兩人拿星期五，四人需要放特殊行動卡取代原本的鼓舞士氣行動，抽兩張起始物品卡，任何人可使用共兩次
*遊戲進行數輪，有人死會回合結束就輸，之前達成條件就獲勝，每輪分6階段
1.事件階段 第一回合不做，之後開一張事件卡結算，有問號放問號到對應冒險卡，有書看劇情結算，結算完放到威脅行動區右邊格，原本有的往左推，推出去的結算下方效果
2.士氣階段 起始玩家根據士氣拿激勵標記或失去，不夠丟每一個扣一滴血 
3.生產階段 根據紮營的板塊拿生產的資源放到當回合可使用區
4.行動階段 全部玩家一起放行動圓片到想要的行動區，之後照順序結算
A 威脅行動 滿足事件卡上需求棄掉該卡並拿獎勵
B 打獵 有野獸卡時可放兩個圓片執行，結算翻面根據武器差值扣血，可能會扣武器等級，獲得獎勵，如果有兩人要選擇誰主動，扣他血
C 打造 放一個行動圓片到發明卡，有對應地形的要先有探索到才能發明，放兩個不用擲骰值皆成功，成功就翻面獲得上面好處，也可以造小屋/屋頂/柵欄/武器
D 採集 一個或兩個到相鄰板塊收集資源，每一格資源只能收集一次
E 探索 一個或兩個行動圓片放到相鄰的未探索區，探索更遠一格要多加一個圓片，且中間的要探索過，成功翻面，有探索板塊就拿抽，有獵物符號就放獵物卡到圖板，新地形就放方塊到對應發明卡
F 整理營地 提升士氣跟拿激勵標記
*激勵標記可啟動腳色能力，每個能力每回合只能使用一次
G休息  回一滴血
*所有獲得的資源或發明都放在當回合去上方，此回合行動階段不能使用
5.天氣階段 根據劇本或回合擲天氣骰，冬雲一個棄一個木頭，所有雲數加總扣屋頂，每個差值付一個木頭跟食物，動物骰掉食物/掉柵欄/打武力3動物，風暴掉柵欄一級，每個不夠付的資源每個人掉一滴
6夜晚階段 可移動營地到相鄰板塊(屋頂柵欄/2向上取整，如果是天然營地就全拆)，每個人花一個食物，不夠扣兩滴，沒有小屋每人扣一滴，所有正常食物棄掉，此階段可使用治療能力
**擴充**
海灘擴 在海灘探索時可改抽海灘卡
個性擴 起始腳色抽一張個性卡
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
STEPHEN.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An amazing pure co-op game that is difficult but not impossible to over come. To play RC you have to be in the mindset of a survivor, you are stranded cold, exposed, and hungry with little to no food, no shelter, and just what you could carry off the ship! No other game I feel gives you such a pure form of decision making as does RC.  You truly have to decide each turn what is the most important thing you need to accomplish this turn as there are plenty of options, but as a group your resources and workers are few. No decision is obvious, every actions is helpful(necessary) in one way or another, and every choice is a risk.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played only once. Tough game to win
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The only differentiation between characters are their unique 4 powers, similar to how in Pandemic et al you have a unique power. All of these come at a cost though so they're not done at will. But in board-based co-ops, board position hugely differentiates players. Here there's nothing else to differentiate. Which is surprisingly disappointing as it means rich pickings for the bandleader to identify the best approach during the action selection and direct traffic. The game complicates things by providing a risk mechanic which is at least diverting ... place 2 workers on a spot and get it with no risk, or place 1 worker and roll dice to see if you get a wound, if you get the action at all, and if you get a card event to manage additionally. Which brings the game thematically to life, bringing despair at ever overcoming the perils of the island. And that's the game's strong point - theme, theme, theme - plus a differing challenge each time you play a scenario based on what the many different big event decks provide you. I just wish the co-op aspect was more than pooling your workers and agreeing on a united approach.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
This is a great game.  The theme is really good and the difficulty is there to get the players talking on how to pull out the win.  I do worry about replayablity a bit, but there are more options online.

RATING: N/A

RATING: 7
"Pretty heavy pure co-op with strong theme."

What I like:
- Theme is strong throughout the game
- Highly variable setup should help replayability
- Excellent gender options for characters

What I don't like:
- Encourages play-by-committee rather than individual action
- Longer and more complex than I would prefer
- 2p requires the neutral Friday helper (not terrible, but not ideal)

My 2p learning game took about 2.5 hours, which wasn't bad, but is pretty long. Hopefully next time will go quite a bit faster.

I think the BGG-voted 3.4 weight might be just a bit too high, but there is definitely a lot going on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an excellent game for solo or cooperative play.  The best positive is the huge variety of events, tools, animals, treasures, etc, so that each game played is different, and can range from repeatedly catastrophic to really easy depending on the timing and management of some key early decisions.  My only criticism is that the variety of gameplay inevitably forces situations in which the rules have to be searched, often without success, for the appropriate resolution.   In a cooperative game, it is easy to resolve with experienced players by developing an on-the-spot consensus of a reasonable why of handling the situation. There is not enough setup for some of the scenarios such that it is sometimes time consuming to set up a scenario because you are trying to figure out how to handle certain issues in this scenario.  These problems are caused primarily because the game has so many diverse dimensions, so I would rather have the game with these issues than not have the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The problem with this game is that it feels like you are making choices and trying to work together against a real challenge.  Yes, the rules are ad hoc and written poorly; but a few game-plays will smooth everything out.  So, after figuring out how to play and losing about 35 games,I starting taking a hard look at the mechanics and structure of the game. Conclusion: there is no real choice & everything is randomly stacked against the players.  The three times I won was when dice rolls went well and random cards didn't effect the game.  The frustration mounts when you realize that the structure of the scenarios are to defeat you at the beginning and become more defeating as you play.  Basically, you loose if you do this or loose doing something else.  

What is worse, is that the game becomes immediately more difficult the more players you have.  

This game can be fun, if change several rules bringing some real choice to the game.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Robinson Crusoe is a scenario-based cooperative game that features a number of player roles.  Unlike a lot of more recent cooperative games, this game makes no attempt to obscure information or play one player off another--everything is essentially decided as a group.  While that may cause "alpha gamer" problems in some groups, I found that the decisions to be made in this game were interesting enough that it didn't really bother me.  I particularly liked the event system, where event cards are drawn because a particular action is taken, part of it happens immediately, and then the card is shuffled into the event deck so that the rest of it can happen at some undetermined time in the future.  I'm generally not a big fan of cooperative games, but I found this one to be interesting and intricate enough that I'd be willing to play it again.

(1 play)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A lot to explore here. I purchased in early 2014 for full price, and was immediately smitten by the theme, the artwork, the bits... everything is gorgeous.

The rulebook was quite difficult. There are excellent play aides that help, and some great videos from both the designer and others that I highly recommend new owners of the game check out. Once you do that, and try a solo play through or two, you can get 95% of what you need to play and enjoy the game.

My 10 year old son and I had a blast playing this - he was really excited by the story that was being told, and we had several "stand up die rolls" that were thrilling for both of us.

I've been playing games for over 30 years, including some monsters in tournaments like ASL and Star Fleet Battles - and I found this game to be very challenging to learn. But like complex those titles, this one is worth the effort.

Will it hold my interest as long as those? Not sure, but they are doing a good job releasing promos and expansions, so it could still be around in a few years. I'd love to see a space themed version of this game ("Robinson Crusoe on Mars"!).

I'd love to see this game on iOS - it would eliminate the long setup time, would enforce those dozen or so niggling little rules exceptions that come up ("does Friday's remaining health score VP?" (no)).

If you are the game buyer in your group, and your group will play coops (likes Pandemic), and you don't mind investing several hours on your own learning this game before introducing to your group, and you can live with a number of rules that you will surely get wrong your first couple of plays... This game can be highly rewarding.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I feel rather like a logistic manager of recources than an adventurer that tries to survive on an island. 
Way to many exceptional rules, make it necessary to consult constantly the rule book. (and with the german rules, they made a good job!) 
Thereby it is impossible for me to immerse into the scenario. And it stayed that way, even as i started to memorize all the fiddly unstreamlined rules after a few plays(!).

I would like to like this game very much, but for me the mechanical struggle between luck of dice rolling/card drawing and the logistic part of recource management doesn´t create a tension of survival on an island at all. The flavor text on the cards can´t distract the lack of experience on a gameplay level.

It reminded me a bit of bad old "roleplaying" experience: Untalented storyteller reads flavor text from a book - group of "adventurers" rolling dice - compare result to your character stats - win/loose.  schhrrrrrffff

In my opinion a gamedesigner who has the aim to create a storytelling game should invest more time in researching gamemechanics that emerge relevant player interaction, instead of using just illustrations and flavor text to achive that goal. Here the story tells itself. My mind is not creating it. My creativity has no relevanz on the outcome of the story.
What then to talk about? Outcome of bad dice rolls/card draws???? What is there to talk about?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
3 plays; Rating: [bgcolor=#66FF99][s][color=#66FF99]-[/color][/s][b]8[/b][s][color=#66FF99]-[/color][/s][/bgcolor]

I hate weather. And hunger. And the stupid Alligator who is terribly strong and doesn't even provide a skin. What the heck are alligator boots made of, huh???

This game is mean. And hard. In my three attempts, I've only once come close to winning the first scenario. That said, it's also really fun. I love this theme (thanks, Friday), and there are thematic elements throughout the mostly euro-influenced design. 

The game is a bit of a worker-placement number. One interesting part of the game is that a player can (usually) choose to use either a single or multiple workers to select an action. With multiple workers, the action is guaranteed to succeed. With only a single worker, a player must roll a set of custom dice and face the consequences. Thankfully, there are ways to mitigate bad rolls. 

One word of warning: the rule book is pretty atrocious. Be prepared to spend the first game or two fruitlessly searching for answers to your rules questions. The first printing of the Z-Man edition also apparently contains a major error. Seek the corrected pdf online. If you plan to teach this to your group, I'd highly recommend setting it up for a solo run-through beforehand.

RATING: 7.5
Very good coop game...once we understand and appreciate all the rules.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I get why people love this game.  It's complex, rich, and very thematic. However, I rarely want to play this. I have yet to play a game where we won and didn't think "wait, did we cheat"? There are some poorly worded cards and a number of fiddly game rules, so we always have the rulebook at hand, although we've played it a half dozen times.  This takes me out of the game and reduces my enjoyment.  Additionally, I'm more interested in building something awesome than constantly have terrible things happen to me. There is very little relief in the game. If the game play was smoother, I might be more inclined to enjoy the beating.  My partner likes it a lot though.

Gave to Mark.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Older brown box version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Robinson Crusoe is a very thematic cooperative (puzzle) game that is much harder than it appears. Unless you enjoy pain, start with the Dog and Friday no matter the player count. I was surprised at how smooth the game play was once the rules were learned properly. My main concern is that despite the different scenarios the game is going to have an optimal way to play each scenario that will eventually feel very scripted reducing replayability. Due to the game being brutally difficult it will be almost impossible to win any scenario doing anything outside of a scenario's optimal strategy. This will reduce or eliminate any possible "fun" in the game to everyone following the orders of the most experienced player and thus the big problem with co-op (puzzle) games is exposed.

Pros:
* Excellent artwork and graphic design.
* High quality game components.
* Very thematic game play.

Cons:
* Co-operative "games" are really just puzzles.
* Excessive shuffling of the event deck.
* Ridiculously hard.
* The most experience player is likely to tell everyone what to do.
* There are still rule conflicts...

1. Rule book page 13: "[i]All tokens in Action spaces ...are discarded after applying their effect.[/i]" and on the same page: "[i]If the token is on any of the Action spaces for the Shelter, Roof, Palisade, or Weapons [...] The token is not discarded when these spaces are used.[/i]"

3. Soldier card says: "[i]Discard 2 Determination tokens to increase the Palisade or Weapon level by 1.[/i]" and in the rule book on page 34: "[i]Discard 3 Determination tokens to increase the Palisade or Weapon level by 1.[/i]"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really good solo or at 2 players, I don't personally like it with more as it gets a bit AP prone. I'm not convinced how likely it is to win because you make clever decision v how likely the game setup makes it for you to win, and I'd be tempted to say that the game plays itself for the most part. But the narrative, and the sense of the board and decks as this maleficent goblin trying to get under your skin by throwing crap at you, definitely work, and out of the puzzley games this is my favorite by far.

Downgraded to 7, as with more plays it started feeling like the deck happens to you, more or less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I've now tried several times to play this on several different occasions and each game is an exercise in extreme frustration.  At first I thought it was enjoyable and we were experiencing rotten luck in our games, but after the last few sessions, I am pretty convinced everything has to go right for a win: favorable map layouts, 1-action events, and most of all, no bad rolls (which is next to impossible).  I am tired of playing the base game and will likely give this one more go on the Beagle expansion, but I expect the results will be much the same.  Going to the DMV is often more enjoyable than this game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When you play a game of Ignacy Trzewiczek there seems to be 2 certitudes: 1) you'll get a rulebook that will give you a headache with lots of little rules here and there and without any player aid to help you. 2) Lots and lots of different symbols, but I must admit that in this game they seem to be logic.

When I'm writing this (16/08/2013), Robinson Crusoe has an average rating of 8.08 and is number 2 in the BGG-hotness. And just like with 'Legends of Andor', I'm wondering, 'Why'? 
This is mainly a game where you have to turn over cards and tokens and undergo what is written on the card/token. 
It's not bad as a co-operative game, but I guess I'm sort of fed-up with co-operative play. They are almost more of the same. If you own Pandemic, Yggdrasil and Defenders of the Realm, you can consider that you'll have all co-operative games you need (and if you want something semi - co-operative, get Shadows over Camelot).

RATING: 9.5
Great theme, great artwork, great coop game. Does all it can to get you into the theme, but it also depends on how much players are willing to immerse. Rules can be a bit scary for new gamers, but I wouldn't call them old school. Modern game, lots of variety, love the different scenarios. The game is made so well that you forget that it's essentially a worker placement. My girlfriend was fooled by it so she likes it and asks to play it. A really fun experience, especially if more experienced players don't take over the game. Good that you can also customise difficulty pretty well. LOVE the artwork on the beast cards! Long time since I found such a truly epic game.

RATING: 9.1
+Outstanding Theme. Scenarios, characters, card decks adds endless variety. Cooperative adventure great for groups where competitiveness can sour an evening. There is usually always discussion about how a handful of decisions could have altered the outcome. Sometimes the game wins, but that usually leads to wanting to play again soon. Players can tweak with difficulty.

=Some luck outcomes, but they usually range from not noticeable to adding flavor. Easy to learn, but benefits greatly from having an experienced player in the mix 

-Can seem like multiplayer solitaire 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a game where you start off in a bad place, and everything you do that helps your current situation makes your life worse later when the encounter you had comes back up through the event deck. It's incredibly fun when your choices come back to bite you. I've never been so on the edge of my seat when playing a co-op game.

The only thing that would make this game better is if you weren't supposed to read the eventual potential consequences of the cards, but the game would need a companion app to accomplish that.

:nostar: Art, Iconography and components functional
:star: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:star: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Raw enjoyment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brilliant.  A whole hell of a lot of game jammed into one box.  The hopelessness, the brutal reality of island life, the beauty of the board...these things merge into what can only be described as board gaming excellence.  Loses .5 only because I hate little cards.  They annoy me, and there's a lot of them in the box.  

Updated: Playgroup finally agreed to try it out.  They felt it was around an 8.0, meaning they enjoyed it less than I do, but they did like it better than the average type of things I hoist on them when I get to pick.  Still one of my favorites, but I'm dropping it .5.  It's a bit more fiddly than I remember, but a very good game nonetheless.  Feel like it could use a rulebook update to streamline the process of teaching and setting up.

RATING: 7.8

Strengths:

- favorite theme
- nice artwork
- lots of different things to focus on (exploring, gathering food, shelter, and my favorite, building items)
- nice story elements and interesting scenarios

Weaknesses: 

- very luck driven
- fiddly
- doesn't always feel like a true co-op (you have a pool of actions with limited options)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Playing in easy mode (with both Friday and the dog) in a two player game, the final weather dice roll would either kill us, or leave us alive to win, and we got lucky and pulled it off, in part due to a nearly endless string of good luck. ON EASY MODE. Fun, and a game of constant cooperation to try and succeed. While the main title of the game is 'Robinson Crusoe', and the first scenario is in essence the basic premise of the titular book, the other scenarios only share in common the gameplay and the island stranding, with scenarios ranging from a volcano, to cannibal tribes, to what is in essence the plot of the film 'The Fog'.

The setup and length though are a little offputting, as with most games that have the sorts of variable setups and huge numbers of different cards and decks that have different setups.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Very nice cooperative game, that feels very consistent and logical. There's a lot of effort to wrap both the theme and the gameplay together and join them in one package. I like the elegance of certain game mechanics and the thrill of learning about new threats and ways of overcoming them. I like that it mixes cards, worker placement and dice. There's never enough resources and you have to decide where to stretch thin. The ruleset is intimidating, but once you digest it, it feels very natural and easy to remember. Not sure about foreign editions, but 3rd print of PL (original) one comes with quite well organized manual and learning the game isn't that problematic. Some people say that there's just too many rules to remember - I cannot really agree with that. It's very smooth and you get the player/round reference sheet that is a great aid during the game.

There's a lot of diversity provided by plethora of different cards, exploration, animals, scenarios - good replayability. Each time it feel's more like an adventure as opposed to "us vs the board". I'm not sure how it tackles with the "leader" effect. Leader can still very well dictate the worker placement for all players. Leader will check dice face distribution, or will perform calculations from gained vs spent. Yes, he cannot lead a straight way to win, as the situation changes constantly, but he will definitely be in position to get the best out of the board in current round. But it's true, that the game encourages tactic discussion a lot, way more than other coops I've played.

You still can be screwed up pretty badly by bad card draw or dice roll. The game is hard, and it's unlikely that you win in any of first few plays. But it presents a cool challenge you actually want to accept.

RATING: 10
An amazing game, never played a game that delivers theme and narrative as well as this one does. Choices mean something in Robinson and they come back to get you and I mean in terms of narrative not just mechanically. Incredibly well designed and illustrated. After learning the rules the game play is smooth and intuitive without sprawl of clutter that other games fall foul of. For me this stands out in my collection as being something quite special and different.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Thematically one of the best cooperative game I've played. I'm still not the biggest fan of coops, but this one is certainly entertaining. It's random to a degree, yes, but most of the time it gives a great illusion of being in control of things.

I don't think it solves the alpha player syndrome as it promised, but not everything can be counted and there are enough meaningful decisions to make that there shouldn't be a single best strategy to win. At the same time, it's very thematic and you're often tempted to do things not because they're the best solutions to a given problem, but because they feel right. So we're cold on an uninhabited island, so we need to make a shelter, maybe some tools and we'll see where we go from there. 

I think it deserves all the accolades it's been given and while there are many other games I prefer to play, this one gets a high note because it's simply amazing in its genre. Still, be aware it has its issues - mainly horrible, horrible rules bloat!

EDIT: After expansion play, I'm not the biggest fan of the direction the designer has taken. Adding complexity to an already complex and fiddly game is a recipe for disaster (at least for me). Had fun while it lasted, but after twenty plays the costs (setup, amount of small rules to remember) outweight the benefits. But I still believe this is THE game for fans of strong theme and cooperation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
We need more cooperative games like this one.
Robinson Crusoe is my current 2nd favourite game and is literally a gem. Why? It makes me dive in a different world, i feel myself in a movie or a book, I am led, but not played by the game. My own decisions have much impact on what can happen next and that's rare. 
Unfortunately I have no partner with whom I can play all day, game sessions need to wait until weekend. So, I often need to play alone and Robinson Crusoe makes me forget it. No other solo game gives me more fun. 
Thank you for this game!
- purchased Spiel13

*solo-experience: 10/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An extremely challenging and thematic cooperative game that has only gotten better the more I play. Players can choose from one of four roles and play through one of the many scenarios included with the game. Dice and other components are of good quality and the art is gorgeous. The game does a good job of storytelling as your party attempts to complete their objective. Are you trying to get rescued? Settle down? Save another survivor? There is a lot of replayability and each experience offers something new, even if it is the same scenario.

It does take a long time to play and it is not likely you will win which makes sense, given the premise that the game is taking place in. But this can make the game a bit draining as you need to weather all of the negatives that this game and Murphy's Law throws at you. The rulebook can also add length due to having a few confusing parts and everything that happens with each phase. But after a few plays things do click and every decision makes more sense as you gain clarity on the goals and how to get there. One of the best cooperative games and one of my favorites overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A nearly perfect game. Perhaps the best thing about Robinson Crusoe is it's ability to put you into so many different settings and still keep the theme intact. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have mixed feelings about this game. It got a lot of hype when it came out and I really enjoyed the first few plays of it. It has a great theme and has tons of replay ability. The negatives for me include the rule book and the components. With the rules, I often find myself wondering if I'm playing correctly. With the components, I understand this is a euro co-op, but I would get so much more out of the game if it had more than just cubes to represent the different resources in the game, especially since the list price for this game is pretty high. 
I like the complexity of this game, but unfortunately because of that it's no where close to the gateway category. Players in my game group don't even mention wanting to play this during a game night. If I want to play a co-op game, I'd personally rather play Pandemic or Forbidden Desert. Despite all this, I still feel like keeping this game in my collection. I really wish I knew why that is.

Essen Spiel 17
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Very fiddly coop, which does not offer a better experience than more streamlined coops as Pandemic or Lord of the Rings. The main mechanic is worker placement and this games feels very Euro, since you gather ressources to build things and gather food to maintain feed your people. I am no fan of much card text and there is a lot of that on the event cards. There are just to many things "active" (events, scenario conditions, traps) to keep a good overview. Still it seemed rather bloated instead of deep.

I have to deduct a whole point for the really badly written rules (German version). For example, an event card tells you to put a certain counter on the hunting deck and you go through all rules for hunting, you do not find the effect of the counter. This is somewhere else, in which all counters are discussed. At the end of the rules, there is a list of all symbols. But it is pretty much only their names, not their meanings! Those rules probably cost us a complete hour of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
First, this rule book is just horrible.  The components list is just about useless and trying to figure out what everything is was half the battle.  It was so horrible I almost just put it away without playing so this game takes an initial knock for that.  The quality of the cards are terrible as they are very thin and many have marks on them.  These cards will show wear further marking them since there is a ton of shuffling with the event deck.   

After, one game and trying to get past my frustration of the rules, it was a pretty good game. There is an interesting mix of long term strategy and tactical decision as events are thrown at you with a little resource management.  Choosing an initial strategy seems crucial because the game seems very tight with what you can get accomplished.  I wish it felt a little more thematic or had a little more of a storytelling feel.  Sometimes is feels a little too mechanical or euro-y which for me seemed to reduce the fun factor a bit.  This will need more plays as the other scenario goals are drastically different. The game seems to have a ton of replay-ability.  

I haven't decided if I like this game or the similar themed game Castaways more however, my initial feeling is for the latter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Co-operative games are hard to pull off. The best are elegantly simple so that players can quickly assimilate the rules in order to focus on solving the problem the game presents together. The worst (Arkham Horror, Ghost Stories) are a bloated mess of dice rolls and fiddly rules. 
Robinson Crusoe falls somewhere in the middle. The players who had played previously were still forgetting rules and there was far too much stuff. On the other hand you could see what was going on and build a plan, and dice rolls are a choice rather than forced on you. I would certainly play again but this would appeal far more to a fan of Mice and Mystics than to someone who likes Pandemic or Hannabi.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
One of the better co-op games to come out this year (2013).
With the various scenarios providing lots of replay ability.
If you want a step-up from gateway co-op games and really like difficult, complex and thematic games then you get your money's worth from this.

dice tower secret trait cards - despair, a secret from the past, useful findings, faith, ostensible strength, hope for escape, illness, insecurity, dizziness

RATING: N/A
sold
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I am really not a fan of co-operative games - almost all such games that I have ever played have left me cold. But I really enjoy this game - it does actually feel like an adventure, with lots of variability in the different scenarios and many different cards you can draw in each one. And I love the mechanic of adventure cards getting shuffled into the event deck - things that happen one day, and decisions you make, will come back to haunt you at an unknown later date.

I've only played the first 4 scenarios so far, all of them with 3 players, the first 2 also with 2 and the first several more times with 4 - and the player count makes quite a big difference (generally it seems harder the more players there are, but that's not a hard and fast rule). I'd like to try scenarios 5 and 6 at some point, although this is no longer a game I want to play all the time. I do wonder if, once all scenarios have been played and won a few times, it starts to get boring (but then my wife did get the expansion for Christmas 2014, albeit I've been less excited about the game since then and we've so far only played the first scenario of the expansion). It's a very fun game that I'll almost never turn down the chance to play.

Não curto jogo colaborativo, então já entrei sabendo que um colaborativo hiper complexo não seria pra mim. De fato o jogo tem um tema muito bem implementado, mas a regra é tão cheia de pormenores que tem que parar pra ver manual o jogo todo, e acabe quebrando demais o ritmo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
(+) Nice artwork, nice components
(+) Theme fits the game really well: you really feel like stranded on an abandoned island. The game doesn't really feel like a puzzle, thanks to the well thought out mechanisms and the fitting theme, the game plays out rather intuitively - but good thinking is certainly required.
(+) Different scenarios, event cards and available technologies will probably result in a big variation in game play which should ensure the game will remain interesting for a long time
(+) I kind of like the mechanism in which the ?-cards related to the actions of building, collecting or exploring sometimes can result in immediate effects but also in 'posponed' effects when they are shuffeled again in the event card deck. The different characters you can play with and the way they influence the game when they get wounded are also pretty well thought through


(-) As with all cooperative games, also this game is rather luck dependant: the cards which are drawn or the different dice which are rolled will make or break your chances of victory. Playing the game well is necessary in order to have a chance of winning, but will certainly not ensure victory. Bad dice rolls or a catastrophic card draw can feel pretty unfair.
(-) The different scenarios are nice, but they result in a number of tiny specific game rules and exceptions. The game rules may be somewhat overwhelming for some players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Tenía ganas de que me gustase por la temática, el diseño y las mecánicas, pero conforme he ido jugando (hasta 10 partidas tanto en solitario como a dos jugadores) y avanzando en las misiones (he llegado hasta la cuarta) me ha ido decepcionando cada vez más. En la primera misión pasa desapercibido, pero en las siguientes te vas dando cuenta de que  el componente azar es demasiado elevado. Hay azar antes, durante y después de que el jugador realice sus acciones, lo que hace que las decisiones no sean tan importantes y que todo dependa de la suerte que uno tenga. De las 6 fases que tiene una ronda, solo en una de ellas el jugador toma decisiones, el resto consiste en mover fichas de un sitio a otro y esperar a ver qué te depara la suerte. Todo esto no sería un problema  si temáticamente fuera bueno, pero tampoco lo es especialmente. Al margen del tema de cada misión, se limita a levantar cartas que te dicen que hay una tormenta o que te ataca un animal (supongo que en una isla desierta tampoco  te puede pasar mucho más). Por último, uno de los errores que me parecen más graves en cualquier juego: las reglas tienen lagunas y son bastante mejorables, me da la impresión de que no se han analizado  las consecuencias que tienen las reglas especiales de cada misión y de algunas cartas de eventos. La idea detrás del juego me parece muy buena pero la ejecución no tanto, una lástima.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Donald owns
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating based on one three-player game at BGG.CON 2012.

This rating feels pretty tentative to me...further play is sure to drive it up a half a point or a point, or down a point or two.  This felt like a pretty good cooperative game, with different players' powers potentially suiting them better to certain actions than others.  In practice, though, this was closer than I prefer to the standard "multiplayer puzzle" end of the coop spectrum, where group discussion pretty much decides what each person should do.  Perhaps because the assumption is that the best moves are fairly easily calculable and that they'll be made by committee, these games almost always seem to to be set up to be only barely winnable.  I think if there was more chance of miscommunication or poor coordination among much more independently acting players, they could get away with less abusively difficult feeling scenarios.

Still, this game was flavorful, reminding me of Goldland in some ways, and didn't really drag.  And the wealth of scenarios should keep it fresh for a while. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Chimera Orange (220)

RATING: 9.9
It´s a special boardgame, and which subject matter fascinates me. I love it! It´s immersive, the story is generated in your head while chasing a target in the game. Graphic design, illustrations, and the quality of the components...; EVERYTHING seems very appropiate to the theme. I wish there were more boardgames of this kind in the market, with themes based on Classical Literature, and well done like this one. It´s a pity that the rulebook is so difficult to manage: I prefer A4 size rulebooks for this kind of games, and the size of typography in some missions is very small. But above this little details, this is one of my favourites board games for sure.

- Freshness and originality: 10
- Artwork: 10
- Graphic Design: 9
- Material Quality: 10
- Mechanics: 10
- Theme: 10
- Fun: 10
- Personal Rating: 10

TOTAL = 9,9

RATING: N/A
[b]This review is based off the ZMan Games (old) version[/b]

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Challenging!  I like all the thinking and planning that goes into each turn.

- Some nice components - the board, scenario cards, player cards, tokens, and cubes are all great!

- Gameplay is very thematic (in fact, probably the most thematic game I've seen).  We really felt like we were trapped on an island trying to survive!  Each turn was a legitimate struggle.

- Some things are as random as the weather - which in this game makes sense.  But there are ways to help mitigate bad things.  You have choices and you can plan for the worst. 

- Even if you lose there is a scoring system so that you can see how many points you got toward your end-goal.

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Rulebook layout is awful for reference!  To brush up on how to properly do a single action, I had to read several different (and often unrelated) sections on different pages to get all the info I needed.  Ultimately, I had to download 2 BGG-user-created references, read the forums, and watch a reviewer video in order to figure out how to play correctly.

- No full components list.  Really hard to tell if I had all the pieces.  Ended up having to use a BGG-user-generated document to check.

- HARD!  We rarely ever win and every turn is kinda depressing with all the bad things that happen each round.  If you hate losing constantly or you get easily frustrated/down, this game is probably not for you!

- Crappy finish on the cards in my copy.  In my copy the ink was already wearing off the edges of the cards while they were still INSIDE the wrapping. Also, several of the cards had bubbling on the surface of the cards.  Since I sleeve, neither of these became too big of an issue, but if you don't normally sleeve you may need to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only played one player and had a good time with it using the Castaways scenario. I would definitely like to do a 3+ player play through as I think it would be a much better experience. My knock here is that it's rather daunting to really understand how gameplay and setup works. I probably spent around 2 hours total watching videos on gameplay. Highly recommend the walkthrough posted on this site by another user. Overall though, a very satisfying experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Finally Played this game! In Robinson Crusoe players play a group of people Stranded on a deserted island trying to survive. Players collectively must make decisions on how to survive through  6 different scenarios included in the game. Players  in the end  try to help each other survive through many hardships thrown at them. This Cooperative game adds a challenge to all players and plays up to 4 Players.

Pros: Beautiful components and artwork, group participation, Challenging Scenarios, Multiple Scenarios for variety of gameplay, Challenging decisions.

Cons: Rules heavy gameplay with no clear flow, Extremely Difficult to win, Luck based outcomes, Confusing rules definitions, Extremely heavy decisions and gameplay, Can open up problems with overpowering decision makers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It has plenty of replay, and has been so fun playing through the various scenarios.  Loving it - one of my most played games in 2014 in terms of time spent playing, if not in actual plays.

RATING: 6.8
For me, it's mostly a great solo game (when i found time to play solo which is rare).
The difficulty is not based on a complex puzzle to solve (like in Pandemic) but more on a learning curve. Once you have beaten a scenario, you know how to solve it and mostly (lack of) luck can make you lose / win. 
For this reason, i think it doesn't work well in a group if someone knows the game (or even worse the scenario) and other don't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Robinson Crusoe sets a new standard for cooperative game design, and for that matter narrative game design. The coolest thing is that it pulls it off with worker placement and a pile of other Euro mechanics. Of course a game about survivors on a desert island would be about sending people to perform different tasks, and of course it would have to be cooperative. I'm especially impressed with how the game handles scenarios. The different contextual elements do a ton of heavy thematic lifting, making each scenario feel unique and thrilling. And I'm also a big fan of the way it manages the actual process of placing workers. You just discuss it, and put them out there. No unnecessary process, no fuss. And it's an outstanding solo game too. A terrific game, and one of the best of 2012-2013.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Kind of let down by this one. Amazing integration of theme, possibly the best I've seen, but I really felt like the gameplay fell flat. There's not really much to do each turn, and while I felt the struggle to survive, it wasn't really fun to try.

RATING: 9.5
Amazing cooperative game with a super strong theme.  You simply feel you are on the island.  Hard to win the game but i´ve never enjoyed losing a game so much. Once you win however, it gives this WOOOOAAAAHHHH factor which is missing in most games. 

There is dice which add some luck factor, but again, you can decide not to use them so eliminate luck.  

Decisions you take during the game may affect you later on and this is a very neat mechanic.  

Also excellent one-player game.  Fantastic game.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
Very well done for what it is and it doesn't overstay its welcome.  

It keeps pressure fairly high the entire game unlike some other  coops I've played and you feel both the desperation and hope of living on the island.  I can say exactly what I need...but will we find the right tile?  Will we make the roll if we risk it with just 1 pawn?  You aren't always certain...and I like that.  There's just enough mitigation built in so you don't feel like it just a dice fest though.

The only knock on this one is that there are lots of little fiddly rules to teach new folks. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is tough and I was really struggling to win the first scenario (I won 1 out of my first 7 tries) until I read about some strategies and then won two in a row.

The game can be extremely brutal and depressing as it throws problem after problem at you.  That said, I really love the theme and the game tells a great story win or lose.

I originally thought the playtime was really long but my solo games are under 2 hours now that I know the mechanics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A good, but slightly overrated co-op.
Difficult to master (good!), but sadly also very difficult to learn in the first place (bad!).
It's not enjoyable to bring this to your family or friends you just sometimes play with.
Has some other flaws, like the fact that the most important part of the board - the actual island you are on - makes up less than 10% of the space of the game, whereas a rather small part such as the tools you can build/invent makes up three times that space. That's simply not immersive (which this game strives to be).

Many other things are immersive enough though, just a little bit of role playing makes this game significantly more enjoyable.

Works well with only 1 player aswell.

tl;dr: Buy if you and/or the group you play with like to dive really deep into games, don't mind if the first 1-2 games are more to learn the game than to enjoy it, and like a really tough challenge.

Don't buy if you 1) hate losing, 2) hate co-op games, 3) have problems with complex rules, 4) search for a game to bring to your gaming group and start enjoying right from the get go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This is a little better than Arkham Horror, which is all I can say for a shared RPG narrative experience. Theme, like in Mage Knight Board Game, is reduced to an accountant's wet dream. No attempt to solve dominant-leader syndrome at all, just ignoring it through complexity and theme.

Another Euro in thematic clothing. I hate how games like this purport to have theme but really douse out all the drama with too many too-cute details.

Having events come back to hurt you is nice, but why can't the cards have the same backs??

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First things first - this game would probably get an initial score of 8 from me if the damn rulebook was written in clear English.  I have a big bone to pick with Portal/Ignacy about their rulesets.  Find someone who speaks Polish and can translate into clear coherent English and has a tiny amount of vision when it comes to designing a rulebook!

Rant over - Once we muddled through the rules and a couple of turns, this turned out to be pretty fun.  It's one of those games where misfortune and pain are in abundance.  I like the way morale factors in and is incorporated into the wounds as well.  You're building shelter, gathering resources and trying to survive.  I also like how you can try to do more actions, but risk dice rolls or do fewer actions, but there is less risk.  I'll definitely play this again and I may buy it, but it definitely needs a Universal Head-caliber game aid as the rules are poorly implemented as can be seen by the TWENTY page FAQ.  The rules are only 20 pages for crying out loud!!

Fortunately, the Z-Man edition of this made the rules a lot more tolerable.  The 67 page FAQ is almost a requirement to have up and ready to reference a question, but considering how wonderfully thematic this game is, it's worth the effort.  When played with the right people too, there will be high fives and genuine excitement.  Cannot recommend it enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Love the game.  I've only played twice..lost both times, but had a great time trying to survive the island.  I really like the co-operative mechanics of the game. The stress this game invokes is something I enjoy in a game. Do I put all my tokens on one task or do I go risky and try to attempt two tasks with the possibility of not being successful and getting injured.  The stress level increases the closer you are to achieving your goals.  Did I make the right choice... aahhh.  Learning what to do or what not to do the next time I play.  My only gripe about the game are the rules.  Some of the rules are a little vague, which left me to have to come to BGG for clarification.  Although, with most games, rules are subject to interpretation by the reader.

RATING: 7
#100 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

I feel like I should like this game even more than I do, given that is a co-op with some Euro feel to it. I think what keeps this one from being higher on the list is its complexity- it's almost too much. Still though, this is such a solid game. The theme shines through really well. I love that there are many different scenarios, and each has felt pretty different. We have completed the first five- I believe there are 12 in the base game, and then we have the Beagle expansion to play as well. Plenty of game left before we'd even need to replay anything!

RATING: 7
The game is incredibly thematic and beautiful to see on the table, and we love having a cooperative game that can be punishingly difficult from time to time. The worker placement is fun, and so is trying to balance the puzzle of what you most need in order to survive. Our only complaints would be that it is just massive and has so many moving parts that it is difficult to get to the table sometimes, and that you can get super unlucky with Event cards or dice rolls (even if you mitigate them as much as possible) which can sometimes make it seem like the odds were so stacked against you that it was legitimately impossible to win the scenario. All that together does make the rare game that we win all the more satisfying.

C50
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Antons
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Robinson Crusoe is one of the first cooperative games I bought and still one of my favorite games in this category. Every single game, no matter whether we lost or won, was a lot of fun. The replayability is incredibly high and the value for money one gets with the box is just incredible.

The only downside is the manual: Robinson Crusoe is a somewhat complex game and it‘s understandable that the manual is as thick as it is, but even then it could have been better. Information that should be placed side-by-side is separated and there is no alphabetical index as well as no table of context. Looking for a specific piece of information? A specific rule? Well, go ahead and browse the whole 38-page-monstrosity. As elegant, polished and fun as the game is: The manual is just as much hard-to-use. Don’t get me wrong: The actual explanations are fine … they just aren’t very well organized.
However: Once you’ve gotten a hang of it the game plays fluidly and you’ll have little reason to actually open the manual at all after two or three games, which is why the manual doesn’t really affect my rating. New players should still be aware of it and ready to invest some time before abd during their first playthrough … much more than would have been necessary with a better manual.

After all that negativity allow me to repeat what I wrote before: IMHO it’s one of the best cooperative games out there!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has a really steep and specific learning curve but once you get through the headache of learning this game, it's super fun. It plays out more like a story than a board game. Everything you do thematically makes sense, and the game makes you feel like you're on a stranded island fighting for your life. There are a lot of cards that provide stories for exploring, building and gathering goods. Just invest the time it takes to read and understand the rule book. Once you get through that hurdle, the game will give you a bunch of scenarios and stories to experience. This is by far my favorite co-op game I own. Pandemic and forbidden desert are the other co-op games I own and Robinson Crusoe is leagues beyond those two. Theres this feeling that even after the game's finished, you just think about the stories you've created with your friends on the island.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Fantastyczna gra, polecam wszystkim maniakom gier planszowych :)Wydanie na wysokim poziomie, trochę zasady zagmatwane ale idzie ogarnąć. Ogromne gratulacje dla całego zespołu i samego autora.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have a love/hate relation with this game. On one hand it offers an amazing immersive experience trough the different scenarios and event cards, You really feel like you are on a cursed island and sometimes it's hard just trying to survive, but when you manage to beat the scenario you feel like you deserved it. For every game that I've played there are a couple of memorable moments, so it is one of this games that generate  stories.

On the other hand there are a lot of rules and sometimes they can even be confusing. Each scenario comes with it's own rule set and usually contradict the "normal" rules. This can also can happen with some kind of events or other bonuses. All this can force you to spend a lot of time reading the rule book or just house rule them.

Maybe without all these complicated rules and flexibility, it wouldn't be possible to offer such an amazing experience, so I still love the game and would recommend to anybody looking for a nice thematic cooperative experience.

RATING: 7.98
Nice production, particularly the game board. Perfect mix of luck, determinism, and player agency for an adventure game. Each game is a challenge, though our win rate has climbed with experience. Theme and mechanisms very well integrated (e.g., exploration / tile placement). Only reason we don't play it more is the length and complex set up. Great fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I watched Ricky Royal's playing of this series and enjoyed the mechanics involved. So, I've added this game because it hits all the right spots. There are plenty of choices to make, deciding on what is more important, gathering, hunting, or building - and all of the sub-choices within. Of special note the flavor of the design, from map items to art really captures that stranded feel, and while the game is easy to catch on to, even after multiple playthroughs, it can still cause you to shiver and clutch your soccer ball closer in the temporary shelter. I'll certainly look to add the expansion at some point. Really a classic game!

A regény alapján készült kooperatív játékban különböző foglalkozású karakterek bőrébe bújunk. Felfedezünk, gyűjtögetünk, vadászunk, kríziseket oldunk meg és közben az időjárás is megkeseríti az életünket. Nagyon sok mindent belegyúrtak a játékba, hogy igazán változatos legyen. Sok kártya, sok lehetőség, sok körülmény. Talán kicsit több is, mint kellett volna. A tematika végülis eléggé átjön. Egy-egy új terület felfedezésével új állatok bukkannak fel, új eszközöket tudunk elkészíteni. Érdekes, hogy többfajta szkenárió van a játékban. Összességében tetszett a RCAOTCI, de nem éri el nálam a BSG és Pandemic szintjét.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
How is this dominating the "Thematic" list on BGG rankings? This felt more like cooperative Stone Age than something comparable to most of the other games in that list when it comes to creating atmosphere. Could be wrong about this, maybe it's just impossible for me to get into because I find it hard to connect with cooperative games in the first place. But then again, I feel like Pandemic has more atmosphere without trying so hard.

I especially don't often enjoy cooperative games that are basically secretly single player games (where the strongest player literally has no need for his teammates), and this game does nothing to try not to be that or to change my mind. 

Also, maybe different scenarios are super different, but in the scenario I played, instead of Pandemic style coop where things get super tense super fast because you can die in an instant, this game felt like more of a slow burn, as it tried to be an epic. For someone like me who does not enjoy cooperative gameplay much, this just drags the game out and makes it less exciting than it already is.

[b]I'd Rather Play:[/b] Pandemic if I really wanted to play a cooperative like this. Battlestar Galactica if I wanted a game that uses teamwork much better as you try and deal with crisises and creates a much, much, stronger "narrative"

Remember, this is all coming from someone who already does not like cooperative games. if you are in that club as well, I wouldn't expect this to change your mind.

(4 Design + 1 Enjoyment)

RATING: 5.75
this game surprised me.  I thought i loved thematic games - i thought that was perhaps the most important criteria - and this one is really stuffed with it.  I was so sure i would love this game that I bought every expansion out at that time. 

But this one has very few decisions to make, each scenario has a best way to go about it, quickly discovered.  While it tells a good story, since I feel just along for the ride, after I play this solo, i can't help but think, "I'd rather have read a book."  

My son, who is the only other person i would play with this, didn't like it much either, and it wasn't that fun for us to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island is one of the most engaging games I've ever played. Despite the somewhat abstract nature of the mechanisms, the game does a fantastic job of allowing players to feel like they are on a deserted island, trying to build shelter, find food, and with a bit of luck, escape. Each scenario uses the core mechanisms to different effect, creating a totally unique experience and allowing for virtually unlimited expansion content. The rules can be a bit cumbersome to work though, but this game tells a story as well as any book or movie.

RATING: 5
If this was the only game I had, I'd like it a lot more. Unfortunately, I had the advantage of playing Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy and Eldritch Horror before this game. And both games execute Robinson Crusoe's mechanics better. Robinson Crusoe's encounter cards don't go far enough in terms of theme, but my biggest gripe with it is the lack of character identities and stories. They don't even have names! The scenarios can try to fill in the blanks all they want, but that doesn't change the fact that I can't see these characters as anything other than pawns.

And that's what makes this a ten in my opinion. The game drew us right in, it was intense and the theme was well-realized. Excellent game!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a very nice cooperative game.  Many cooperative games can start to feel redundant no matter how good they are.  Even with a lot of variable content the game is usually played out the same way and you can start to lose interest.  Not this guy.

A lot of the usual cooperative game tropes are here.  Each player gets a unique role with special abilities at the start of the game, gameplay is carried out with action points to accomplish tasks each turn, and the game bites back by drawing from an event deck at the end of each turn.

Where this game starts to break from the pack though is in the challenges players are actually wrestling with.  Each game can be played against different scenarios such as rescuing a stranded companion, collecting resources, or escaping an erupting volcano.  And unlike games like Mansions of Madness or Legends of Andor, once you've played through a scenario I don't think this game would start to get stale playing the same scenario multiple times.  The scenarios really just make up a framework of tasks for the players to accomplish while the gameplay itself is still varied and tense.

This game is hard!  Perhaps the most difficult coop I've played to date.  There is a lot of micromanagement because players are almost always on a clock, but you still need to build shelter and cover to protect yourself from the elements, feed yourself each turn, construct weapons to hunt so feeding yourself is possible, and all while performing the tasks necessary to actually win the game.  The tension is very real, I start to feel the hopelessness of these characters stuck on the island trying to survive but for some reason it always felt fun and never frustrating.

The game also has decently good production.  Nothing that is going to blow anyone away but everything is pretty and nothing felt cheap.

This may have just become my favorite cooperative game.  Unfortunately it is already out of print just a few months after it's release in North America and owners of copies for sale are price-gouging people for 2-3 times the retail cost.  Of course I hold out hope that having sold out as fast as it did Z-Man has no choice but to reprint it in the near future.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
9 dla gry.
10 dla kooperacyjnej gry. (IDZIE DO TOP 10?) :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolutely excellent. It's a pleasure to play it, there are enough cards to assure replayability, the quality of the design is excellent (maybe the pawns could be better).

Beware of the length of the game: with 4 players (where 2 didn't know the game, and I was doing the "master of the game") it took 3h30 to play, and we didn't reach the end because everyone was so tired.
The game is so difficult that it can be frustrating: with new players, I suggest to play rightaway with the additional support (Friday and the dog) and the starting objects. The point is to have fun: the players shouldn't have the feeling they are so far from the winning that they don't want to play until the end.

With 2 players, it's excellent: you can take the time to think, and also be less frustrated to lose, because you can think of diverse strategies, discuss more easily than with 4 players. It's my point of view.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very thematic game. It feels like a worker placement game, the players have to decide if they want to focus on the stuff they are doing (placing 2 'workers' on it), or if they want to attempt to do more in one round (placing only 1 worker on some places). Everywhere where players push their luck with only one worker dice decide if the task is successfull and/or if it brings any additional problems (wounds or an event connected to the task the player was doing (gathering, building or exploring)).

Events can sometimes be shuffled into the deck for daily events (simulating delayed consequences from an earlier adventure), occasinally it even depends on what the player did when he had a choise on the event card (e.g. if you find some strange berries while gathering you have the option to eat them for a small benefit, but the card will get shuffled into daily events and will ocme up later with something bad, if you don't touch them they also don't get shuffled in).

While the system is a bit fiddly it can generate really interesting stories.

The game comes with a lot of differente scenarios giving tons of replayability
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.6
Highly collaborative co-op game that doesn't feel like you're solving a math problem and is complex and varied enough to where quarterbacking isn't really a problem.

One of the most thematic games I've ever played. Because of that though, there are a ton of rules, but they are all very intuitive. For rules ambiguities, I was usually able to guess the correct rule just by asking myself "If I were in this situation in real life, what would happen/what would I do?

Bit of a brain burner but it's 100% fun brainburn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Finally decided to get this. Mostly intended for solo plays, but I'd be happy to try it co-op if someone would like to at some point.

Much to my own surprise, I managed to win the first scenario on my very first playthrough! EDIT: I know I played one rule incorrectly, using a build worker pawn (brown) for any kind of action. But I must have played more rules incorrectly, because I haven't come close to winning since.

UPDATE 1:
This is a seriously punishing game. Playing the first scenario solo, I'd be happy to even survive 12 rounds. Getting enough wood for the fire at the same time feels about as reasonable as expecting me to jump a skyscraper…

UPDATE 2:
I "kind of" managed to win a game today. I was playing solo, but used all four characters. I also added Friday and the dog. I used only Event cards with the book symbol. I also did not cover the Arrange Camp action with the card you're supposed to use when playing with four players, and I allowed myself two of the blue Wreckage cards to start, instead of the normal one. I also interpreted some rules I wasn't quite sure about to my own favour. For example, I'm not sure if you can lose the starting invention cards if you draw multiple cards that tell you to lose inventions.

Honestly, I feel this game is just way too ridiculously hard. I can't understand why they didn't ramp up the difficulty at least a little bit slower. There are 7 different scenarios in the game – you'd think they could at least make the introductory one not completely impossible to win in two or three plays without having to cheat…

I think the biggest problem is that even when I won (kind of), I had absolutely no feeling of satisfaction or success. I just felt that I was lucky, and that there really wasn't anything I could do to increase the likelihood of success, apart from finding ways to bend the rules.

I've lowered my rating of this from a 7 to a 4.

RATING: 5.5
First the bad sides : it's convoluted, fiddly, increases the coop leader problem instead of diminishing it, the board is non functional and the rules are a mess.

Still I had great fun playing this!  It's highly thematic even if it's not really Robinson Crusoe.

Do I want to play again?  Not really.  All the people I played with felt the same.  A great experience that doesn't need to be repeated.

As someone else mentioned, this is really a multiplayer solo game.  You never feel like you play your own actions and there is nothing to manage by yourself.  I never felt like my characters with 2 actions, more like one big player with 8 actions. I'd give a better rating for solo play.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
From the games I've played. I haven't played a game that is as immersive as this one. You get lost in the world that this game creates. You literally feel like you are fighting for your life. Every facet of this game is oozing with theme and realistic mechanics. It just makes sense. You go exploring by yourself? Well shoot you might just get lost and not make it back in time to protect yourself from the elements. But if you don't go by yourself or if you build a map, you mitigate the risks. Oh wait! There are otters eating your fish! If you don't kill them soon you lose a food source...This is just a small piece of the pie. There is so much you need to do but you have so little time. If you beat this game, you will just BARELY make it. I love it. People may complain about the alpha gamer complex, but this is the curse of EVERY co-op game. With that said, I think the alpha gamer complex actually spices up the role playing experience in this game. When your lives are on the line, people will not just talk civilly. There is a sense of desperation and this game brings it out so well. I only reserve to play this game with people who are truly dedicated board game fans. If Small World/Libertalia/Settlers of Catan are considered complex enough for you. Avoid this game. I would recommend Pandemic. It is a lighter cooperative game with a solid theme and also brings on the pressure. If you feel that you and a few friends want to experience something more complex and difficult then try Robinson Crusoe. You won't be disappointed. Just keep in mind that the rule book is a mess. You will need to read it carefully, and watching a playthrough on YouTube will help you immensely. Also playing a couple of 1 player games will help too. On that note this game plays excellently in 1 player mode. I enjoy having the company of Friday and a dog. Okay, I should stop before this becomes an essay. I love this game. It isn't for the faint in heart game, but for those who want to play an immersive, survival game rich in theme and challenges, I HIGHLY recommend this game.

Artwork- 10
Ease to Teach- 6
Fun- 10
Mechanics- 10
Replay Value- 10
Strategy- 10
Theme- 10

66/70= 94.3%
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Probably my favorite game to play solo. It's very difficult and has great replayability. I recommend playing at least 2 characters because the morality system (which is integral to the game mechanics) is altered in the single character rules. The big flaw is the crappy rulebook. It's not laid out well, and furthermore it doesn't cover so many things. You will be googling questions constantly for many playthroughs. It's a little fiddly but worth learning. The random events flow together well. The decisions are meaningful. The atmosphere is there. Great game.
