[EDIT] Indeed, send out the Dog with a Map. Should've figured they wouldn't succesfully map about the whole island between them (racking in Discoveries as they went)... Should give this another try and hope I don't miss any other rule. And try with a different character than the Cook, which seemed quite powered to take on the Castaways.

[EDIT] Tried it out solo once again and though it is an ok game, still not overly thrilled yet. However, it is clear I merely scratched the surface, so I hope replays will get me enthused more for this game. The final vote is still out.

[EDIT July 2014] Another solo play, this time the Carpenter at castaways. Getting more used to the flow of the game, enabling me more to focus on what needs to be done. Pretty sure I played correct this time. As I played quicker, the game felt fresh and exciting. Won Castaways comfortably by the 11th turn but RC is starting to show it's strength: getting better at replay. Upped my rating by 1 to a solid 8 with upwards potential. Getting ready to give this a chance with my gaming group (though it might be on the heavy side for them, coming from Defenders of the Realm and Pandemic). Definitely the best heavy coop out there yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Italy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Robinson Crusoe: Why it is an 8:

Great Theme: One of the thrills of this game is how clearly the theme shines throughout a play.  The rewards and costs to the different actions players can take make perfect sense in the setting. At the same time, mechanics from spending extra wood on cold nights to not knowing what animals you will find if you go out hunting seem to service the theme as much as game play.  All of this is especially delightful considering the theme is a sparsely represented genre in boardgames.  

Control over negatives: Many beneficial actions introduce risk or lead to negative consequences. If you are losing lots of food to rain, well, it is because you didn't build your roof.  If you lose a turn due to illness, well, you knew it was coming, and you still didn't spend time on the cure.  If someone dies from eating bad food, well, you decided to eat that bad food. This control over what kinds of negative events occur adds an interesting puzzle allowing players to foist challenges on their future selves for the sake of immediate gratification.

Novel cost benefit analysis: The control players have over negatives mentioned above introduces an interesting psychological game; the drive to meet the goal versus the desire to avoid negative consequences. It is possible to make the players incredibly robust, with lots of food, weapons, and shelter.  Unfortunately, the goal of any particular mission usually requires the attention and resources of the players before they achieve this robustness.  This causes players to take risks, accept negative consequences they could otherwise avoid, and abandon strategies as they become too costly.  Players must constantly assess which pending problems they can afford to address, and which ones they must let slide in favor of advancing toward the goal.

Why it isn't a 9: 
I think the decision to management ratio of this game is too skewed toward the management.  This can make the game feel, particularly when tired, like moving a lot of bits around and following steps.  This isn't always the case, and there are tough decisions to be had, but they don't always take as long as running the game mechanisms that are triggered by those decisions.

Why it wouldn't be a 10 if it were a 9:
Group think:  The differences between players is very minor.  After accumulating a particular resource, which is non-transferable between characters, players unlock their special abilities.  Outside of having these resources, there is little reason to draw a distinction between players or between their characters.  On the first turn, there is no 'role' to fill.  Everyone can explore, get food, or build.  This leads to a situation where we enumerate the problems, and then we may as well mix up who does what.  This isn't always the case, but it is enough  for me to count against it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Why do I keep trying co-ops? Because I'm still hoping to find one I really like. And this one had a ton of hype. And it's supposedly [listitem=2360681]the 7th best game to come out of last year's Essen[/listitem].
I was a bit put off by the amount of setup the game required and the amount of rules, but once that was over I was ready to try this one.
OK, so the scenario we played wasn't all that challenging, but it did show us some of what the game has on offer. 
There was quite a bit of random if-this-happens-than-flip-a-card or if-that-happens-flip-a-card-from-a-different-pile. Lots of random stuff getting flipped and triggering stuff. And as in most co-ops you team up to tackle the most pressing problems the game throws at you. It all felt quite been-there-done-that to me. It was all put together quite well but it didn't feel refreshing or new to me.
I might not be able to fully judge from this first play, but it seems to me [thing=30549][/thing] offers the same amount of fun in less time.

Initial rating: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
Is it overlong? Yes.
Does it solve the leader problem of co-ops? No.
Is the rulebook messy and a nightmare to learn? Yes (so I'm told).
Is it Robinson Crusoe? No. There were 4 of us on the island.
Were any of the choices we had to make agonising? Yes; sort of.
Was it fun to play? It was. Of the 4 of us, 1 really liked it, I quite liked it and the other 2 both felt it ran too long for what it was.

Essentially, there is not much here that you haven't seen if you've played Pandemic (do something good, now do something bad. Repeat). The dice add an element of push-your-luck whilst allowing you to play safe but risk running out of time (actions).

It was fun, and I did enjoy it. It didn't seem to take as long as I'm told it did which is always a good sign, but I really have no need to pick this up.

Update: On a second play, I'm noticing little bits that annoy me, like how's there's no way to mark a -1 that's permanent versus one that is just for the round. Like how there are seven million little bits in the game (streamlined it isn't). It also really doesn't play any differently to all the other co-ops out there.

Rating down from 7 to 6.2.

RATING: 6
Very good co-op game in which you're trying to survive through different scenarios. I like the deck buildning feature of the game that makes each game a unique story and in which all decisions you make might (and most often WILL) come back and mess up your life in a later turn. Very rich theme that goes well with the game engine.

OK components with a very "euroish" feel, wooden discs, cubes etc. I feel they give the game a slight "warsaw pact dullness" with the chosen colours. In a game with such a rich theme one would expect some miniatures and luxurious tokens.

Unforunately this game also confirmed my fear of co op games. I just can't help feeling like a teacher, helping all the other players with decisions and so on. I'm the biggest "gamer" of my gaming group. This leads to me not being able to immerse myself in the game and I don't have any fun.

RATING: 9.5
Far and away my favorite game. Theme runs very deep, tons of variety. Can run long (2hrs.) with new players, but the theme is appealing to gamers and non-gamers alike. Female representation of characters is a big plus as well. I have the expansion and all the extras as well, but plays fantastic with just the base game. I still think about different individual plays of this game often. Can't recommend this enough. Seems overwhelming at first with massive rules reading, but once you get the gameplay, is very easy to teach and set-up. Still a bear to organize all the pieces and tokens. Order an organizer with it. This is running about $200 online right now and I wouldn't even consider selling it.

RATING: 9
  I raised my rating from an 8 to a 9 because this game just gets better the more I play it. Not easier, mind you, but better.

  It just evokes such a great feeling of being on a deserted island that you're trying to explore (without dying!), and slowly wasting away while you try to accomplish more than you can do safely.

  For some people, having the game grind you down is not for them, and I get that. But I think it's fantastic. Love Ignacy's work.

  One of my top ten of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Fiendishly difficult to the point of frustration. Yet my biggest complaint is that this co-op feels very much like an overly elaborate game of solitaire with too many moving parts that add up to more chrome than substance. That's not to say there weren't parts I enjoyed. The overall theming, and especially the feeling of exploration, was lots of fun. The incidental artwork was charming even if the character drawings were atrocious -- especially the women. And the joy of flipping over a card to reveal the next part of the adventure was exciting. However, none of it added up to a game I really want to play on a regular basis. As a solitaire game, it's just too much. As a co-op, it never really felt like a shared experience. Too much chrome on top of too much difficulty on top of too much luck of the draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Wow!  I had read the hype about this one but it still managed to blow me out of the water.

It's a highly challenging solo/co-op formed around the best implementation of worker placement that I've tried.  It also delivers what might be the best executed narrative of any game I've tried.  It has tonnes of variety, with six very different scenarios in the box (and more that can be downloaded in BGG's file section).  Gorgeous art, too -- this is one of the best-looking games I've seen.

The only aspect it falls short on is the crap rulebook, which is a poor resource for learning the game and is even worse for trying to look up specific rules.  Even the list of components was frustrating to read through.  But the obtuse and borderline incomplete rulebook isn't a dealbreaker for me.  This has the potential to be my absolute favourite game.  It's exactly in my wheelhouse.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A survival game with interesting decisions throughout. I mostly play solo and absolutely love it. The game creates a rich story that you will enjoy discussing or recounting after the game is over.

RATING: 6
Intriguing Cooperative Boardgame. Mixes survival and worker placement elements with a stranded on a (not so) deserted island theme. 

Slightly over-ambitious and clunky ruleset combined with a messy (English) rulebook, but doesn't stop the game from being enjoyable and entertaining, albeit slightly long which lends it too overstaying its welcome at times. Another downside is the constant book keeping and remembering what should be resulted, certainly not an intuitive game by any means.

Enjoyable. But maybe better as a solitaire game.

RATING: N/A
1-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Wow, that rulebook! I knew going in that the rulebook was notoriously bad, so I thought I could get a pretty good handle on it. I was wrong. There are so many cards and so many special situations that come up in any single game that you're constantly having to go to the rulebook. Often times the answers are either really vague or  just not there, so you'll be spending quite a bit of time on the forums if you want to get the rules right.

Once you get past that, the game is not too bad. It does a good job of sticking to the theme and the whole element of placing two discs for a guaranteed success, or one disc for a riskier move, is pretty unique.

However, it does feel like your win or loss is mostly controlled by the luck of the cards and dice. Sometimes you feel like you're making all of the right decisions, using your special abilities to your best advantage, but you still just get destroyed by a bad roll of the weather dice or by the wrong card coming up at the wrong time.

I'm giving this a 6 for now because while it's not a great game, it's not a bad experience.

Sold.

RATING: 9
After 1 play, I already know this game has everything I like.  Scenarios, Event cards, variable player powers, different actions, and hard decisions. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The keyword here is "immersive". 

This game is very good at making every single decisions matter. it's very hard, and that's a good thing. A "good" hard cooperative games make you think and actually work for what you want to accomplish. 

The outcomes in this game will only depend on how you will deal with every situations. Are you willing to take a gamble on something in order to have more ressources? Are you willing to put all of your ressources on one action only during an entire turn just to make sure everything succeeds? It's very good at making you feel awesome when you accomplish something and terrible when you don't, but at least, you will learn from your mistakes and become a true survivor.

It's almost perfect, and I say ALMOST because there is one thing that bothered me a bit. The game didn't come with a "turn summary" which made my first plays very painful for other players since I was constantly reading the manual searching for one little thing hidden in a billion words paragraph.

Luckily, user PunTheHun made a fantastic summary sheet with everything we needed to remember during a turn, so that's awesome.

Another must own game if you are fan of cooperative games, hard games...or games in general I guess ?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I have only played the first scenario solo so far and found it to be easier to win than i first thought it would be, however because the first scenario doesn't really call for you to engage much with some of the elements of the game (the hunting deck, invention cards, special abilities) I really need to play this again and get this in front of my group. As a solo player i never really needed to worry about food, morale, and threat aspects but in a larger game i can see these mattering much much more.

*Update - Now having played a full 4 player game (we still only played the 1st scenario as they were all new to this game) I really enjoyed it, we got the win but only just and had to engage with several more mechanics than when i played solo. I still didnt find the threat actions very bad but perhaps we got lucky with our card draws. I'm looking forward to playing this again soon!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is one of those games that I appreciate more in theory than in practice.  It's a very smart piece of design, the system is very malleable and interesting.  But the game play is so tight and does not forgive any mistakes or bad luck which doesn't feel right.

It appears to be a sandbox game where you can sort of have fun with it and be creative in your decisions but you really cannot do things because you just want to do them.  You need to always take the perfect actions or take massive damage, which takes some fun out of the game.

On top of this the rules are pretty poorly written and quite clunky, which makes it more of a chore to play.

It's definitely a fun game to try but it's certainly ranked higher than it should be.

RATING: 8.25
A brutal co-operative that keeps its players on the ropes from start to finish. The storytelling opportunities are rather unique, where an event takes place but is then shuffled back into the event deck, where it may come back to haunt your group.

Like many co-operative titles, Quarterbacking may become a problem with certain groups, but this felt like a natural step up in complexity from a title like Pandemic.

RATING: 5
Gorgeous art & components. 2nd edition is the prettiest box I've owned. The difficulty balance is too knife-edge, and every single mechanic is just another way to hurt you. Depressing and draining. Character abilities feel like convoluted patches to the framework rather than interesting twists to gameplay.
The forced action order felt out of place, restricting for the sake of it.
The game is clearly designed as punishing and unrelenting, but without giving the players much empowerment - only resignation that their slow death is the probable outcome. Take the dog to ease the pain - he'll outlive you.

RATING: 7
I really love ameritrash/euro hybrids, games that, while embracing the theme and/or telling/creating a story, use well thought of, wasy to grasp, difficult to master mechanics. Robinson Crusoe definitely falls into this category. It is brilliant. I just don't like the theme too much.

RATING: 7
Signed Ignatzi at Essen 2012. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A Modern Boardgame design, another sign of the future of boardgames. Combines the elements of the retro "Ameritrash" and "Eurogame" categories into an immersive yet strategic cooperative game.

Good flow of play, a plethora of choices, absolutely great sense of accomplishment, tough risk assessment, layers upon layers of theme and narration, amazing replayability, manageable luck.. Really this game does so many things great that it really seems like an instant classic. In addition this game takes one of my favorite mechanics, events that trigger with a delay, and boosts it up to venus.

On the downside there is the classic Alpha Player problem of several co-op games. I don't really see an in-game way to deal with this (one player dominating the others and ordering them around), other than the amount of choices that call for many brains to smoothly plan for them. Player groups that have this problem will like the experience, but not the game. In addition, the game really is a bit fiddly in practice, but not to the point of frustration.

Overall this game is a blast, especially for co-op lovers (like me!), and even co-op haters might find this engaging enough to enjoy. It's one of those games that leave an instant mark and you might catch yourself thinking about it hours after your play, and its narrative may well survive to become a point of discussion long after the gaming session is over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a really challenging cooperative board game. While it is really well made, it is too fiddley for my tastes.

RATING: 6


I had heard that this game was insanely hard.  And I can certainly see how things could go wrong very quickly.  We were fairly lucky and managed to sail through the introductory scenario without too much of an issue.

I enjoyed the game a lot.  There's not a lot you get to do on your turn, and there's usually more that you want to do than can get done.  Which means that you'll want to work with your team and try to make sure everybody's on the same page in terms of what should get done.  What I really liked about the game was the narrative that we built around the game.  For example, our accident prone explorer insisted on crafting most of the game, and managed to fail to build anything three times out of four (but boy was he determined, ha get it?, to build that map!)  

I also like that there are various scenarios and that repeat plays will have different objectives and will play out very differently.  I'm already looking forward to trying a different scenario.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
OK.  This game is something.  Wow, the instructions almost left me more confused.  It took about four reads before I could try to play without constantly looking at the rulebook.  There are some great cheat sheets on BGG that really make the game more smooth.  One you get the flow of the game, it makes for a great game.  It is very challenging even on the first 'castaways' scenario.  However, I strived to beat it and would actually play games back to back to try to beat it until I did...once so far as solo, and once barely with two players WITH the dog and Friday.  It is an addicting game with pretty cool choices and a great theme.  I also like the fact that there are no 'real' turns for players.  Players discuss on what to do together and place their pawns in those locations.  Makes it where you can theme the game to new players very easily.  As long as the game master doesn't control the game and plays it as "We just crashed and this may be what is coming, what should we do?" type of game master...it should be fun for all.  UPDATE:  The more I play this game, the more I like it.  The theme has really jumped out at me now, and I just love how things like cuts and scrapes will get worse with time unless you have a cure, etc... I now am playing with the beagle expansion and just love it...even though it is hard, I enjoy the challenge.  It has been on my table for days set up and it is not being put away anytime soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Self-flagellation gamified. The game successfully captures the desperation of slowly starving to death stranded on a desert island. An overwhelming oppressive narrative develops as nearly every game event has a net-negative outcome. Survival can be delightful, but losing after three hours of play is near unforgivable. Additionally, the game is overly fiddly with too much board management and promises a sense of adventure and discovery that it fails to deliver. I'd rather be on Gilligan's Island.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So I can understand the hype behind this cooperative game. It is both flavorful and thematic to the core. A throughly enjoyable design by Ignacy and one that deserves a high rating based on a few plays. However, like all text-heavy co-op games, repeated plays will likely reduce the score since as more text cards are explored, the novelty will wear off. The scenarios however, are quite rich and will provide a variety of challenges for many years to come.

The game features obstacles and hurdles coming from exploration, hunting and surviving the island enroute to achieving specific victory conditions. I find that the game balance is quite exquisite and a few crucial missteps may cause players to lose the game. However, careful planning and repeated plays will probably reveal some basic strategies for surviving the island.

A couple of novel mechanisms: Dual use cards akin to "choose-your-own-adventure" cards where picking a beneficial short-term reward may lead to a negative outcome further down the road. Love the risk-reward mechanism coupled with action selection where doubling your action prevents risk.

A great game design and worthy of some gaming awards
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Fantastic co-op that captures the feel of the genre beautifully. As a kid I loved reading Robinson Crusoe, Swiss Family Robinson and all the others - and this game taps right into those memories. 
Graphic design is beautiful, and the board has a map-like, castaway diary feel that is a pleasure to look at. 
My only gripe is the jarring illustrations on the character cards: why, when the rest of the game is so thematic, do the characters resemble steampunk rejects from the 19th century? Pith helmets, goggles and repeaters? Come on guys - disappointing band-wagon jumping. If this post ever gets read by the designers, PLEASE include replacement cards in an expansion.

RATING: N/A
:star::star::star::nostar:

I finally figured out what I don't like about Robinson Crusoe. It's a fine game, but it's just not for me. I think it makes the opposite move that Mage Knight does.

Mage Knight takes the Ameritrashy adventuring-hero-slaughters-monsters conceit but replaces the heart of its gameplay with a Euro-ish deck-builder-resource-management-thinky-thinky game. I love that.

Robinson Crusoe takes the Euro resource-gathering-worker-placement conceit but replaces the heart of its gameplay to with an Ameritrashy throw-dice-press-your-luck-draw-cards-risky-risky game. Meh, not what I want. When I want to go AT, I'll go all out with something like Eldritch Horror.

RATING: 8.1
achat neuf
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is amazing! It is -by far- the best coop game I've played! It also is the best Solo game I've played!
Once you digest the rules (which is the hard part), it is dripping with theme, the mechanics are superb, the tension can be overwhelming.

The 6 base Scenarios offer 6 very different experiences, as does the number of Characters used: 4 characters offer a lot of options BUT require a lot of resources for building and feeding! on the other hand with 1 or 2 characters, you have so few actions available that every single choice you make is critical!

More than a game, it is a story generator (Archipelago does that to a lesser extend). Depending on the first Events you draw as well as the first Island Tiles revealed, the same Scenario can/must be played very differently from one session to another.

I've been playing this game non-stop since I got it, I have beaten the first 5 scenarios at least twice, I'm close to a 50/50 win/loss track record BUT I still have not beaten the 6th (survived with the family but could not build all 9 items); I still have 3 additional scenarios to try and I am currently working on my own Scenarios (LOST-themed)!
Once again, amazing game!

update: I have now played and beaten every scenarios, including King Kong, the Naturalist, Leviathan's defeat, Zombie Island, Dino Island, Fallout.
update: also Livigstone, HMS Baikou, Hunters, LOST.
Now I need the French version of Voyage of the Beagle!

[+] everything is top-notch: theme, mechanics, replayability, components
[-] lots of rules to digest

RATING: 4
Was bored of it after 3 plays. Cool theme. I can see why a lot of people would like this game. But really, it gets boring (for me) because no matter what choices are made, there is very little way to mitigate luck. If you play safe enough to not die, you struggle to beat the scenario objectives. If you play to get the scenario objectives, you die from not playing safe enough. In the end, striking that balance between the two is pretty simple but then it just comes down to a crap shoot of card draws and dice rolls. Thus it feels like meaningful decisions are few and easily made.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Totally unique coop game. All about optimization and intuitive handling of events. The obligatory randomness of the event deck gets straightened out a bit by the cool mechanic wherein every event has a follow-up, of which you know it is going to come out, but you don't know when. Adds a lot of tension to the game, but the game still suffers from deterministic action taking sometimes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this might be the pinnacle of co-op games. The system is so robust that even though every scenario uses the exact same mechanisms, each one feels completely unique. Even replays of the same scenario rarely repeat their narrative. The highlight is the encounter system that not only forces you to make a difficult decision when it triggers, but then makes you deal with the consequences of that decision a second time when it pops up again in the event deck. It's incredibly clever and extremely immersive. 

The rulebook is a mess and there are still a few unresolved issues the FAQ hasn't addressed, but it's nothing that can't be worked around. Trust me, it's worth the effort...Adventure awaits!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Le doy un 6 provisional hasta nueva partida donde seguramente mejorará.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Do not waste your time. Another poorly designed game by Ignacy Trzewiczek
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Short version is that this is good for what it is but not my thing.

I have to really love a game to put up with as many bits as this one has. Rules were also not entirely clear until we started - I think this is one of those that's harder to get your head around than the complexity would imply (like trying to learn Race for the Galaxy if you haven't played Puerto Rico or San Juan).

Obviously co-op games need something to prevent one player from bossing the others around. This game achieves that through randomness, and as a result, you have to play very reactively. I found myself unable to plan very effectively more than half a turn or so in advance. As far as reactive games go, this is one of the better ones I've played (though not on the level of, say, Battlestar Galactica) - but I found it very frustrating, even though we won. I felt like the dice going our way were a larger component in our victory than our choices, and I don't like that feeling.

Then again, I'm already predisposed against co-ops. I'd rather play this again than, say, Ghost Stories, so take that for what it's worth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Still in plastic
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vera sorpresa del 2012, non tanto per il sistema cooperativo diverso dal solito ma soprattutto per la assoluta rigiocabilità, si possono creare scenari infiniti con infinite sfide.

RATING: N/A
Structurally interesting but not all that original. Lots of built-in variability, at least superficially. Rules are curiously over- and under-written, and hopeless for a quick-start first game. I find the graphics muddy and amateurish, but they are thematic, I suppose.

It does not address the play-by-committee or alpha player problem at all, despite the designer's protestations to the contrary. In fact, given the complexity and the tightness/difficulty, this is a problem child on that score.

RATING: 7
This game offers a very cutthroat and tight coop experience for strategic gamers; it also offers a very immersive storytelling experience through a clever implementation of the adventure decks. It excels Pandemic + On the Brink in many aspects.

After you learn the basics from scenario 1, however, only scenario 6 seems to reach the game's full potential. Scenarios 2-3 are too easy, and 4-5 are fiddly. I feel that there is a lot of room for improvement, through 1) new scenarios, 2) a mobile app handling adventures, or 3) more diversity in inventions.

The cannibal scenario can be really imbalanced if you draw several of the book symbol event cards at the very beginning. I drew the one with 2 books on it and that basically takes you down half of your total life.

RATING: 5
There are few designers who take pleasure in crafting overwrought games with freakishly bad rulebooks, but Iggy T is definitely one of them. 

I mean, what other game has spawned multiple comprehensive FAQs that are 20 to 60 pages long? Besides [i]Stronghold[/i], that is, the designer's other muddled disappointment.

In the Castaways scenario, I loved my brush with gangrene and our feverish destruction of a charging ape.  But that was only 1% of our gaming experience, with the rest consisting of listless debate of where to place our wooden cylinders.

Next time, more gangrene and less wood.  Please.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is my favorite game right now.  I cant imagine how long it took to play test a game that is both tightly tuned and yet plays like an open ended adventure.  

Mad props to Ignacy, his team, and all of the people who play tested this.

There are other games that I really like for other reasons, but this one is the most fun I've ever had while thinking really hard and often losing at a board game.

I've played four games now (won 2, lost 2, all outcomes very close.)  9 rating is conservative.  I dont like to hand out 10s and I'm waiting to see if there's a reason it shouldnt be a 10.  My only complaint is that the rules could be better organized - I dont even think that many of the ambiguity complaints are warranted for the most part, information is just not ideally organized in the rulebook making it very easy to miss rules that make critical distinctions. Fortunately we have a horde of BGGers helping each other figure it out.

10/26 - some scenarios are more fun and have more replayability than others.  Not everyone likes the feeling of struggling on an island and some people think its too fiddly for what you end up "doing."  I dont have that problem.  I love the game and will play solo when I dont have anyone else to play with.

Sticking with 9 rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Big game with lots of stuff, and a load of bits. But it isn't all used at once, and is all logical and there to help you keep track of things with a minimum of fuss. The actual game is hard, but makes sense, and you can figure out what to do logically then apply it to the game, which helps. Loads of variety in setup, and the 6 scenarios (plus others downloadable) give a lot more replayability than appears - it's highly unlikely you'll complete any successfully first time, and if you do... well, let's see you do it again! It is full of little choices, and does need planning & micromanagement, as well as lots of moving bits around the board, which some find annoying.

There's also assistance built in for solo play.

RATING: 10
One of the best game I've played. Is difficult, but really fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have only played this game twice solo on the first scenario but I thoroughly enjoy it. Unlike other games that I've played (other than Mage Knight) that say they can be played solo, this game feels like it's been designed that way and isn't some sort of variant that's been tacked on. 

The game is full of tough choices and doesn't seem like it would ever lose its replay value. Having 6 difference scenarios, a number of different characters with their own unique abilities and the sheer randomness of the cards, tiles, etc... I don't think that you could ever get bored. All of the components are beautifully designed and are of high quality too.

Like most coop games where the players are fighting the game itself... it's very punishing. There are also quite a few little rules to take in to account and the sequence of events is important to remember. Most of the systemic concerns I believe would disappear the more comfortable I became with the game. Only having played it twice now and pretty much a year apart, I think that I should get a couple more games in soon to really get the game down and then see what the other people in my group think. We don't tend to play co-ops, but this is something that they've seemed interested in in the past, so I might as well see what they think. If, at the end of the day, they don't enjoy it, I don't think that I'd ever get rid of it because I can already tell that it's a solid system and game. Its rating should only climb as I play it more. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
A very thematic cooperative worker-placement game, where you play as survivors on an island that is trying everything it can do to kill your group.
It's an excellent game with a ton of stuff going on. There are more or less only four main actions that your workers can do, but everytime these play out very differently and make for a really interesting, very enthralling game that tells exciting stories. You never know what the island is going to hit you with next and there could be danger or treasures under each card, leading to very involved discussions between players when planning the next turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
not real complaints here.  It is a perfect thematic blend of strategy and tactical game play in a cooperative environment.

RATING: 9
I love the theme of this game and how it is implemented. It tells a great story of adventure and survival. It is one of the best realisations of a theme I have experienced playing a board game. Exceptional.
Wins: 18
Losses: 11
Aborts: 5 (due to getting the scenario rules wrong, cat sabotage or poor time management)

+ Voyage of the Beagle, Extra animals, King Kong, sailor, beach expansion, Dr Livingstone and treasure island.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very fun game and my favorite co-op. Varied scenarios combine with interesting actions and random setup to create a pretty unique experience each time. Also the storytelling actually makes sense in this game as opposed to the Arkham/Eldritch style of forced/"disconnected from gameplay" storytelling.

Production quality is lacking for the MSRP. Wooden cubes are generic, the plastic cubes feel cheap and the wooden discs should've had the character art engraved in them with a price like this.

RATING: 8
I'd say the feel of this game is right between Pandemic (strong planning for next turn and seeing where likely trouble will occur) and Ghost Stories (sometimes needing to rely on the dice to succeed and you get kicked in the head from random directions a lot too)... so its pretty darn good.  The story scenarios seems like a lot of fun to explore and with those huge decks of cards I doubt this ever feels all that samey.  Gwen wants to see the components first... but I think we might be adding this to our collection.

RATING: 8
Kooperacja przygodowa ze scenariuszami. Gracze: 1-4 Tłumaczenie: średnio, da się grać z osobą która ogarnia. Wymagania: cierpliwość i niezłomność. Czas: 3h + 1/3h per os.

Dużo klimatu - motyw rozbitków z epoki powieści Robinson Crusoe. Bywa trudna, trochę trwa. Ma sporo zasad, ale nie trzeba ich znać na pamięć, jeśli jest jedna osoba, która je zna. Brak downtime'u.

RATING: 9
An amazing co op game. Very hard to win

The Good:
-The theme is so integrated in the mechanisms.
-The story is so immersive
-I love the planning. You really have to work together.
-The game feels like you are struggling to survive
-The event mechanism is one of my favorite mechanisms of all time.
-High replay value
-Some humor in this

The Bad:
-The rulebook(I think the new edition has fixed that)
-Very hard. So if you don't like games that are very hard, stay away.

RATING: 8
Very nice game with good components, beautiful artwork and interesting theme! The rulebook is quite long, but well written and exhaustive.
After a few turns the game mechanics became easier, but the game is still quite difficult (but not impossible) to win.
It always gives you that feeling of not being able to do all the things that you need (which matches perfectly the theme), but it's also very rewarding when you finally make it to your goal!

RATING: 7
Seems a bit overhyped.  So far, scenarios seem pretty hard - maybe so hard that luck of the roll/draw becomes as important as strategy.  I don't mind a challenge, but the game seems to be just one bad thing after another and after a while that pain reduces some of the fun.

I think Castaways is a better game than this one because it is more fun to play and its theme and story is just as rich.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played two games of scenario 1 back to back ...lost both :-) however I am completely hooked by this game! Gather wood and food, survive the night build a shelter and try to stockpile wood all with far too few actions, it is great fun and requires a mixture of luck and adaptability of playing style. I particularly enjoy the adventure cards that get shuffled back into the event deck lurking there ready to scupper your plans at any moment, building tension as the game progresses.

update 02 Sept 2013: after 4 more plays we finally beat scenario 1. We then tried Scenario 2 and died very quickly:-) I highly recommend this game. Everyone should have a go at playing it at least once.

....Someone should definitely make a Cthulhu inspired ^^^/;,;/^^^scenario... oh wait Arkham horror :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably the most thematic game of my entire collection (250+ games). Robinson Crusoe is an enjoyable experience, but there are too many rule ambiguities to consider this game a masterpiece. I have spent more time in the rulebook or on this forum than actually playing the game. 

  Also, the box states that it plays in 2 hours, but expect 3-4 hours for your first plays (even solitaire).

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
This is a coop where the theme blends perfectly with the gameplay. The atmosphere of being castaways breathes throughout the game and a story unfolds in each play. 
The luck in this game is containable. You can take risks and push your luck, but you always have the option to play safe. The event and action cards never seem unfair and even give you a decision. You can take the benefits now and worry about the consequences later when the cards comes back. The dice don't feel unfair either since you can spend earned tokens to reroll. 
The teamplay is very prone to alpha players giving orders or directions. But you can always make your own decision or discuss the group plan. You never feel forced nor have the feeling the game demands You to take a certain actions, it instead demands that the Group takes actions to survive. The experience becomes better with fewer players, or when all players are equally familiar with the rules and gameflow. 
There is a lot of variation due to the different scenario's. Balance: the first scenario is too easy with 4 players. And that's bad since the game thrives on the feeling of survival and thus needs to be hard to evoke that feeling. The game is very moddable, it provides a game system and you can create your own scenario's. The game is also great for solo play.

RATING: 8
Extremely thematic, but very complicated and the rules don't do the best job of teaching it. It took us three games to even be sure we were playing it correctly. Even once you get the rules correct, it is very difficult, which I think is a positive but others might find frustrating as it is very punishing and unforgiving. You really have to struggle and work together to survive, taking chances which may or may not pay off.

RATING: N/A
2/5/14 -- Half a solo play in and, frankly, I got a little bored.  Of course, I was still learning the rules and I have the attention span of a gnat these days, so make of that what you will.  It seems the game missed some opportunities to reinforce the theme, favoring instead abstract procedure.  For example, the weapons track?  What is this representing, how many spears I've made?  The events et al seem a little bit dry, e.g. a storm happened, take a wound.  Uhhh, OK.

But it's far too soon for a well-formed opinion.  I'll probably try pulling it out for BrianCon '14, wherein it will have the best chance for success.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love how this handles its random element: you never technically *have* to roll dice; but taking calculated risks can be very beneficial.

I also love its storytelling element. Adding encounter cards to the event deck based on your choices is really brilliant.

It's longer than what I typically like but it does a lot really well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
R
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very impressive thematic/strategy mixture. I really enjoy the brutal difficulty and balance between luck and effective play. Robinson Crusoe seems to be a game that you can win or lose when playing well but simply cannot win when playing poorly. It requires you to learn its inner workings, plume strategic depths, and experiment with new plans. All the while it's cackling in the corner with devious intent. Let's see if its measly 6 scenarios can stand the test of time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
For me, this is the best co-op out there. Superb theme and a harsh island where you really have to fight for survival. Some brilliant mechanics in there too, and 6 scenarios in the box to keep things fresh. This is also much less of a 'puzzle' than Pandemic is too. Thumbs up.
